      64             : namespace nlohmann
      65             : {
      66             : /*!
      67             : @brief default JSONSerializer template argument
      68             : 
      69             : This serializer ignores the template arguments and uses ADL
      70             : ([argument-dependent lookup](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/adl))
      71             : for serialization.
      72             : */
      73             : template<typename T = void, typename SFINAE = void>
      74             : struct adl_serializer;
      75             : 
      76             : template<template<typename U, typename V, typename... Args> class ObjectType =
      77             :          std::map,
      78             :          template<typename U, typename... Args> class ArrayType = std::vector,
      79             :          class StringType = std::string, class BooleanType = bool,
      80             :          class NumberIntegerType = std::int64_t,
      81             :          class NumberUnsignedType = std::uint64_t,
      82             :          class NumberFloatType = double,
      83             :          template<typename U> class AllocatorType = std::allocator,
      84             :          template<typename T, typename SFINAE = void> class JSONSerializer =
      85             :          adl_serializer>
      86             : class basic_json;
      87             : 
      88             : /*!
      89             : @brief JSON Pointer
      90             : 
      91             : A JSON pointer defines a string syntax for identifying a specific value
      92             : within a JSON document. It can be used with functions `at` and
      93             : `operator[]`. Furthermore, JSON pointers are the base for JSON patches.
      94             : 
      95             : @sa [RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)
      96             : 
      97             : @since version 2.0.0
      98             : */
      99             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
     100             : class json_pointer;
     101             : 
     102             : /*!
     103             : @brief default JSON class
     104             : 
     105             : This type is the default specialization of the @ref basic_json class which
     106             : uses the standard template types.
     107             : 
     108             : @since version 1.0.0
     109             : */
     110             : using json = basic_json<>;
     111             : }
     112             : 
     113             : #endif
     114             : 
     115             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_scope.hpp>
     116             : 
     117             : 
     118             : // This file contains all internal macro definitions
     119             : // You MUST include macro_unscope.hpp at the end of json.hpp to undef all of them
     120             : 
     121             : // exclude unsupported compilers
     122             : #if defined(__clang__)
     123             :     #if (__clang_major__ * 10000 + __clang_minor__ * 100 + __clang_patchlevel__) < 30400
     124             :         #error "unsupported Clang version - see https://github.com/nlohmann/json#supported-compilers"
     125             :     #endif
     126             : #elif defined(__GNUC__) && !(defined(__ICC) || defined(__INTEL_COMPILER))
     127             :     #if (__GNUC__ * 10000 + __GNUC_MINOR__ * 100 + __GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__) < 40900
     128             :         #error "unsupported GCC version - see https://github.com/nlohmann/json#supported-compilers"
     129             :     #endif
     130             : #endif
     131             : 
     132             : // disable float-equal warnings on GCC/clang
     133             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
     134             :     #pragma GCC diagnostic push
     135             :     #pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Wfloat-equal"
     136             : #endif
     137             : 
     138             : // disable documentation warnings on clang
     139             : #if defined(__clang__)
     140             :     #pragma GCC diagnostic push
     141             :     #pragma GCC diagnostic ignored "-Wdocumentation"
     142             : #endif
     143             : 
     144             : // allow for portable deprecation warnings
     145             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
     146             :     #define JSON_DEPRECATED __attribute__((deprecated))
     147             : #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
     148             :     #define JSON_DEPRECATED __declspec(deprecated)
     149             : #else
     150             :     #define JSON_DEPRECATED
     151             : #endif
     152             : 
     153             : // allow to disable exceptions
     154             : #if (defined(__cpp_exceptions) || defined(__EXCEPTIONS) || defined(_CPPUNWIND)) && !defined(JSON_NOEXCEPTION)
     155             :     #define JSON_THROW(exception) throw exception
     156             :     #define JSON_TRY try
     157             :     #define JSON_CATCH(exception) catch(exception)
     158             : #else
     159             :     #define JSON_THROW(exception) std::abort()
     160             :     #define JSON_TRY if(true)
     161             :     #define JSON_CATCH(exception) if(false)
     162             : #endif
     163             : 
     164             : // override exception macros
     165             : #if defined(JSON_THROW_USER)
     166             :     #undef JSON_THROW
     167             :     #define JSON_THROW JSON_THROW_USER
     168             : #endif
     169             : #if defined(JSON_TRY_USER)
     170             :     #undef JSON_TRY
     171             :     #define JSON_TRY JSON_TRY_USER
     172             : #endif
     173             : #if defined(JSON_CATCH_USER)
     174             :     #undef JSON_CATCH
     175             :     #define JSON_CATCH JSON_CATCH_USER
     176             : #endif
     177             : 
     178             : // manual branch prediction
     179             : #if defined(__clang__) || defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__GNUG__)
     180             :     #define JSON_LIKELY(x)      __builtin_expect(!!(x), 1)
     181             :     #define JSON_UNLIKELY(x)    __builtin_expect(!!(x), 0)
     182             : #else
     183             :     #define JSON_LIKELY(x)      x
     184             :     #define JSON_UNLIKELY(x)    x
     185             : #endif
     186             : 
     187             : // C++ language standard detection
     188             : #if (defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 201703L) || (defined(_HAS_CXX17) && _HAS_CXX17 == 1) // fix for issue #464
     189             :     #define JSON_HAS_CPP_17
     190             :     #define JSON_HAS_CPP_14
     191             : #elif (defined(__cplusplus) && __cplusplus >= 201402L) || (defined(_HAS_CXX14) && _HAS_CXX14 == 1)
     192             :     #define JSON_HAS_CPP_14
     193             : #endif
     194             : 
     195             : // Ugly macros to avoid uglier copy-paste when specializing basic_json. They
     196             : // may be removed in the future once the class is split.
     197             : 
     198             : #define NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION                                \
     199             :     template<template<typename, typename, typename...> class ObjectType,   \
     200             :              template<typename, typename...> class ArrayType,              \
     201             :              class StringType, class BooleanType, class NumberIntegerType, \
     202             :              class NumberUnsignedType, class NumberFloatType,              \
     203             :              template<typename> class AllocatorType,                       \
     204             :              template<typename, typename = void> class JSONSerializer>
     205             : 
     206             : #define NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL                                            \
     207             :     basic_json<ObjectType, ArrayType, StringType, BooleanType,             \
     208             :     NumberIntegerType, NumberUnsignedType, NumberFloatType,                \
     209             :     AllocatorType, JSONSerializer>
     210             : 
     211             : /*!
     212             : @brief Helper to determine whether there's a key_type for T.
     213             : 
     214             : This helper is used to tell associative containers apart from other containers
     215             : such as sequence containers. For instance, `std::map` passes the test as it
     216             : contains a `mapped_type`, whereas `std::vector` fails the test.
     217             : 
     218             : @sa http://stackoverflow.com/a/7728728/266378
     219             : @since version 1.0.0, overworked in version 2.0.6
     220             : */
     221             : #define NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(type)                                        \
     222             :     template<typename T> struct has_##type {                                  \
     223             :     private:                                                                  \
     224             :         template<typename U, typename = typename U::type>                     \
     225             :         static int detect(U &&);                                              \
     226             :         static void detect(...);                                              \
     227             :     public:                                                                   \
     228             :         static constexpr bool value =                                         \
     229             :                 std::is_integral<decltype(detect(std::declval<T>()))>::value; \
     230             :     }
     231             : 
     232             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/meta.hpp>

     246             : namespace nlohmann
     247             : {
     248             : /*!
     249             : @brief detail namespace with internal helper functions
     250             : 
     251             : This namespace collects functions that should not be exposed,
     252             : implementations of some @ref basic_json methods, and meta-programming helpers.
     253             : 
     254             : @since version 2.1.0

     256             : namespace detail
     257             : {
     258             : /////////////

     261             : 
     262             : template<typename> struct is_basic_json : std::false_type {};
     263             : 
     264             : NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL_DECLARATION
     265             : struct is_basic_json<NLOHMANN_BASIC_JSON_TPL> : std::true_type {};
     266             : 
     267             : // alias templates to reduce boilerplate
     268             : template<bool B, typename T = void>
     269             : using enable_if_t = typename std::enable_if<B, T>::type;
     270             : 
     271             : template<typename T>
     272             : using uncvref_t = typename std::remove_cv<typename std::remove_reference<T>::type>::type;
     273             : 
     274             : // implementation of C++14 index_sequence and affiliates
     275             : // source: https://stackoverflow.com/a/32223343
     276             : template<std::size_t... Ints>
     277             : struct index_sequence
     278             : {
     279             :     using type = index_sequence;
     280             :     using value_type = std::size_t;
     281             :     static constexpr std::size_t size() noexcept
     282             :     {
     283             :         return sizeof...(Ints);
     284             :     }
     285             : };
     286             : 
     287             : template<class Sequence1, class Sequence2>
     288             : struct merge_and_renumber;
     289             : 
     290             : template<std::size_t... I1, std::size_t... I2>
     291             : struct merge_and_renumber<index_sequence<I1...>, index_sequence<I2...>>
     292             :         : index_sequence < I1..., (sizeof...(I1) + I2)... > {};
     293             : 
     294             : template<std::size_t N>
     295             : struct make_index_sequence
     296             :     : merge_and_renumber < typename make_index_sequence < N / 2 >::type,
     297             :       typename make_index_sequence < N - N / 2 >::type > {};
     298             : 
     299             : template<> struct make_index_sequence<0> : index_sequence<> {};
     300             : template<> struct make_index_sequence<1> : index_sequence<0> {};
     301             : 
     302             : template<typename... Ts>
     303             : using index_sequence_for = make_index_sequence<sizeof...(Ts)>;
     304             : 
     305             : /*
     306             : Implementation of two C++17 constructs: conjunction, negation. This is needed
     307             : to avoid evaluating all the traits in a condition
     308             : 
     309             : For example: not std::is_same<void, T>::value and has_value_type<T>::value
     310             : will not compile when T = void (on MSVC at least). Whereas
     311             : conjunction<negation<std::is_same<void, T>>, has_value_type<T>>::value will
     312             : stop evaluating if negation<...>::value == false
     313             : 
     314             : Please note that those constructs must be used with caution, since symbols can
     315             : become very long quickly (which can slow down compilation and cause MSVC
     316             : internal compiler errors). Only use it when you have to (see example ahead).
     317             : */
     318             : template<class...> struct conjunction : std::true_type {};
     319             : template<class B1> struct conjunction<B1> : B1 {};
     320             : template<class B1, class... Bn>
     321             : struct conjunction<B1, Bn...> : std::conditional<bool(B1::value), conjunction<Bn...>, B1>::type {};
     322             : 
     323             : template<class B> struct negation : std::integral_constant<bool, not B::value> {};
     324             : 
     325             : // dispatch utility (taken from ranges-v3)
     326             : template<unsigned N> struct priority_tag : priority_tag < N - 1 > {};
     327             : template<> struct priority_tag<0> {};
     328             : 
     329             : ////////////////////////
     330             : // has_/is_ functions //
     331             : ////////////////////////
     332             : 
     333             : // source: https://stackoverflow.com/a/37193089/4116453
     334             : 
     335             : template <typename T, typename = void>
     336             : struct is_complete_type : std::false_type {};
     337             : 
     338             : template <typename T>
     339             : struct is_complete_type<T, decltype(void(sizeof(T)))> : std::true_type {};
     340             : 
     341             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(mapped_type);
     342             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(key_type);
     343             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(value_type);
     344             : NLOHMANN_JSON_HAS_HELPER(iterator);
     345             : 
     346             : template<bool B, class RealType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     347             : struct is_compatible_object_type_impl : std::false_type {};
     348             : 
     349             : template<class RealType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     350             : struct is_compatible_object_type_impl<true, RealType, CompatibleObjectType>
     351             : {
     352             :     static constexpr auto value =
     353             :         std::is_constructible<typename RealType::key_type, typename CompatibleObjectType::key_type>::value and
     354             :         std::is_constructible<typename RealType::mapped_type, typename CompatibleObjectType::mapped_type>::value;
     355             : };
     356             : 
     357             : template<class BasicJsonType, class CompatibleObjectType>
     358             : struct is_compatible_object_type
     359             : {
     360             :     static auto constexpr value = is_compatible_object_type_impl <
     361             :                                   conjunction<negation<std::is_same<void, CompatibleObjectType>>,
     362             :                                   has_mapped_type<CompatibleObjectType>,
     363             :                                   has_key_type<CompatibleObjectType>>::value,
     364             :                                   typename BasicJsonType::object_t, CompatibleObjectType >::value;
     365             : };
     366             : 
     367             : template<typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     368             : struct is_basic_json_nested_type
     369             : {
     370             :     static auto constexpr value = std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::iterator>::value or
     371             :                                   std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::const_iterator>::value or
     372             :                                   std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::reverse_iterator>::value or
     373             :                                   std::is_same<T, typename BasicJsonType::const_reverse_iterator>::value;
     374             : };
     375             : 
     376             : template<class BasicJsonType, class CompatibleArrayType>
     377             : struct is_compatible_array_type
     378             : {
     379             :     static auto constexpr value =
     380             :         conjunction<negation<std::is_same<void, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     381             :         negation<is_compatible_object_type<
     382             :         BasicJsonType, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     383             :         negation<std::is_constructible<typename BasicJsonType::string_t,
     384             :         CompatibleArrayType>>,
     385             :         negation<is_basic_json_nested_type<BasicJsonType, CompatibleArrayType>>,
     386             :         has_value_type<CompatibleArrayType>,
     387             :         has_iterator<CompatibleArrayType>>::value;
     388             : };
     389             : 
     390             : template<bool, typename, typename>
     391             : struct is_compatible_integer_type_impl : std::false_type {};
     392             : 
     393             : template<typename RealIntegerType, typename CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     394             : struct is_compatible_integer_type_impl<true, RealIntegerType, CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     395             : {
     396             :     // is there an assert somewhere on overflows?
     397             :     using RealLimits = std::numeric_limits<RealIntegerType>;
     398             :     using CompatibleLimits = std::numeric_limits<CompatibleNumberIntegerType>;
     399             : 
     400             :     static constexpr auto value =
     401             :         std::is_constructible<RealIntegerType, CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value and
     402             :         CompatibleLimits::is_integer and
     403             :         RealLimits::is_signed == CompatibleLimits::is_signed;
     404             : };
     405             : 
     406             : template<typename RealIntegerType, typename CompatibleNumberIntegerType>
     407             : struct is_compatible_integer_type
     408             : {
     409             :     static constexpr auto value =
     410             :         is_compatible_integer_type_impl <
     411             :         std::is_integral<CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value and
     412             :         not std::is_same<bool, CompatibleNumberIntegerType>::value,
     413             :         RealIntegerType, CompatibleNumberIntegerType > ::value;
     414             : };
     415             : 
     416             : // trait checking if JSONSerializer<T>::from_json(json const&, udt&) exists
     417             : template<typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     418             : struct has_from_json
     419             : {
     420             :   private:
     421             :     // also check the return type of from_json
     422             :     template<typename U, typename = enable_if_t<std::is_same<void, decltype(uncvref_t<U>::from_json(
     423             :                  std::declval<BasicJsonType>(), std::declval<T&>()))>::value>>
     424             :     static int detect(U&&);
     425             :     static void detect(...);
     426             : 
     427             :   public:
     428             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(
     429             :                                       detect(std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<T, void>>()))>::value;
     430             : };
     431             : 
     432             : // This trait checks if JSONSerializer<T>::from_json(json const&) exists
     433             : // this overload is used for non-default-constructible user-defined-types
     434             : template<typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     435             : struct has_non_default_from_json
     436             : {
     437             :   private:
     438             :     template <
     439             :         typename U,
     440             :         typename = enable_if_t<std::is_same<
     441             :                                    T, decltype(uncvref_t<U>::from_json(std::declval<BasicJsonType>()))>::value >>
     442             :     static int detect(U&&);
     443             :     static void detect(...);
     444             : 
     445             :   public:
     446             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(detect(
     447             :                                       std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<T, void>>()))>::value;
     448             : };
     449             : 
     450             : // This trait checks if BasicJsonType::json_serializer<T>::to_json exists
     451             : template<typename BasicJsonType, typename T>
     452             : struct has_to_json
     453             : {
     454             :   private:
     455             :     template<typename U, typename = decltype(uncvref_t<U>::to_json(
     456             :                  std::declval<BasicJsonType&>(), std::declval<T>()))>
     457             :     static int detect(U&&);
     458             :     static void detect(...);
     459             : 
     460             :   public:
     461             :     static constexpr bool value = std::is_integral<decltype(detect(
     462             :                                       std::declval<typename BasicJsonType::template json_serializer<T, void>>()))>::value;
     463             : };
     464             : 
     465             : template <typename BasicJsonType, typename CompatibleCompleteType>
     466             : struct is_compatible_complete_type
     467             : {
     468             :     static constexpr bool value =
     469             :         not std::is_base_of<std::istream, CompatibleCompleteType>::value and
     470             :         not is_basic_json<CompatibleCompleteType>::value and
     471             :         not is_basic_json_nested_type<BasicJsonType, CompatibleCompleteType>::value and
     472             :         has_to_json<BasicJsonType, CompatibleCompleteType>::value;
     473             : };

     476             : struct is_compatible_type
     477             :     : conjunction<is_complete_type<CompatibleType>,
     478             :       is_compatible_complete_type<BasicJsonType, CompatibleType>>
     479             : {

     484             : struct static_const
     485             : {
     486             :     static constexpr T value{};
     487             : };
     488             :

     494             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/exceptions.hpp>
     495             : 
     496             : 
     497             : #include <exception> // exception
     498             : #include <stdexcept> // runtime_error
     499             : #include <string> // to_string
     500             : 
     501             : namespace nlohmann
     502             : {
     503             : namespace detail
     504             : {
     505             : ////////////////
     506             : // exceptions //
     507             : ////////////////
     508             : 
     509             : /*!
     510             : @brief general exception of the @ref basic_json class
     511             : 
     512             : This class is an extension of `std::exception` objects with a member @a id for
     513             : exception ids. It is used as the base class for all exceptions thrown by the
     514             : @ref basic_json class. This class can hence be used as "wildcard" to catch
     515             : exceptions.
     516             : 
     517             : Subclasses:
     518             : - @ref parse_error for exceptions indicating a parse error
     519             : - @ref invalid_iterator for exceptions indicating errors with iterators
     520             : - @ref type_error for exceptions indicating executing a member function with
     521             :                   a wrong type
     522             : - @ref out_of_range for exceptions indicating access out of the defined range
     523             : - @ref other_error for exceptions indicating other library errors
     524             : 
     525             : @internal
     526             : @note To have nothrow-copy-constructible exceptions, we internally use
     527             :       `std::runtime_error` which can cope with arbitrary-length error messages.
     528             :       Intermediate strings are built with static functions and then passed to
     529             :       the actual constructor.
     530             : @endinternal
     531             : 
     532             : @liveexample{The following code shows how arbitrary library exceptions can be
     533             : caught.,exception}
     534             : 
     535             : @since version 3.0.0
     536             : */
     537    23253240 : class exception : public std::exception
     538             : {
     539             :   public:
     540             :     /// returns the explanatory string
     541         115 :     const char* what() const noexcept override
     542             :     {
     543         115 :         return m.what();
     544             :     }
     545             : 
     546             :     /// the id of the exception
     547             :     const int id;
     548             : 
     549             :   protected:
     550     7752798 :     exception(int id_, const char* what_arg) : id(id_), m(what_arg) {}
     551             : 
     552     7752798 :     static std::string name(const std::string& ename, int id_)
     553             :     {
     554     7752798 :         return "[json.exception." + ename + "." + std::to_string(id_) + "] ";
     555             :     }
     556             : 
     557             :   private:
     558             :     /// an exception object as storage for error messages
     559             :     std::runtime_error m;
     560             : };
     561             : 
     562             : /*!
     563             : @brief exception indicating a parse error
     564             : 
     565             : This exception is thrown by the library when a parse error occurs. Parse errors
     566             : can occur during the deserialization of JSON text, CBOR, MessagePack, as well
     567             : as when using JSON Patch.
     568             : 
     569             : Member @a byte holds the byte index of the last read character in the input
     570             : file.
     571             : 
     572             : Exceptions have ids 1xx.
     573             : 
     574             : name / id                      | example message | description
     575             : ------------------------------ | --------------- | -------------------------
     576             : json.exception.parse_error.101 | parse error at 2: unexpected end of input; expected string literal | This error indicates a syntax error while deserializing a JSON text. The error message describes that an unexpected token (character) was encountered, and the member @a byte indicates the error position.
     577             : json.exception.parse_error.102 | parse error at 14: missing or wrong low surrogate | JSON uses the `\uxxxx` format to describe Unicode characters. Code points above above 0xFFFF are split into two `\uxxxx` entries ("surrogate pairs"). This error indicates that the surrogate pair is incomplete or contains an invalid code point.
     578             : json.exception.parse_error.103 | parse error: code points above 0x10FFFF are invalid | Unicode supports code points up to 0x10FFFF. Code points above 0x10FFFF are invalid.
     579             : json.exception.parse_error.104 | parse error: JSON patch must be an array of objects | [RFC 6902](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6902) requires a JSON Patch document to be a JSON document that represents an array of objects.
     580             : json.exception.parse_error.105 | parse error: operation must have string member 'op' | An operation of a JSON Patch document must contain exactly one "op" member, whose value indicates the operation to perform. Its value must be one of "add", "remove", "replace", "move", "copy", or "test"; other values are errors.
     581             : json.exception.parse_error.106 | parse error: array index '01' must not begin with '0' | An array index in a JSON Pointer ([RFC 6901](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6901)) may be `0` or any number without a leading `0`.
     582             : json.exception.parse_error.107 | parse error: JSON pointer must be empty or begin with '/' - was: 'foo' | A JSON Pointer must be a Unicode string containing a sequence of zero or more reference tokens, each prefixed by a `/` character.
     583             : json.exception.parse_error.108 | parse error: escape character '~' must be followed with '0' or '1' | In a JSON Pointer, only `~0` and `~1` are valid escape sequences.
     584             : json.exception.parse_error.109 | parse error: array index 'one' is not a number | A JSON Pointer array index must be a number.
     585             : json.exception.parse_error.110 | parse error at 1: cannot read 2 bytes from vector | When parsing CBOR or MessagePack, the byte vector ends before the complete value has been read.
     586             : json.exception.parse_error.112 | parse error at 1: error reading CBOR; last byte: 0xF8 | Not all types of CBOR or MessagePack are supported. This exception occurs if an unsupported byte was read.
     587             : json.exception.parse_error.113 | parse error at 2: expected a CBOR string; last byte: 0x98 | While parsing a map key, a value that is not a string has been read.
     588             : 
     589             : @note For an input with n bytes, 1 is the index of the first character and n+1
     590             :       is the index of the terminating null byte or the end of file. This also
     591             :       holds true when reading a byte vector (CBOR or MessagePack).
     592             : 
     593             : @liveexample{The following code shows how a `parse_error` exception can be
     594             : caught.,parse_error}
     595             : 
     596             : @sa @ref exception for the base class of the library exceptions
     597             : @sa @ref invalid_iterator for exceptions indicating errors with iterators
     598             : @sa @ref type_error for exceptions indicating executing a member function with
     599             :                     a wrong type
     600             : @sa @ref out_of_range for exceptions indicating access out of the defined range
     601             : @sa @ref other_error for exceptions indicating other library errors
     602             : 
     603             : @since version 3.0.0
     604             : */
     605    23252166 : class parse_error : public exception
     606             : {
     607             :   public:
     608             :     /*!
     609             :     @brief create a parse error exception
     610             :     @param[in] id_       the id of the exception
     611             :     @param[in] byte_     the byte index where the error occurred (or 0 if the
     612             :                          position cannot be determined)
     613             :     @param[in] what_arg  the explanatory string
     614             :     @return parse_error object
     615             :     */
     616     7751730 :     static parse_error create(int id_, std::size_t byte_, const std::string& what_arg)
     617             :     {
     618    15503460 :         std::string w = exception::name("parse_error", id_) + "parse error" +
     619    31006920 :                         (byte_ != 0 ? (" at " + std::to_string(byte_)) : "") +
     620    15503460 :                         ": " + what_arg;
     621    15503460 :         return parse_error(id_, byte_, w.c_str());
     622             :     }
     623             : 
     624             :     /*!
     625             :     @brief byte index of the parse error
     626             : 
     627             :     The byte index of the last read character in the input file.
     628             : 
     629             :     @note For an input with n bytes, 1 is the index of the first character and
     630             :           n+1 is the index of the terminating null byte or the end of file.
     631             :           This also holds true when reading a byte vector (CBOR or MessagePack).
     632             :     */
     633             :     const std::size_t byte;
     634             : 
     635             :   private:
     636     7751730 :     parse_error(int id_, std::size_t byte_, const char* what_arg)
     637     7751730 :         : exception(id_, what_arg), byte(byte_) {}
     638             : };
     639             : 
     640             : /*!
     641             : @brief exception indicating errors with iterators
     642             : 
     643             : This exception is thrown if iterators passed to a library function do not match
     644             : the expected semantics.
     645             : 
     646             : Exceptions have ids 2xx.
     647             : 
     648             : name / id                           | example message | description
     649             : ----------------------------------- | --------------- | -------------------------
     650             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.201 | iterators are not compatible | The iterators passed to constructor @ref basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last) are not compatible, meaning they do not belong to the same container. Therefore, the range (@a first, @a last) is invalid.
     651             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.202 | iterator does not fit current value | In an erase or insert function, the passed iterator @a pos does not belong to the JSON value for which the function was called. It hence does not define a valid position for the deletion/insertion.
     652             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.203 | iterators do not fit current value | Either iterator passed to function @ref erase(IteratorType first, IteratorType last) does not belong to the JSON value from which values shall be erased. It hence does not define a valid range to delete values from.
     653             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.204 | iterators out of range | When an iterator range for a primitive type (number, boolean, or string) is passed to a constructor or an erase function, this range has to be exactly (@ref begin(), @ref end()), because this is the only way the single stored value is expressed. All other ranges are invalid.
     654             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.205 | iterator out of range | When an iterator for a primitive type (number, boolean, or string) is passed to an erase function, the iterator has to be the @ref begin() iterator, because it is the only way to address the stored value. All other iterators are invalid.
     655             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.206 | cannot construct with iterators from null | The iterators passed to constructor @ref basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last) belong to a JSON null value and hence to not define a valid range.
     656             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.207 | cannot use key() for non-object iterators | The key() member function can only be used on iterators belonging to a JSON object, because other types do not have a concept of a key.
     657             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.208 | cannot use operator[] for object iterators | The operator[] to specify a concrete offset cannot be used on iterators belonging to a JSON object, because JSON objects are unordered.
     658             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.209 | cannot use offsets with object iterators | The offset operators (+, -, +=, -=) cannot be used on iterators belonging to a JSON object, because JSON objects are unordered.
     659             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.210 | iterators do not fit | The iterator range passed to the insert function are not compatible, meaning they do not belong to the same container. Therefore, the range (@a first, @a last) is invalid.
     660             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.211 | passed iterators may not belong to container | The iterator range passed to the insert function must not be a subrange of the container to insert to.
     661             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.212 | cannot compare iterators of different containers | When two iterators are compared, they must belong to the same container.
     662             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.213 | cannot compare order of object iterators | The order of object iterators cannot be compared, because JSON objects are unordered.
     663             : json.exception.invalid_iterator.214 | cannot get value | Cannot get value for iterator: Either the iterator belongs to a null value or it is an iterator to a primitive type (number, boolean, or string), but the iterator is different to @ref begin().
     664             : 
     665             : @liveexample{The following code shows how an `invalid_iterator` exception can be
     666             : caught.,invalid_iterator}
     667             : 
     668             : @sa @ref exception for the base class of the library exceptions
     669             : @sa @ref parse_error for exceptions indicating a parse error
     670             : @sa @ref type_error for exceptions indicating executing a member function with
     671             :                     a wrong type
     672             : @sa @ref out_of_range for exceptions indicating access out of the defined range
     673             : @sa @ref other_error for exceptions indicating other library errors
     674             : 
     675             : @since version 3.0.0
     676             : */

     691             : /*!
     692             : @brief exception indicating executing a member function with a wrong type
     693             : 
     694             : This exception is thrown in case of a type error; that is, a library function is
     695             : executed on a JSON value whose type does not match the expected semantics.
     696             : 
     697             : Exceptions have ids 3xx.
     698             : 
     699             : name / id                     | example message | description
     700             : ----------------------------- | --------------- | -------------------------
     701             : json.exception.type_error.301 | cannot create object from initializer list | To create an object from an initializer list, the initializer list must consist only of a list of pairs whose first element is a string. When this constraint is violated, an array is created instead.
     702             : json.exception.type_error.302 | type must be object, but is array | During implicit or explicit value conversion, the JSON type must be compatible to the target type. For instance, a JSON string can only be converted into string types, but not into numbers or boolean types.
     703             : json.exception.type_error.303 | incompatible ReferenceType for get_ref, actual type is object | To retrieve a reference to a value stored in a @ref basic_json object with @ref get_ref, the type of the reference must match the value type. For instance, for a JSON array, the @a ReferenceType must be @ref array_t&.
     704             : json.exception.type_error.304 | cannot use at() with string | The @ref at() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     705             : json.exception.type_error.305 | cannot use operator[] with string | The @ref operator[] member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     706             : json.exception.type_error.306 | cannot use value() with string | The @ref value() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     707             : json.exception.type_error.307 | cannot use erase() with string | The @ref erase() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     708             : json.exception.type_error.308 | cannot use push_back() with string | The @ref push_back() and @ref operator+= member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     709             : json.exception.type_error.309 | cannot use insert() with | The @ref insert() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     710             : json.exception.type_error.310 | cannot use swap() with number | The @ref swap() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     711             : json.exception.type_error.311 | cannot use emplace_back() with string | The @ref emplace_back() member function can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     712             : json.exception.type_error.312 | cannot use update() with string | The @ref update() member functions can only be executed for certain JSON types.
     713             : json.exception.type_error.313 | invalid value to unflatten | The @ref unflatten function converts an object whose keys are JSON Pointers back into an arbitrary nested JSON value. The JSON Pointers must not overlap, because then the resulting value would not be well defined.
     714             : json.exception.type_error.314 | only objects can be unflattened | The @ref unflatten function only works for an object whose keys are JSON Pointers.
     715             : json.exception.type_error.315 | values in object must be primitive | The @ref unflatten function only works for an object whose keys are JSON Pointers and whose values are primitive.
     716             : json.exception.type_error.316 | invalid UTF-8 byte at index 10: 0x7E | The @ref dump function only works with UTF-8 encoded strings; that is, if you assign a `std::string` to a JSON value, make sure it is UTF-8 encoded. |
     717             : 
     718             : @liveexample{The following code shows how a `type_error` exception can be
     719             : caught.,type_error}
     720             : 
     721             : @sa @ref exception for the base class of the library exceptions
     722             : @sa @ref parse_error for exceptions indicating a parse error
     723             : @sa @ref invalid_iterator for exceptions indicating errors with iterators
     724             : @sa @ref out_of_range for exceptions indicating access out of the defined range
     725             : @sa @ref other_error for exceptions indicating other library errors
     726             : 
     727             : @since version 3.0.0
     728             : */

     742             : /*!
     743             : @brief exception indicating access out of the defined range
     744             : 
     745             : This exception is thrown in case a library function is called on an input
     746             : parameter that exceeds the expected range, for instance in case of array
     747             : indices or nonexisting object keys.
     748             : 
     749             : Exceptions have ids 4xx.
     750             : 
     751             : name / id                       | example message | description
     752             : ------------------------------- | --------------- | -------------------------
     753             : json.exception.out_of_range.401 | array index 3 is out of range | The provided array index @a i is larger than @a size-1.
     754             : json.exception.out_of_range.402 | array index '-' (3) is out of range | The special array index `-` in a JSON Pointer never describes a valid element of the array, but the index past the end. That is, it can only be used to add elements at this position, but not to read it.
     755             : json.exception.out_of_range.403 | key 'foo' not found | The provided key was not found in the JSON object.
     756             : json.exception.out_of_range.404 | unresolved reference token 'foo' | A reference token in a JSON Pointer could not be resolved.
     757             : json.exception.out_of_range.405 | JSON pointer has no parent | The JSON Patch operations 'remove' and 'add' can not be applied to the root element of the JSON value.
     758             : json.exception.out_of_range.406 | number overflow parsing '10E1000' | A parsed number could not be stored as without changing it to NaN or INF.
     759             : json.exception.out_of_range.407 | number overflow serializing '9223372036854775808' | UBJSON only supports integers numbers up to 9223372036854775807. |
     760             : json.exception.out_of_range.408 | excessive array size: 8658170730974374167 | The size (following `#`) of an UBJSON array or object exceeds the maximal capacity. |
     761             : 
     762             : @liveexample{The following code shows how an `out_of_range` exception can be
     763             : caught.,out_of_range}
     764             :

     825             : 
     826             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/value_t.hpp>
     827             : 
     828             : 
     829             : #include <array> // array
     830             : #include <ciso646> // and
     831             : #include <cstddef> // size_t
     832             : #include <cstdint> // uint8_t
     833             : 
     834             : namespace nlohmann
     835             : {
     836             : namespace detail
     837             : {
     838             : ///////////////////////////
     839             : // JSON type enumeration //
     840             : ///////////////////////////
     841             : 
     842             : /*!
     843             : @brief the JSON type enumeration
     844             : 
     845             : This enumeration collects the different JSON types. It is internally used to
     846             : distinguish the stored values, and the functions @ref basic_json::is_null(),
     847             : @ref basic_json::is_object(), @ref basic_json::is_array(),
     848             : @ref basic_json::is_string(), @ref basic_json::is_boolean(),
     849             : @ref basic_json::is_number() (with @ref basic_json::is_number_integer(),
     850             : @ref basic_json::is_number_unsigned(), and @ref basic_json::is_number_float()),
     851             : @ref basic_json::is_discarded(), @ref basic_json::is_primitive(), and
     852             : @ref basic_json::is_structured() rely on it.
     853             : 
     854             : @note There are three enumeration entries (number_integer, number_unsigned, and
     855             : number_float), because the library distinguishes these three types for numbers:
     856             : @ref basic_json::number_unsigned_t is used for unsigned integers,
     857             : @ref basic_json::number_integer_t is used for signed integers, and
     858             : @ref basic_json::number_float_t is used for floating-point numbers or to
     859             : approximate integers which do not fit in the limits of their respective type.
     860             : 
     861             : @sa @ref basic_json::basic_json(const value_t value_type) -- create a JSON
     862             : value with the default value for a given type
     863             : 
     864             : @since version 1.0.0
     865             : */
     866             : enum class value_t : std::uint8_t
     867             : {
     868             :     null,             ///< null value
     869             :     object,           ///< object (unordered set of name/value pairs)
     870             :     array,            ///< array (ordered collection of values)
     871             :     string,           ///< string value
     872             :     boolean,          ///< boolean value
     873             :     number_integer,   ///< number value (signed integer)
     874             :     number_unsigned,  ///< number value (unsigned integer)
     875             :     number_float,     ///< number value (floating-point)
     876             :     discarded         ///< discarded by the the parser callback function
     877             : };
     878             : 
     879             : /*!
     880             : @brief comparison operator for JSON types
     881             : 
     882             : Returns an ordering that is similar to Python:
     883             : - order: null < boolean < number < object < array < string
     884             : - furthermore, each type is not smaller than itself
     885             : - discarded values are not comparable
     886             : 
     887             : @since version 1.0.0
     888             : */
     889        1643 : inline bool operator<(const value_t lhs, const value_t rhs) noexcept
     890             : {
     891             :     static constexpr std::array<std::uint8_t, 8> order = {{
     892             :             0 /* null */, 3 /* object */, 4 /* array */, 5 /* string */,
     893             :             1 /* boolean */, 2 /* integer */, 2 /* unsigned */, 2 /* float */
     894             :         }
     895             :     };
     896             : 
     897        1643 :     const auto l_index = static_cast<std::size_t>(lhs);
     898        1643 :     const auto r_index = static_cast<std::size_t>(rhs);
     899        1643 :     return l_index < order.size() and r_index < order.size() and order[l_index] < order[r_index];
     900             : }
     901             : }
     902             : }
     903             : 
     904             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/conversions/from_json.hpp>
     905             : 
     906             : 
     907             : #include <algorithm> // transform
     908             : #include <array> // array
     909             : #include <ciso646> // and, not
     910             : #include <forward_list> // forward_list
     911             : #include <iterator> // inserter, front_inserter, end
     912             : #include <map> // map
     913             : #include <string> // string
     914             : #include <tuple> // tuple, make_tuple
     915             : #include <type_traits> // is_arithmetic, is_same, is_enum, underlying_type, is_convertible
     916             : #include <utility> // pair, declval
     917             : #include <valarray> // valarray
     918             : 
     919             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/exceptions.hpp>
     920             : 
     921             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_scope.hpp>
     922             : 
     923             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/meta.hpp>
     924             : 
     925             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/value_t.hpp>
     926             : 
     927             : 
     928             : namespace nlohmann
     929             : {
     930             : namespace detail
     931             : {
     932             : // overloads for basic_json template parameters
     933             : template<typename BasicJsonType, typename ArithmeticType,
     934             :          enable_if_t<std::is_arithmetic<ArithmeticType>::value and
     935             :                      not std::is_same<ArithmeticType, typename BasicJsonType::boolean_t>::value,
     936             :                      int> = 0>
     937         227 : void get_arithmetic_value(const BasicJsonType& j, ArithmeticType& val)
     938             : {
     939         227 :     switch (static_cast<value_t>(j))
     940             :     {
     941          34 :         case value_t::number_unsigned:

    1552             : struct to_json_fn

    1560             :     }

    1566             :                       "could not find to_json() method in T's namespace");

    1572             :                       "forcing MSVC stacktrace to show which T we're talking about.");

    1574             :     }

    1610             : namespace nlohmann

    1612             : namespace detail
    1613             : {
    1614             : /// the supported input formats
    1615             : enum class input_format_t { json, cbor, msgpack, ubjson };
    1616             : 
    1617             : ////////////////////
    1618             : // input adapters //
    1619             : ////////////////////
    1620             : 
    1621             : /*!
    1622             : @brief abstract input adapter interface
    1623             : 
    1624             : Produces a stream of std::char_traits<char>::int_type characters from a
    1625             : std::istream, a buffer, or some other input type. Accepts the return of
    1626             : exactly one non-EOF character for future input. The int_type characters
    1627             : returned consist of all valid char values as positive values (typically
    1628             : unsigned char), plus an EOF value outside that range, specified by the value
    1629             : of the function std::char_traits<char>::eof(). This value is typically -1, but
    1630             : could be any arbitrary value which is not a valid char value.
    1631             : */
    1632    10930994 : struct input_adapter_protocol
    1633             : {
    1634             :     /// get a character [0,255] or std::char_traits<char>::eof().
    1635             :     virtual std::char_traits<char>::int_type get_character() = 0;
    1636    10930994 :     virtual ~input_adapter_protocol() = default;
    1637             : };
    1638             : 
    1639             : /// a type to simplify interfaces
    1640             : using input_adapter_t = std::shared_ptr<input_adapter_protocol>;
    1641             : 
    1642             : /*!
    1643             : Input adapter for a (caching) istream. Ignores a UFT Byte Order Mark at
    1644             : beginning of input. Does not support changing the underlying std::streambuf
    1645             : in mid-input. Maintains underlying std::istream and std::streambuf to support
    1646             : subsequent use of standard std::istream operations to process any input
    1647             : characters following those used in parsing the JSON input.  Clears the
    1648             : std::istream flags; any input errors (e.g., EOF) will be detected by the first
    1649             : subsequent call for input from the std::istream.
    1650             : */
    1651             : class input_stream_adapter : public input_adapter_protocol
    1652             : {
    1653             :   public:
    1654         727 :     ~input_stream_adapter() override
    1655        1454 :     {
    1656             :         // clear stream flags; we use underlying streambuf I/O, do not
    1657             :         // maintain ifstream flags
    1658         727 :         is.clear();
    1659         727 :     }
    1660             : 
    1661         727 :     explicit input_stream_adapter(std::istream& i)
    1662         727 :         : is(i), sb(*i.rdbuf())
    1663         727 :     {}
    1664             : 
    1665             :     // delete because of pointer members
    1666             :     input_stream_adapter(const input_stream_adapter&) = delete;
    1667             :     input_stream_adapter& operator=(input_stream_adapter&) = delete;
    1668             : 
    1669             :     // std::istream/std::streambuf use std::char_traits<char>::to_int_type, to
    1670             :     // ensure that std::char_traits<char>::eof() and the character 0xFF do not
    1671             :     // end up as the same value, eg. 0xFFFFFFFF.
    1672   396335662 :     std::char_traits<char>::int_type get_character() override
    1673             :     {
    1674   396335662 :         return sb.sbumpc();
    1675             :     }
    1676             : 
    1677             :   private:
    1678             :     /// the associated input stream
    1679             :     std::istream& is;
    1680             :     std::streambuf& sb;
    1681             : };
    1682             : 
    1683             : /// input adapter for buffer input
    1684    10930261 : class input_buffer_adapter : public input_adapter_protocol
    1685             : {
    1686             :   public:
    1687    10930261 :     input_buffer_adapter(const char* b, const std::size_t l)
    1688    10930261 :         : cursor(b), limit(b + l)
    1689    10930261 :     {}
    1690             : 
    1691             :     // delete because of pointer members
    1692             :     input_buffer_adapter(const input_buffer_adapter&) = delete;
    1693             :     input_buffer_adapter& operator=(input_buffer_adapter&) = delete;
    1694             : 
    1695   211479833 :     std::char_traits<char>::int_type get_character() noexcept override
    1696             :     {
    1697   211479833 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(cursor < limit))
    1698             :         {
    1699   208300551 :             return std::char_traits<char>::to_int_type(*(cursor++));
    1700             :         }
    1701             : 
    1702     3179282 :         return std::char_traits<char>::eof();
    1703             :     }
    1704             : 
    1705             :   private:
    1706             :     /// pointer to the current character
    1707             :     const char* cursor;
    1708             :     /// pointer past the last character
    1709             :     const char* const limit;
    1710             : };
    1711             : 
    1712             : template<typename WideStringType>
    1713           6 : class wide_string_input_adapter : public input_adapter_protocol
    1714             : {
    1715             :   public:
    1716           6 :     wide_string_input_adapter(const WideStringType& w) : str(w) {}
    1717             : 
    1718          85 :     std::char_traits<char>::int_type get_character() noexcept override
    1719             :     {
    1720             :         // check if buffer needs to be filled
    1721          85 :         if (utf8_bytes_index == utf8_bytes_filled)
    1722             :         {
    1723             :             if (sizeof(typename WideStringType::value_type) == 2)
    1724             :             {
    1725          18 :                 fill_buffer_utf16();
    1726             :             }
    1727             :             else
    1728             :             {
    1729          36 :                 fill_buffer_utf32();
    1730             :             }
    1731             : 
    1732          54 :             assert(utf8_bytes_filled > 0);
    1733          54 :             assert(utf8_bytes_index == 0);
    1734             :         }
    1735             : 
    1736             :         // use buffer
    1737          85 :         assert(utf8_bytes_filled > 0);
    1738          85 :         assert(utf8_bytes_index < utf8_bytes_filled);
    1739          85 :         return utf8_bytes[utf8_bytes_index++];
    1740             :     }
    1741             : 
    1742             :   private:
    1743          18 :     void fill_buffer_utf16()
    1744             :     {
    1745          18 :         utf8_bytes_index = 0;
    1746             : 
    1747          18 :         if (current_wchar == str.size())
    1748             :         {
    1749           1 :             utf8_bytes[0] = std::char_traits<char>::eof();
    1750           1 :             utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1751             :         }
    1752             :         else
    1753             :         {
    1754             :             // get the current character
    1755          17 :             const int wc = static_cast<int>(str[current_wchar++]);
    1756             : 
    1757             :             // UTF-16 to UTF-8 encoding
    1758          17 :             if (wc < 0x80)
    1759             :             {
    1760          11 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = wc;
    1761          11 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1762             :             }
    1763           6 :             else if (wc <= 0x7FF)
    1764             :             {
    1765           2 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = 0xC0 | ((wc >> 6));
    1766           2 :                 utf8_bytes[1] = 0x80 | (wc & 0x3F);
    1767           2 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 2;
    1768             :             }
    1769           4 :             else if (0xD800 > wc or wc >= 0xE000)
    1770             :             {
    1771           1 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = 0xE0 | ((wc >> 12));
    1772           1 :                 utf8_bytes[1] = 0x80 | ((wc >> 6) & 0x3F);
    1773           1 :                 utf8_bytes[2] = 0x80 | (wc & 0x3F);
    1774           1 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 3;
    1775             :             }
    1776             :             else
    1777             :             {
    1778           3 :                 if (current_wchar < str.size())
    1779             :                 {
    1780           2 :                     const int wc2 = static_cast<int>(str[current_wchar++]);
    1781           2 :                     const int charcode = 0x10000 + (((wc & 0x3FF) << 10) | (wc2 & 0x3FF));
    1782           2 :                     utf8_bytes[0] = 0xf0 | (charcode >> 18);
    1783           2 :                     utf8_bytes[1] = 0x80 | ((charcode >> 12) & 0x3F);
    1784           2 :                     utf8_bytes[2] = 0x80 | ((charcode >> 6) & 0x3F);
    1785           2 :                     utf8_bytes[3] = 0x80 | (charcode & 0x3F);
    1786           2 :                     utf8_bytes_filled = 4;
    1787             :                 }
    1788             :                 else
    1789             :                 {
    1790             :                     // unknown character
    1791           1 :                     ++current_wchar;
    1792           1 :                     utf8_bytes[0] = wc;
    1793           1 :                     utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1794             :                 }
    1795             :             }
    1796             :         }
    1797          18 :     }
    1798             : 
    1799          36 :     void fill_buffer_utf32()

    1801          36 :         utf8_bytes_index = 0;
    1802             : 
    1803          36 :         if (current_wchar == str.size())
    1804             :         {
    1805           2 :             utf8_bytes[0] = std::char_traits<char>::eof();
    1806           2 :             utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1807             :         }
    1808             :         else
    1809             :         {
    1810             :             // get the current character
    1811          34 :             const int wc = static_cast<int>(str[current_wchar++]);

    1813             :             // UTF-32 to UTF-8 encoding
    1814          34 :             if (wc < 0x80)
    1815             :             {
    1816          22 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = wc;
    1817          22 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1818             :             }
    1819          12 :             else if (wc <= 0x7FF)
    1820             :             {
    1821           4 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = 0xC0 | ((wc >> 6) & 0x1F);
    1822           4 :                 utf8_bytes[1] = 0x80 | (wc & 0x3F);
    1823           4 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 2;
    1824             :             }
    1825           8 :             else if (wc <= 0xFFFF)
    1826             :             {

    1829           3 :                 utf8_bytes[2] = 0x80 | (wc & 0x3F);
    1830           3 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 3;
    1831             :             }

    1836           4 :                 utf8_bytes[2] = 0x80 | ((wc >> 6) & 0x3F);
    1837           4 :                 utf8_bytes[3] = 0x80 | (wc & 0x3F);
    1838           4 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 4;
    1839             :             }
    1840             :             else
    1841             :             {

    1843           1 :                 utf8_bytes[0] = wc;
    1844           1 :                 utf8_bytes_filled = 1;
    1845             :             }
    1846             :         }

    1849             :   private:

    1851             :     const WideStringType& str;
    1852             : 
    1853             :     /// index of the current wchar in str
    1854             :     std::size_t current_wchar = 0;
    1855             : 
    1856             :     /// a buffer for UTF-8 bytes
    1857             :     std::array<std::char_traits<char>::int_type, 4> utf8_bytes = {{0, 0, 0, 0}};
    1858             :

    1860             :     std::size_t utf8_bytes_index = 0;
    1861             :     /// number of valid bytes in the utf8_codes array
    1862             :     std::size_t utf8_bytes_filled = 0;
    1863             : };

    1865    12839294 : class input_adapter

    1899             :     /// input adapter for string literal

    1901             :              typename std::enable_if<
    1902             :                  std::is_pointer<CharT>::value and
    1903             :                  std::is_integral<typename std::remove_pointer<CharT>::type>::value and
    1904             :                  sizeof(typename std::remove_pointer<CharT>::type) == 1,
    1905             :                  int>::type = 0>
    1906         175 :     input_adapter(CharT b)
    1907             :         : input_adapter(reinterpret_cast<const char*>(b),
    1908         175 :                         std::strlen(reinterpret_cast<const char*>(b))) {}
    1909             : 
    1910             :     /// input adapter for iterator range with contiguous storage
    1911             :     template<class IteratorType,
    1912             :              typename std::enable_if<
    1913             :                  std::is_same<typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category, std::random_access_iterator_tag>::value,
    1914             :                  int>::type = 0>
    1915    10929787 :     input_adapter(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
    1916    10929787 :     {
    1917             :         // assertion to check that the iterator range is indeed contiguous,
    1918             :         // see http://stackoverflow.com/a/35008842/266378 for more discussion
    1919   165843705 :         assert(std::accumulate(
    1920             :                    first, last, std::pair<bool, int>(true, 0),
    1921             :                    [&first](std::pair<bool, int> res, decltype(*first) val)
    1922             :         {
    1923             :             res.first &= (val == *(std::next(std::addressof(*first), res.second++)));
    1924             :             return res;
    1925             :         }).first);
    1926             : 
    1927             :         // assertion to check that each element is 1 byte long
    1928             :         static_assert(
    1929             :             sizeof(typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::value_type) == 1,
    1930             :             "each element in the iterator range must have the size of 1 byte");
    1931             : 
    1932    10929787 :         const auto len = static_cast<size_t>(std::distance(first, last));
    1933    10929787 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(len > 0))
    1934             :         {
    1935             :             // there is at least one element: use the address of first
    1936    10929774 :             ia = std::make_shared<input_buffer_adapter>(reinterpret_cast<const char*>(&(*first)), len);
    1937             :         }
    1938             :         else
    1939             :         {
    1940             :             // the address of first cannot be used: use nullptr
    1941          13 :             ia = std::make_shared<input_buffer_adapter>(nullptr, len);
    1942             :         }
    1943    10929787 :     }
    1944             : 
    1945             :     /// input adapter for array
    1946             :     template<class T, std::size_t N>
    1947         165 :     input_adapter(T (&array)[N])
    1948         165 :         : input_adapter(std::begin(array), std::end(array)) {}
    1949             : 
    1950             :     /// input adapter for contiguous container
    1951             :     template<class ContiguousContainer, typename
    1952             :              std::enable_if<not std::is_pointer<ContiguousContainer>::value and
    1953             :                             std::is_base_of<std::random_access_iterator_tag, typename std::iterator_traits<decltype(std::begin(std::declval<ContiguousContainer const>()))>::iterator_category>::value,
    1954             :                             int>::type = 0>
    1955    10929337 :     input_adapter(const ContiguousContainer& c)
    1956    10929337 :         : input_adapter(std::begin(c), std::end(c)) {}
    1957             : 
    1958    10930994 :     operator input_adapter_t()
    1959             :     {
    1960    10930994 :         return ia;
    1961             :     }
    1962             : 
    1963             :   private:
    1964             :     /// the actual adapter
    1965             :     input_adapter_t ia = nullptr;
    1966             : };
    1967             : }
    1968             : }
    1969             : 
    1970             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/input/lexer.hpp>

    1988             : namespace nlohmann
    1989             : {
    1990             : namespace detail
    1991             : {
    1992             : ///////////
    1993             : // lexer //
    1994             : ///////////
    1995             : 
    1996             : /*!
    1997             : @brief lexical analysis
    1998             : 
    1999             : This class organizes the lexical analysis during JSON deserialization.
    2000             : */
    2001             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
    2002     9976828 : class lexer
    2003             : {
    2004             :     using number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
    2005             :     using number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
    2006             :     using number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
    2007             :     using string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
    2008             : 
    2009             :   public:
    2010             :     /// token types for the parser
    2011             :     enum class token_type
    2012             :     {
    2013             :         uninitialized,    ///< indicating the scanner is uninitialized
    2014             :         literal_true,     ///< the `true` literal
    2015             :         literal_false,    ///< the `false` literal
    2016             :         literal_null,     ///< the `null` literal
    2017             :         value_string,     ///< a string -- use get_string() for actual value
    2018             :         value_unsigned,   ///< an unsigned integer -- use get_number_unsigned() for actual value
    2019             :         value_integer,    ///< a signed integer -- use get_number_integer() for actual value
    2020             :         value_float,      ///< an floating point number -- use get_number_float() for actual value
    2021             :         begin_array,      ///< the character for array begin `[`
    2022             :         begin_object,     ///< the character for object begin `{`
    2023             :         end_array,        ///< the character for array end `]`
    2024             :         end_object,       ///< the character for object end `}`
    2025             :         name_separator,   ///< the name separator `:`
    2026             :         value_separator,  ///< the value separator `,`
    2027             :         parse_error,      ///< indicating a parse error
    2028             :         end_of_input,     ///< indicating the end of the input buffer
    2029             :         literal_or_value  ///< a literal or the begin of a value (only for diagnostics)
    2030             :     };
    2031             : 
    2032             :     /// return name of values of type token_type (only used for errors)
    2033         380 :     static const char* token_type_name(const token_type t) noexcept
    2034             :     {
    2035         380 :         switch (t)
    2036             :         {
    2037           1 :             case token_type::uninitialized:
    2038           1 :                 return "<uninitialized>";
    2039           2 :             case token_type::literal_true:
    2040           2 :                 return "true literal";
    2041           1 :             case token_type::literal_false:
    2042           1 :                 return "false literal";
    2043           1 :             case token_type::literal_null:
    2044           1 :                 return "null literal";
    2045          14 :             case token_type::value_string:
    2046          14 :                 return "string literal";
    2047          18 :             case lexer::token_type::value_unsigned:
    2048             :             case lexer::token_type::value_integer:
    2049             :             case lexer::token_type::value_float:
    2050          18 :                 return "number literal";
    2051           1 :             case token_type::begin_array:
    2052           1 :                 return "'['";
    2053           1 :             case token_type::begin_object:
    2054           1 :                 return "'{'";
    2055          36 :             case token_type::end_array:
    2056          36 :                 return "']'";
    2057          26 :             case token_type::end_object:
    2058          26 :                 return "'}'";
    2059          23 :             case token_type::name_separator:
    2060          23 :                 return "':'";
    2061           2 :             case token_type::value_separator:
    2062           2 :                 return "','";
    2063           1 :             case token_type::parse_error:
    2064           1 :                 return "<parse error>";
    2065         192 :             case token_type::end_of_input:
    2066         192 :                 return "end of input";
    2067          61 :             case token_type::literal_or_value:
    2068          61 :                 return "'[', '{', or a literal";
    2069             :             default: // catch non-enum values // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    2070             :                 return "unknown token"; // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    2071             :         }
    2072             :     }
    2073             : 
    2074     9976828 :     explicit lexer(detail::input_adapter_t&& adapter)
    2075    19953656 :         : ia(std::move(adapter)), decimal_point_char(get_decimal_point()) {}
    2076             :
