    2082             :     /////////////////////
    2083             :     // locales
    2084             :     /////////////////////
    2085             : 
    2086             :     /// return the locale-dependent decimal point
    2087     9976828 :     static char get_decimal_point() noexcept
    2088             :     {
    2089     9976828 :         const auto loc = localeconv();
    2090     9976828 :         assert(loc != nullptr);
    2091     9976828 :         return (loc->decimal_point == nullptr) ? '.' : *(loc->decimal_point);
    2092             :     }
    2093             : 
    2094             :     /////////////////////
    2095             :     // scan functions
    2096             :     /////////////////////
    2097             : 
    2098             :     /*!
    2099             :     @brief get codepoint from 4 hex characters following `\u`
    2100             : 
    2101             :     For input "\u c1 c2 c3 c4" the codepoint is:
    2102             :       (c1 * 0x1000) + (c2 * 0x0100) + (c3 * 0x0010) + c4
    2103             :     = (c1 << 12) + (c2 << 8) + (c3 << 4) + (c4 << 0)
    2104             : 
    2105             :     Furthermore, the possible characters '0'..'9', 'A'..'F', and 'a'..'f'
    2106             :     must be converted to the integers 0x0..0x9, 0xA..0xF, 0xA..0xF, resp. The
    2107             :     conversion is done by subtracting the offset (0x30, 0x37, and 0x57)
    2108             :     between the ASCII value of the character and the desired integer value.
    2109             : 
    2110             :     @return codepoint (0x0000..0xFFFF) or -1 in case of an error (e.g. EOF or
    2111             :             non-hex character)
    2112             :     */
    2113     4325190 :     int get_codepoint()
    2114             :     {
    2115             :         // this function only makes sense after reading `\u`
    2116     4325190 :         assert(current == 'u');
    2117     4325190 :         int codepoint = 0;
    2118             : 
    2119     4325190 :         const auto factors = { 12, 8, 4, 0 };
    2120    21623701 :         for (const auto factor : factors)
    2121             :         {
    2122    17299408 :             get();
    2123             : 
    2124    17299408 :             if (current >= '0' and current <= '9')
    2125             :             {
    2126     6624803 :                 codepoint += ((current - 0x30) << factor);
    2127             :             }
    2128    10674605 :             else if (current >= 'A' and current <= 'F')
    2129             :             {
    2130         331 :                 codepoint += ((current - 0x37) << factor);
    2131             :             }
    2132    10674274 :             else if (current >= 'a' and current <= 'f')
    2133             :             {
    2134    10673377 :                 codepoint += ((current - 0x57) << factor);
    2135             :             }
    2136             :             else
    2137             :             {
    2138         897 :                 return -1;
    2139             :             }
    2140             :         }
    2141             : 
    2142     4324293 :         assert(0x0000 <= codepoint and codepoint <= 0xFFFF);
    2143     4324293 :         return codepoint;
    2144             :     }
    2145             : 
    2146             :     /*!
    2147             :     @brief check if the next byte(s) are inside a given range
    2148             : 
    2149             :     Adds the current byte and, for each passed range, reads a new byte and
    2150             :     checks if it is inside the range. If a violation was detected, set up an
    2151             :     error message and return false. Otherwise, return true.
    2152             : 
    2153             :     @param[in] ranges  list of integers; interpreted as list of pairs of
    2154             :                        inclusive lower and upper bound, respectively
    2155             : 
    2156             :     @pre The passed list @a ranges must have 2, 4, or 6 elements; that is,
    2157             :          1, 2, or 3 pairs. This precondition is enforced by an assertion.
    2158             : 
    2159             :     @return true if and only if no range violation was detected
    2160             :     */
    2161    15632317 :     bool next_byte_in_range(std::initializer_list<int> ranges)
    2162             :     {
    2163    15632317 :         assert(ranges.size() == 2 or ranges.size() == 4 or ranges.size() == 6);
    2164    15632317 :         add(current);
    2165             : 
    2166    42087636 :         for (auto range = ranges.begin(); range != ranges.end(); ++range)
    2167             :         {
    2168    34203855 :             get();
    2169    34203855 :             if (JSON_LIKELY(*range <= current and current <= *(++range)))
    2170             :             {
    2171    26455319 :                 add(current);
    2172             :             }
    2173             :             else
    2174             :             {
    2175     7748536 :                 error_message = "invalid string: ill-formed UTF-8 byte";
    2176     7748536 :                 return false;
    2177             :             }
    2178             :         }
    2179             : 
    2180     7883781 :         return true;
    2181             :     }
    2182             : 
    2183             :     /*!
    2184             :     @brief scan a string literal
    2185             : 
    2186             :     This function scans a string according to Sect. 7 of RFC 7159. While
    2187             :     scanning, bytes are escaped and copied into buffer token_buffer. Then the
    2188             :     function returns successfully, token_buffer is *not* null-terminated (as it
    2189             :     may contain \0 bytes), and token_buffer.size() is the number of bytes in the
    2190             :     string.
    2191             : 
    2192             :     @return token_type::value_string if string could be successfully scanned,
    2193             :             token_type::parse_error otherwise
    2194             : 
    2195             :     @note In case of errors, variable error_message contains a textual
    2196             :           description.
    2197             :     */
    2198    17767781 :     token_type scan_string()
    2199             :     {
    2200             :         // reset token_buffer (ignore opening quote)
    2201    17767781 :         reset();
    2202             : 
    2203             :         // we entered the function by reading an open quote
    2204    17767781 :         assert(current == '\"');
    2205             : 
    2206    10236344 :         while (true)
    2207             :         {
    2208             :             // get next character
    2209    28004125 :             switch (get())
    2210             :             {
    2211             :                 // end of file while parsing string
    2212         102 :                 case std::char_traits<char>::eof():
    2213             :                 {
    2214         102 :                     error_message = "invalid string: missing closing quote";
    2215         102 :                     return token_type::parse_error;
    2216             :                 }
    2217             : 
    2218             :                 // closing quote
    2219    10017614 :                 case '\"':
    2220             :                 {
    2221    10017614 :                     return token_type::value_string;
    2222             :                 }
    2223             : 
    2224             :                 // escapes
    2225     2233317 :                 case '\\':
    2226             :                 {
    2227     2233317 :                     switch (get())
    2228             :                     {
    2229             :                         // quotation mark
    2230        2048 :                         case '\"':
    2231        2048 :                             add('\"');
    2232        2048 :                             break;
    2233             :                         // reverse solidus
    2234        1722 :                         case '\\':
    2235        1722 :                             add('\\');
    2236        1722 :                             break;
    2237             :                         // solidus
    2238         856 :                         case '/':
    2239         856 :                             add('/');
    2240         856 :                             break;
    2241             :                         // backspace
    2242          95 :                         case 'b':
    2243          95 :                             add('\b');
    2244          95 :                             break;
    2245             :                         // form feed
    2246         107 :                         case 'f':
    2247         107 :                             add('\f');
    2248         107 :                             break;
    2249             :                         // line feed
    2250         101 :                         case 'n':
    2251         101 :                             add('\n');
    2252         101 :                             break;
    2253             :                         // carriage return
    2254         107 :                         case 'r':
    2255         107 :                             add('\r');
    2256         107 :                             break;
    2257             :                         // tab
    2258          53 :                         case 't':
    2259          53 :                             add('\t');
    2260          53 :                             break;
    2261             : 
    2262             :                         // unicode escapes
    2263     2227988 :                         case 'u':
    2264             :                         {
    2265     2227988 :                             const int codepoint1 = get_codepoint();
    2266     2227988 :                             int codepoint = codepoint1; // start with codepoint1
    2267             : 
    2268     2227988 :                             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(codepoint1 == -1))
    2269             :                             {
    2270         896 :                                 error_message = "invalid string: '\\u' must be followed by 4 hex digits";
    2271         896 :                                 return token_type::parse_error;
    2272             :                             }
    2273             : 
    2274             :                             // check if code point is a high surrogate
    2275     2227092 :                             if (0xD800 <= codepoint1 and codepoint1 <= 0xDBFF)
    2276             :                             {
    2277             :                                 // expect next \uxxxx entry
    2278     2097210 :                                 if (JSON_LIKELY(get() == '\\' and get() == 'u'))
    2279             :                                 {
    2280     2097202 :                                     const int codepoint2 = get_codepoint();
    2281             : 
    2282     2097202 :                                     if (JSON_UNLIKELY(codepoint2 == -1))
    2283             :                                     {
    2284           1 :                                         error_message = "invalid string: '\\u' must be followed by 4 hex digits";
    2285           1 :                                         return token_type::parse_error;
    2286             :                                     }
    2287             : 
    2288             :                                     // check if codepoint2 is a low surrogate
    2289     2097201 :                                     if (JSON_LIKELY(0xDC00 <= codepoint2 and codepoint2 <= 0xDFFF))
    2290             :                                     {
    2291             :                                         // overwrite codepoint
    2292     2097181 :                                         codepoint =
    2293             :                                             // high surrogate occupies the most significant 22 bits
    2294     2097181 :                                             (codepoint1 << 10)
    2295             :                                             // low surrogate occupies the least significant 15 bits
    2296     2097181 :                                             + codepoint2
    2297             :                                             // there is still the 0xD800, 0xDC00 and 0x10000 noise
    2298             :                                             // in the result so we have to subtract with:
    2299             :                                             // (0xD800 << 10) + DC00 - 0x10000 = 0x35FDC00
    2300             :                                             - 0x35FDC00;
    2301             :                                     }
    2302             :                                     else
    2303             :                                     {
    2304          20 :                                         error_message = "invalid string: surrogate U+DC00..U+DFFF must be followed by U+DC00..U+DFFF";

    2306             :                                     }
    2307             :                                 }
    2308             :                                 else
    2309             :                                 {
    2310           8 :                                     error_message = "invalid string: surrogate U+DC00..U+DFFF must be followed by U+DC00..U+DFFF";
    2311           8 :                                     return token_type::parse_error;
    2312     2097181 :                                 }
    2313             :                             }
    2314             :                             else
    2315             :                             {
    2316      129882 :                                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(0xDC00 <= codepoint1 and codepoint1 <= 0xDFFF))
    2317             :                                 {
    2318           2 :                                     error_message = "invalid string: surrogate U+DC00..U+DFFF must follow U+D800..U+DBFF";
    2319           2 :                                     return token_type::parse_error;
    2320             :                                 }
    2321             :                             }
    2322             : 
    2323             :                             // result of the above calculation yields a proper codepoint
    2324     2227061 :                             assert(0x00 <= codepoint and codepoint <= 0x10FFFF);
    2325             : 
    2326             :                             // translate codepoint into bytes
    2327     2227061 :                             if (codepoint < 0x80)
    2328             :                             {
    2329             :                                 // 1-byte characters: 0xxxxxxx (ASCII)
    2330        2439 :                                 add(codepoint);

    2332     2224622 :                             else if (codepoint <= 0x7FF)

    2334             :                                 // 2-byte characters: 110xxxxx 10xxxxxx

    2340             :                                 // 3-byte characters: 1110xxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx

    2345             :                             else
    2346             :                             {
    2347             :                                 // 4-byte characters: 11110xxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx 10xxxxxx

    2351     2097181 :                                 add(0x80 | (codepoint & 0x3F));

    2500      120413 :                     add(current);

    2502             :                 }
    2503             : 
    2504             :                 // U+0080..U+07FF: bytes C2..DF 80..BF
    2505       22181 :                 case 0xC2:

    2540       16382 :                     break;
    2541             :                 }
    2542             :

    2555      837006 :                 case 0xE1:

    2570      837006 :                     if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not (next_byte_in_range({0x80, 0xBF, 0x80, 0xBF}))))

    2613             :                     {

    2620         119 :                 default:

    2629           2 :     static void strtof(float& f, const char* str, char** endptr) noexcept

    2635             :     {
    2636     3001796 :         f = std::strtod(str, endptr);
    2637     3001796 :     }
    2638             : 
    2639             :     static void strtof(long double& f, const char* str, char** endptr) noexcept
    2640             :     {
    2641             :         f = std::strtold(str, endptr);
    2642             :     }
    2643             : 
    2644             :     /*!
    2645             :     @brief scan a number literal
    2646             : 
    2647             :     This function scans a string according to Sect. 6 of RFC 7159.
    2648             : 
    2649             :     The function is realized with a deterministic finite state machine derived
    2650             :     from the grammar described in RFC 7159. Starting in state "init", the
    2651             :     input is read and used to determined the next state. Only state "done"
    2652             :     accepts the number. State "error" is a trap state to model errors. In the
    2653             :     table below, "anything" means any character but the ones listed before.
    2654             : 
    2655             :     state    | 0        | 1-9      | e E      | +       | -       | .        | anything
    2656             :     ---------|----------|----------|----------|---------|---------|----------|-----------
    2657             :     init     | zero     | any1     | [error]  | [error] | minus   | [error]  | [error]
    2658             :     minus    | zero     | any1     | [error]  | [error] | [error] | [error]  | [error]
    2659             :     zero     | done     | done     | exponent | done    | done    | decimal1 | done
    2660             :     any1     | any1     | any1     | exponent | done    | done    | decimal1 | done
    2661             :     decimal1 | decimal2 | [error]  | [error]  | [error] | [error] | [error]  | [error]
    2662             :     decimal2 | decimal2 | decimal2 | exponent | done    | done    | done     | done
    2663             :     exponent | any2     | any2     | [error]  | sign    | sign    | [error]  | [error]
    2664             :     sign     | any2     | any2     | [error]  | [error] | [error] | [error]  | [error]
    2665             :     any2     | any2     | any2     | done     | done    | done    | done     | done
    2666             : 
    2667             :     The state machine is realized with one label per state (prefixed with
    2668             :     "scan_number_") and `goto` statements between them. The state machine
    2669             :     contains cycles, but any cycle can be left when EOF is read. Therefore,
    2670             :     the function is guaranteed to terminate.
    2671             : 
    2672             :     During scanning, the read bytes are stored in token_buffer. This string is
    2673             :     then converted to a signed integer, an unsigned integer, or a
    2674             :     floating-point number.
    2675             : 
    2676             :     @return token_type::value_unsigned, token_type::value_integer, or
    2677             :             token_type::value_float if number could be successfully scanned,
    2678             :             token_type::parse_error otherwise
    2679             : 
    2680             :     @note The scanner is independent of the current locale. Internally, the
    2681             :           locale's decimal point is used instead of `.` to work with the
    2682             :           locale-dependent converters.
    2683             :     */
    2684     9004106 :     token_type scan_number()
    2685             :     {
    2686             :         // reset token_buffer to store the number's bytes
    2687     9004106 :         reset();
    2688             : 
    2689             :         // the type of the parsed number; initially set to unsigned; will be
    2690             :         // changed if minus sign, decimal point or exponent is read
    2691     9004106 :         token_type number_type = token_type::value_unsigned;
    2692             : 
    2693             :         // state (init): we just found out we need to scan a number
    2694     9004106 :         switch (current)
    2695             :         {
    2696     3001923 :             case '-':
    2697             :             {
    2698     3001923 :                 add(current);
    2699     3001923 :                 goto scan_number_minus;
    2700             :             }
    2701             : 
    2702          95 :             case '0':
    2703             :             {
    2704          95 :                 add(current);
    2705          95 :                 goto scan_number_zero;
    2706             :             }
    2707             : 
    2708     6002088 :             case '1':
    2709             :             case '2':
    2710             :             case '3':
    2711             :             case '4':
    2712             :             case '5':
    2713             :             case '6':
    2714             :             case '7':
    2715             :             case '8':
    2716             :             case '9':
    2717             :             {
    2718     6002088 :                 add(current);
    2719     6002088 :                 goto scan_number_any1;
    2720             :             }
    2721             : 
    2722             :             default: // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    2723             :             {
    2724             :                 // all other characters are rejected outside scan_number()
    2725             :                 assert(false); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    2726             :             }
    2727             :         }
    2728             : 
    2729     3001923 : scan_number_minus:
    2730             :         // state: we just parsed a leading minus sign
    2731     3001923 :         number_type = token_type::value_integer;
    2732     3001923 :         switch (get())
    2733             :         {
    2734         131 :             case '0':
    2735             :             {
    2736         131 :                 add(current);
    2737         131 :                 goto scan_number_zero;
    2738             :             }
    2739             : 
    2740     3001757 :             case '1':
    2741             :             case '2':
    2742             :             case '3':
    2743             :             case '4':
    2744             :             case '5':
    2745             :             case '6':
    2746             :             case '7':
    2747             :             case '8':
    2748             :             case '9':
    2749             :             {
    2750     3001757 :                 add(current);
    2751     3001757 :                 goto scan_number_any1;
    2752             :             }
    2753             : 
    2754          35 :             default:
    2755             :             {
    2756          35 :                 error_message = "invalid number; expected digit after '-'";
    2757          35 :                 return token_type::parse_error;
    2758             :             }
    2759             :         }
    2760             : 
    2761         226 : scan_number_zero:
    2762             :         // state: we just parse a zero (maybe with a leading minus sign)
    2763         226 :         switch (get())
    2764             :         {
    2765          90 :             case '.':
    2766             :             {
    2767          90 :                 add(decimal_point_char);
    2768          90 :                 goto scan_number_decimal1;
    2769             :             }
    2770             : 
    2771          74 :             case 'e':
    2772             :             case 'E':
    2773             :             {
    2774          74 :                 add(current);
    2775          74 :                 goto scan_number_exponent;
    2776             :             }
    2777             : 
    2778          62 :             default:
    2779          62 :                 goto scan_number_done;
    2780             :         }
    2781             : 
    2782     9003845 : scan_number_any1:
    2783             :         // state: we just parsed a number 0-9 (maybe with a leading minus sign)
    2784   138529112 :         switch (get())
    2785             :         {
    2786   129525267 :             case '0':
    2787             :             case '1':
    2788             :             case '2':
    2789             :             case '3':
    2790             :             case '4':
    2791             :             case '5':
    2792             :             case '6':
    2793             :             case '7':
    2794             :             case '8':
    2795             :             case '9':
    2796             :             {
    2797   129525267 :                 add(current);
    2798   129525267 :                 goto scan_number_any1;
    2799             :             }
    2800             : 
    2801     3001410 :             case '.':
    2802             :             {
    2803     3001410 :                 add(decimal_point_char);
    2804     3001410 :                 goto scan_number_decimal1;
    2805             :             }
    2806             : 
    2807         322 :             case 'e':
    2808             :             case 'E':
    2809             :             {
    2810         322 :                 add(current);
    2811         322 :                 goto scan_number_exponent;
    2812             :             }
    2813             : 
    2814     6002113 :             default:
    2815     6002113 :                 goto scan_number_done;
    2816             :         }
    2817             : 
    2818     3001500 : scan_number_decimal1:
    2819             :         // state: we just parsed a decimal point
    2820     3001500 :         number_type = token_type::value_float;
    2821     3001500 :         switch (get())
    2822             :         {
    2823     3001470 :             case '0':
    2824             :             case '1':
    2825             :             case '2':
    2826             :             case '3':
    2827             :             case '4':
    2828             :             case '5':
    2829             :             case '6':
    2830             :             case '7':
    2831             :             case '8':
    2832             :             case '9':
    2833             :             {
    2834     3001470 :                 add(current);
    2835     3001470 :                 goto scan_number_decimal2;
    2836             :             }
    2837             : 
    2838          30 :             default:
    2839             :             {
    2840          30 :                 error_message = "invalid number; expected digit after '.'";
    2841          30 :                 return token_type::parse_error;
    2842             :             }
    2843             :         }
    2844             : 
    2845    24862883 : scan_number_decimal2:
    2846             :         // we just parsed at least one number after a decimal point
    2847    24862883 :         switch (get())
    2848             :         {
    2849    21861413 :             case '0':
    2850             :             case '1':
    2851             :             case '2':
    2852             :             case '3':
    2853             :             case '4':
    2854             :             case '5':
    2855             :             case '6':
    2856             :             case '7':
    2857             :             case '8':
    2858             :             case '9':
    2859             :             {
    2860    21861413 :                 add(current);
    2861    21861413 :                 goto scan_number_decimal2;
    2862             :             }
    2863             : 
    2864        1327 :             case 'e':
    2865             :             case 'E':
    2866             :             {
    2867        1327 :                 add(current);
    2868        1327 :                 goto scan_number_exponent;
    2869             :             }
    2870             : 
    2871     3000143 :             default:
    2872     3000143 :                 goto scan_number_done;
    2873             :         }
    2874             : 
    2875        1723 : scan_number_exponent:
    2876             :         // we just parsed an exponent
    2877        1723 :         number_type = token_type::value_float;
    2878        1723 :         switch (get())
    2879             :         {
    2880         837 :             case '+':
    2881             :             case '-':
    2882             :             {
    2883         837 :                 add(current);
    2884         837 :                 goto scan_number_sign;
    2885             :             }
    2886             : 
    2887         832 :             case '0':
    2888             :             case '1':
    2889             :             case '2':
    2890             :             case '3':
    2891             :             case '4':
    2892             :             case '5':
    2893             :             case '6':
    2894             :             case '7':
    2895             :             case '8':
    2896             :             case '9':
    2897             :             {
    2898         832 :                 add(current);
    2899         832 :                 goto scan_number_any2;
    2900             :             }
    2901             : 
    2902          54 :             default:
    2903             :             {
    2904          54 :                 error_message =
    2905             :                     "invalid number; expected '+', '-', or digit after exponent";
    2906          54 :                 return token_type::parse_error;
    2907             :             }
    2908             :         }
    2909             : 
    2910         837 : scan_number_sign:
    2911             :         // we just parsed an exponent sign
    2912         837 :         switch (get())
    2913             :         {
    2914         819 :             case '0':
    2915             :             case '1':
    2916             :             case '2':
    2917             :             case '3':
    2918             :             case '4':
    2919             :             case '5':
    2920             :             case '6':
    2921             :             case '7':
    2922             :             case '8':
    2923             :             case '9':
    2924             :             {
    2925         819 :                 add(current);
    2926         819 :                 goto scan_number_any2;
    2927             :             }
    2928             : 
    2929          18 :             default:
    2930             :             {
    2931          18 :                 error_message = "invalid number; expected digit after exponent sign";
    2932          18 :                 return token_type::parse_error;
    2933             :             }
    2934             :         }
    2935             : 
    2936        1651 : scan_number_any2:
    2937             :         // we just parsed a number after the exponent or exponent sign
    2938        3042 :         switch (get())
    2939             :         {
    2940        1391 :             case '0':
    2941             :             case '1':
    2942             :             case '2':
    2943             :             case '3':
    2944             :             case '4':
    2945             :             case '5':
    2946             :             case '6':
    2947             :             case '7':
    2948             :             case '8':
    2949             :             case '9':
    2950             :             {
    2951        1391 :                 add(current);
    2952        1391 :                 goto scan_number_any2;
    2953             :             }
    2954             : 
    2955        1651 :             default:
    2956        1651 :                 goto scan_number_done;
    2957             :         }
    2958             : 
    2959     9003969 : scan_number_done:
    2960             :         // unget the character after the number (we only read it to know that
    2961             :         // we are done scanning a number)
    2962     9003969 :         unget();
    2963             : 
    2964     9003969 :         char* endptr = nullptr;
    2965     9003969 :         errno = 0;
    2966             : 
    2967             :         // try to parse integers first and fall back to floats
    2968     9003969 :         if (number_type == token_type::value_unsigned)
    2969             :         {
    2970     4502375 :             const auto x = std::strtoull(token_buffer.data(), &endptr, 10);
    2971             : 
    2972             :             // we checked the number format before
    2973     4502375 :             assert(endptr == token_buffer.data() + token_buffer.size());
    2974             : 
    2975     4502375 :             if (errno == 0)
    2976             :             {
    2977     4502374 :                 value_unsigned = static_cast<number_unsigned_t>(x);
    2978     4502374 :                 if (value_unsigned == x)
    2979             :                 {
    2980     4502373 :                     return token_type::value_unsigned;
    2981             :                 }
    2982             :             }
    2983             :         }
    2984     4501594 :         else if (number_type == token_type::value_integer)
    2985             :         {
    2986     1499800 :             const auto x = std::strtoll(token_buffer.data(), &endptr, 10);
    2987             : 
    2988             :             // we checked the number format before
    2989     1499800 :             assert(endptr == token_buffer.data() + token_buffer.size());
    2990             : 
    2991     1499800 :             if (errno == 0)
    2992             :             {
    2993     1499799 :                 value_integer = static_cast<number_integer_t>(x);
    2994     1499799 :                 if (value_integer == x)
    2995             :                 {
    2996     1499798 :                     return token_type::value_integer;
    2997             :                 }
    2998             :             }
    2999             :         }
    3000             : 
    3001             :         // this code is reached if we parse a floating-point number or if an
    3002             :         // integer conversion above failed
    3003     3001798 :         strtof(value_float, token_buffer.data(), &endptr);
    3004             : 
    3005             :         // we checked the number format before
    3006     3001798 :         assert(endptr == token_buffer.data() + token_buffer.size());
    3007             : 
    3008     3001798 :         return token_type::value_float;
    3009             :     }

    3011             :     /*!

    3017             :                             token_type return_type)

    3035             :     /// reset token_buffer; current character is beginning of token
    3036    26771887 :     void reset() noexcept
    3037             :     {
    3038    26771887 :         token_buffer.clear();
    3039    26771887 :         token_string.clear();
    3040    26771887 :         token_string.push_back(std::char_traits<char>::to_char_type(current));
    3041    26771887 :     }
    3042             : 
    3043             :     /*
    3044             :     @brief get next character from the input
    3045             : 
    3046             :     This function provides the interface to the used input adapter. It does
    3047             :     not throw in case the input reached EOF, but returns a
    3048             :     `std::char_traits<char>::eof()` in that case.  Stores the scanned characters
    3049             :     for use in error messages.
    3050             : 
    3051             :     @return character read from the input
    3052             :     */
    3053   387620265 :     std::char_traits<char>::int_type get()
    3054             :     {
    3055   387620265 :         ++chars_read;
    3056   387620265 :         if (next_unget)
    3057             :         {
    3058             :             // just reset the next_unget variable and work with current
    3059    18980553 :             next_unget = false;
    3060             :         }
    3061             :         else
    3062             :         {
    3063   368639712 :             current = ia->get_character();
    3064             :         }
    3065             : 
    3066   387620265 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(current != std::char_traits<char>::eof()))
    3067             :         {
    3068   385393531 :             token_string.push_back(std::char_traits<char>::to_char_type(current));
    3069             :         }
    3070   387620265 :         return current;
    3071             :     }
    3072             : 
    3073             :     /*!
    3074             :     @brief unget current character (read it again on next get)
    3075             : 
    3076             :     We implement unget by setting variable next_unget to true. The input is not
    3077             :     changed - we just simulate ungetting by modifying chars_read and
    3078             :     token_string. The next call to get() will behave as if the unget character
    3079             :     is read again.
    3080             :     */
    3081    18980743 :     void unget()
    3082             :     {
    3083    18980743 :         next_unget = true;
    3084    18980743 :         --chars_read;
    3085    18980743 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(current != std::char_traits<char>::eof()))
    3086             :         {
    3087    18980212 :             assert(token_string.size() != 0);
    3088    18980212 :             token_string.pop_back();
    3089             :         }
    3090    18980743 :     }
    3091             : 
    3092             :     /// add a character to token_buffer
    3093   220383867 :     void add(int c)
    3094             :     {
    3095   220383867 :         token_buffer.push_back(std::char_traits<char>::to_char_type(c));
    3096   220383867 :     }

    3179             :     {
    3180     9976828 :         if (get() == 0xEF)
    3181             :         {
    3182          54 :             if (get() == 0xBB and get() == 0xBF)
    3183             :             {
    3184             :                 // we completely parsed the BOM
    3185          14 :                 return true;
    3186             :             }
    3187             :             else
    3188             :             {
    3189             :                 // after reading 0xEF, an unexpected character followed
    3190          40 :                 return false;
    3191             :             }

    3337             : /*!
    3338             : @brief SAX interface
    3339             : */
    3340             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
    3341    10929810 : struct json_sax
    3342             : {
    3343             :     /// type for (signed) integers
    3344             :     using number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
    3345             :     /// type for unsigned integers
    3346             :     using number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
    3347             :     /// type for floating-point numbers

    3349             :     /// type for strings
    3350             :     using string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
    3351             : 
    3352             :     /// constant to indicate that no size limit is given for array or object
    3353             :     static constexpr auto no_limit = std::size_t(-1);
    3354             : 
    3355             :     /*!
    3356             :     @brief a null value was read
    3357             :     @return whether parsing should proceed
    3358             :     */
    3359             :     virtual bool null() = 0;
    3360             : 
    3361             :     /*!
    3362             :     @brief a boolean value was read

    3443    10930837 :     virtual ~json_sax() = default;

    3445             : 
    3446             : 
    3447             : namespace detail
    3448             : {
    3449             : /*!
    3450             : @brief SAX implementation to create a JSON value from SAX events
    3451             : 
    3452             : This class implements the @ref json_sax interface and processes the SAX events
    3453             : to create a JSON value which makes it basically a DOM parser. The structure or
    3454             : hierarchy of the JSON value is managed by the stack `ref_stack` which contains
    3455             : a pointer to the respective array or object for each recursion depth.
    3456             : 
    3457             : After successful parsing, the value that is passed by reference to the
    3458             : constructor contains the parsed value.
    3459             : 
    3460             : @tparam BasicJsonType  the JSON type
    3461             : */
    3462             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
    3463    10929338 : class json_sax_dom_parser : public json_sax<BasicJsonType>
    3464             : {
    3465             :   public:
    3466             :     using number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
    3467             :     using number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
    3468             :     using number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
    3469             :     using string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
    3470             : 
    3471             :     /*!
    3472             :     @param[in, out] r  reference to a JSON value that is manipulated while
    3473             :                        parsing
    3474             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions_  whether parse errors yield exceptions
    3475             :     */
    3476    10929338 :     json_sax_dom_parser(BasicJsonType& r, const bool allow_exceptions_ = true)
    3477    10929338 :         : root(r), allow_exceptions(allow_exceptions_)
    3478    10929338 :     {}
    3479             : 
    3480      929034 :     bool null() override
    3481             :     {
    3482      929034 :         handle_value(nullptr);
    3483      929034 :         return true;
    3484             :     }
    3485             : 
    3486        5945 :     bool boolean(bool val) override
    3487             :     {
    3488        5945 :         handle_value(val);
    3489        5945 :         return true;
    3490             :     }
    3491             : 
    3492     4926677 :     bool number_integer(number_integer_t val) override

    3495     4926677 :         return true;
    3496             :     }
    3497             :

    3519             :

    3521             :         {

    3523             :                                             "excessive object size: " + std::to_string(len)));
    3524             :         }
    3525             : 
    3526        7500 :         return true;
    3527             :     }
    3528             :

    3534             :     }
    3535             : 
    3536        7384 :     bool end_object() override

    3538        7384 :         ref_stack.pop_back();
    3539        7384 :         return true;
    3540             :     }
    3541             : 
    3542        8987 :     bool start_array(std::size_t len) override
    3543             :     {
    3544        8987 :         ref_stack.push_back(handle_value(BasicJsonType::value_t::array));
    3545             : 
    3546        8987 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(len != json_sax<BasicJsonType>::no_limit and len > ref_stack.back()->max_size()))
    3547             :         {
    3548           2 :             JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(408,
    3549             :                                             "excessive array size: " + std::to_string(len)));
    3550             :         }

    3552        8985 :         return true;
    3553             :     }
    3554             : 
    3555        8870 :     bool end_array() override
    3556             :     {
    3557        8870 :         ref_stack.pop_back();

    3850             :   private:
    3851             :     /*!
    3852             :     @param[in] v  value to add to the JSON value we build during parsing
    3853             :     @param[in] skip_callback  whether we should skip calling the callback
    3854             :                function; this is required after start_array() and
    3855             :                start_object() SAX events, because otherwise we would call the
    3856             :                callback function with an empty array or object, respectively.

    3859             :                root.

    4024             : ////////////
    4025             : // parser //
    4026             : ////////////
    4027             : 
    4028             : /*!
    4029             : @brief syntax analysis
    4030             : 
    4031             : This class implements a recursive decent parser.
    4032             : */
    4033             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
    4034     9976671 : class parser
    4035             : {
    4036             :     using number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
    4037             :     using number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
    4038             :     using number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
    4039             :     using string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
    4040             :     using lexer_t = lexer<BasicJsonType>;
    4041             :     using token_type = typename lexer_t::token_type;
    4042             : 
    4043             :   public:
    4044             :     enum class parse_event_t : uint8_t
    4045             :     {
    4046             :         /// the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
    4047             :         object_start,
    4048             :         /// the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
    4049             :         object_end,
    4050             :         /// the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
    4051             :         array_start,
    4052             :         /// the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
    4053             :         array_end,
    4054             :         /// the parser read a key of a value in an object
    4055             :         key,
    4056             :         /// the parser finished reading a JSON value
    4057             :         value
    4058             :     };
    4059             : 
    4060             :     using json_sax_t = json_sax<BasicJsonType>;
    4061             : 
    4062             :     using parser_callback_t =
    4063             :         std::function<bool(int depth, parse_event_t event, BasicJsonType& parsed)>;
    4064             : 
    4065             :     /// a parser reading from an input adapter
    4066     9976671 :     explicit parser(detail::input_adapter_t&& adapter,
    4067             :                     const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
    4068             :                     const bool allow_exceptions_ = true)
    4069     9976671 :         : callback(cb), m_lexer(std::move(adapter)), allow_exceptions(allow_exceptions_)
    4070             :     {
    4071             :         // read first token
    4072     9976671 :         get_token();
    4073     9976671 :     }
    4074             : 
    4075             :     /*!
    4076             :     @brief public parser interface
    4077             : 
    4078             :     @param[in] strict      whether to expect the last token to be EOF
    4079             :     @param[in,out] result  parsed JSON value
    4080             : 
    4081             :     @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
    4082             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
    4083             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
    4084             :     */
    4085     9975181 :     void parse(const bool strict, BasicJsonType& result)
    4086             :     {
    4087     9975181 :         if (callback)
    4088             :         {
    4089         281 :             json_sax_dom_callback_parser<BasicJsonType> sdp(result, callback, allow_exceptions);
    4090         194 :             sax_parse_internal(&sdp);
    4091         192 :             result.assert_invariant();
    4092             : 
    4093             :             // in strict mode, input must be completely read
    4094         192 :             if (strict and (get_token() != token_type::end_of_input))
    4095             :             {
    4096          52 :                 sdp.parse_error(m_lexer.get_position(),
    4097             :                                 m_lexer.get_token_string(),
    4098             :                                 parse_error::create(101, m_lexer.get_position(), exception_message(token_type::end_of_input)));
    4099             :             }
    4100             : 
    4101             :             // in case of an error, return discarded value
    4102         192 :             if (sdp.is_errored())
    4103             :             {
    4104         107 :                 result = value_t::discarded;
    4105         107 :                 return;
    4106             :             }
    4107             : 
    4108             :             // set top-level value to null if it was discarded by the callback
    4109             :             // function
    4110          85 :             if (result.is_discarded())

    4112           3 :                 result = nullptr;
    4113             :             }
    4114             :         }

    4165             :   private:
    4166     9976671 :     bool sax_parse_internal(json_sax_t* sax)
    4167             :     {
    4168             :         // stack to remember the hieararchy of structured values we are parsing
    4169             :         // true = array; false = object

    4176    26777828 :             if (not skip_to_state_evaluation)

    4182             :                     {

    4491             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/primitive_iterator.hpp>
    4492             : 
    4493             : 
    4494             : #include <cstddef> // ptrdiff_t
    4495             : #include <limits>  // numeric_limits
    4496             : 
    4497             : namespace nlohmann
    4498             : {
    4499             : namespace detail
    4500             : {
    4501             : /*
    4502             : @brief an iterator for primitive JSON types
    4503             : 
    4504             : This class models an iterator for primitive JSON types (boolean, number,
    4505             : string). It's only purpose is to allow the iterator/const_iterator classes
    4506             : to "iterate" over primitive values. Internally, the iterator is modeled by
    4507             : a `difference_type` variable. Value begin_value (`0`) models the begin,
    4508             : end_value (`1`) models past the end.
    4509             : */
    4510      275286 : class primitive_iterator_t
    4511             : {
    4512             :   private:
    4513             :     using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
    4514             :     static constexpr difference_type begin_value = 0;
    4515             :     static constexpr difference_type end_value = begin_value + 1;
    4516             : 
    4517             :     /// iterator as signed integer type
    4518      137643 :     difference_type m_it = (std::numeric_limits<std::ptrdiff_t>::min)();
    4519             : 
    4520             :   public:
    4521           4 :     constexpr difference_type get_value() const noexcept
    4522             :     {
    4523           4 :         return m_it;
    4524             :     }
    4525             : 
    4526             :     /// set iterator to a defined beginning
    4527         680 :     void set_begin() noexcept
    4528             :     {
    4529         680 :         m_it = begin_value;
    4530         680 :     }
    4531             : 
    4532             :     /// set iterator to a defined past the end
    4533         964 :     void set_end() noexcept
    4534             :     {
    4535         964 :         m_it = end_value;
    4536         964 :     }
    4537             : 
    4538             :     /// return whether the iterator can be dereferenced
    4539         261 :     constexpr bool is_begin() const noexcept
    4540             :     {
    4541         261 :         return m_it == begin_value;
    4542             :     }
    4543             : 
    4544             :     /// return whether the iterator is at end
    4545          40 :     constexpr bool is_end() const noexcept
    4546             :     {
    4547          40 :         return m_it == end_value;
    4548             :     }
    4549             : 
    4550         794 :     friend constexpr bool operator==(primitive_iterator_t lhs, primitive_iterator_t rhs) noexcept
    4551             :     {
    4552         794 :         return lhs.m_it == rhs.m_it;
    4553             :     }
    4554             : 
    4555         681 :     friend constexpr bool operator<(primitive_iterator_t lhs, primitive_iterator_t rhs) noexcept
    4556             :     {
    4557         681 :         return lhs.m_it < rhs.m_it;
    4558             :     }
    4559             : 
    4560             :     primitive_iterator_t operator+(difference_type n) noexcept
    4561             :     {
    4562             :         auto result = *this;
    4563             :         result += n;
    4564             :         return result;
    4565             :     }
    4566             : 
    4567           8 :     friend constexpr difference_type operator-(primitive_iterator_t lhs, primitive_iterator_t rhs) noexcept
    4568             :     {
    4569           8 :         return lhs.m_it - rhs.m_it;
    4570             :     }
    4571             : 
    4572         144 :     primitive_iterator_t& operator++() noexcept
    4573             :     {
    4574         144 :         ++m_it;
    4575         144 :         return *this;
    4576             :     }
    4577             : 
    4578             :     primitive_iterator_t const operator++(int) noexcept
    4579             :     {
    4580             :         auto result = *this;
    4581             :         m_it++;
    4582             :         return result;
    4583             :     }
    4584             : 
    4585         215 :     primitive_iterator_t& operator--() noexcept
    4586             :     {
    4587         215 :         --m_it;
    4588         215 :         return *this;
    4589             :     }
    4590             : 
    4591             :     primitive_iterator_t const operator--(int) noexcept
    4592             :     {
    4593             :         auto result = *this;
    4594             :         m_it--;
    4595             :         return result;
    4596             :     }
    4597             : 
    4598          60 :     primitive_iterator_t& operator+=(difference_type n) noexcept
    4599             :     {
    4600          60 :         m_it += n;
    4601          60 :         return *this;
    4602             :     }
    4603             : 
    4604             :     primitive_iterator_t& operator-=(difference_type n) noexcept
    4605             :     {
    4606             :         m_it -= n;
    4607             :         return *this;
    4608             :     }
    4609             : };
    4610             : }
    4611             : }
    4612             : 
    4613             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/internal_iterator.hpp>
    4614             : 
    4615             : 
    4616             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/primitive_iterator.hpp>
    4617             : 
    4618             : 
    4619             : namespace nlohmann
    4620             : {
    4621             : namespace detail
    4622             : {
    4623             : /*!
    4624             : @brief an iterator value
    4625             : 
    4626             : @note This structure could easily be a union, but MSVC currently does not allow
    4627             : unions members with complex constructors, see https://github.com/nlohmann/json/pull/105.
    4628             : */
    4629      135993 : template<typename BasicJsonType> struct internal_iterator
    4630             : {
    4631             :     /// iterator for JSON objects
    4632             :     typename BasicJsonType::object_t::iterator object_iterator {};
    4633             :     /// iterator for JSON arrays
    4634             :     typename BasicJsonType::array_t::iterator array_iterator {};
    4635             :     /// generic iterator for all other types
    4636             :     primitive_iterator_t primitive_iterator {};
    4637             : };
    4638             : }
    4639             : }
    4640             : 
    4641             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/iter_impl.hpp>
    4642             : 
    4643             : 
    4644             : #include <ciso646> // not
    4645             : #include <iterator> // iterator, random_access_iterator_tag, bidirectional_iterator_tag, advance, next
    4646             : #include <type_traits> // conditional, is_const, remove_const
    4647             : 
    4648             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/exceptions.hpp>
    4649             : 
    4650             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/internal_iterator.hpp>
    4651             : 
    4652             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/iterators/primitive_iterator.hpp>
    4653             : 
    4654             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/macro_scope.hpp>
    4655             : 
    4656             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/meta.hpp>
    4657             : 
    4658             : // #include <nlohmann/detail/value_t.hpp>
    4659             : 
    4660             : 
    4661             : namespace nlohmann
    4662             : {
    4663             : namespace detail
    4664             : {
    4665             : // forward declare, to be able to friend it later on
    4666             : template<typename IteratorType> class iteration_proxy;
    4667             : 
    4668             : /*!
    4669             : @brief a template for a bidirectional iterator for the @ref basic_json class
    4670             : 
    4671             : This class implements a both iterators (iterator and const_iterator) for the
    4672             : @ref basic_json class.
    4673             : 
    4674             : @note An iterator is called *initialized* when a pointer to a JSON value has
    4675             :       been set (e.g., by a constructor or a copy assignment). If the iterator is
    4676             :       default-constructed, it is *uninitialized* and most methods are undefined.
    4677             :       **The library uses assertions to detect calls on uninitialized iterators.**
    4678             : 
    4679             : @requirement The class satisfies the following concept requirements:
    4680             : -
    4681             : [BidirectionalIterator](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/BidirectionalIterator):
    4682             :   The iterator that can be moved can be moved in both directions (i.e.
    4683             :   incremented and decremented).
    4684             : 
    4685             : @since version 1.0.0, simplified in version 2.0.9, change to bidirectional
    4686             :        iterators in version 3.0.0 (see https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/593)
    4687             : */
    4688             : template<typename BasicJsonType>
    4689             : class iter_impl
    4690             : {
    4691             :     /// allow basic_json to access private members
    4692             :     friend iter_impl<typename std::conditional<std::is_const<BasicJsonType>::value, typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type, const BasicJsonType>::type>;
    4693             :     friend BasicJsonType;
    4694             :     friend iteration_proxy<iter_impl>;
    4695             : 
    4696             :     using object_t = typename BasicJsonType::object_t;
    4697             :     using array_t = typename BasicJsonType::array_t;
    4698             :     // make sure BasicJsonType is basic_json or const basic_json
    4699             :     static_assert(is_basic_json<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type>::value,
    4700             :                   "iter_impl only accepts (const) basic_json");
    4701             : 
    4702             :   public:
    4703             : 
    4704             :     /// The std::iterator class template (used as a base class to provide typedefs) is deprecated in C++17.
    4705             :     /// The C++ Standard has never required user-defined iterators to derive from std::iterator.
    4706             :     /// A user-defined iterator should provide publicly accessible typedefs named
    4707             :     /// iterator_category, value_type, difference_type, pointer, and reference.
    4708             :     /// Note that value_type is required to be non-const, even for constant iterators.
    4709             :     using iterator_category = std::bidirectional_iterator_tag;
    4710             : 
    4711             :     /// the type of the values when the iterator is dereferenced
    4712             :     using value_type = typename BasicJsonType::value_type;
    4713             :     /// a type to represent differences between iterators
    4714             :     using difference_type = typename BasicJsonType::difference_type;
    4715             :     /// defines a pointer to the type iterated over (value_type)
    4716             :     using pointer = typename std::conditional<std::is_const<BasicJsonType>::value,
    4717             :           typename BasicJsonType::const_pointer,
    4718             :           typename BasicJsonType::pointer>::type;
    4719             :     /// defines a reference to the type iterated over (value_type)
    4720             :     using reference =
    4721             :         typename std::conditional<std::is_const<BasicJsonType>::value,
    4722             :         typename BasicJsonType::const_reference,
    4723             :         typename BasicJsonType::reference>::type;
    4724             : 
    4725             :     /// default constructor
    4726           3 :     iter_impl() = default;
    4727             : 
    4728             :     /*!
    4729             :     @brief constructor for a given JSON instance
    4730             :     @param[in] object  pointer to a JSON object for this iterator
    4731             :     @pre object != nullptr
    4732             :     @post The iterator is initialized; i.e. `m_object != nullptr`.
    4733             :     */
    4734      135990 :     explicit iter_impl(pointer object) noexcept : m_object(object)
    4735             :     {
    4736      135990 :         assert(m_object != nullptr);
    4737             : 
    4738      135990 :         switch (m_object->m_type)
    4739             :         {
    4740      132973 :             case value_t::object:
    4741             :             {
    4742      132973 :                 m_it.object_iterator = typename object_t::iterator();
    4743      132973 :                 break;
    4744             :             }
    4745             : 
    4746        1367 :             case value_t::array:
    4747             :             {
    4748        1367 :                 m_it.array_iterator = typename array_t::iterator();
    4749        1367 :                 break;
    4750             :             }
    4751             : 
    4752        1650 :             default:
    4753             :             {
    4754        1650 :                 m_it.primitive_iterator = primitive_iterator_t();
    4755        1650 :                 break;
    4756             :             }
    4757             :         }
    4758      135990 :     }
    4759             : 
    4760             :     /*!
    4761             :     @note The conventional copy constructor and copy assignment are implicitly
    4762             :           defined. Combined with the following converting constructor and
    4763             :           assignment, they support: (1) copy from iterator to iterator, (2)
    4764             :           copy from const iterator to const iterator, and (3) conversion from
    4765             :           iterator to const iterator. However conversion from const iterator
    4766             :           to iterator is not defined.
    4767             :     */
    4768             : 
    4769             :     /*!
    4770             :     @brief converting constructor
    4771             :     @param[in] other  non-const iterator to copy from
    4772             :     @note It is not checked whether @a other is initialized.
    4773             :     */
    4774      135073 :     iter_impl(const iter_impl<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type>& other) noexcept
    4775      135073 :         : m_object(other.m_object), m_it(other.m_it) {}
    4776             : 
    4777             :     /*!
    4778             :     @brief converting assignment
    4779             :     @param[in,out] other  non-const iterator to copy from
    4780             :     @return const/non-const iterator
    4781             :     @note It is not checked whether @a other is initialized.
    4782             :     */

    4784             :     {
    4785          22 :         m_object = other.m_object;
    4786          22 :         m_it = other.m_it;
    4787          22 :         return *this;
    4788             :     }

    5388             : //////////////////////
    5389             : // reverse_iterator //
    5390             : //////////////////////
    5391             : 
    5392             : /*!
    5393             : @brief a template for a reverse iterator class
    5394             : 
    5395             : @tparam Base the base iterator type to reverse. Valid types are @ref
    5396             : iterator (to create @ref reverse_iterator) and @ref const_iterator (to
    5397             : create @ref const_reverse_iterator).
    5398             : 
    5399             : @requirement The class satisfies the following concept requirements:
    5400             : -
    5401             : [BidirectionalIterator](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/BidirectionalIterator):
    5402             :   The iterator that can be moved can be moved in both directions (i.e.
    5403             :   incremented and decremented).
    5404             : - [OutputIterator](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/OutputIterator):
    5405             :   It is possible to write to the pointed-to element (only if @a Base is
    5406             :   @ref iterator).
    5407             : 
    5408             : @since version 1.0.0
    5409             : */
    5410             : template<typename Base>
    5411          51 : class json_reverse_iterator : public std::reverse_iterator<Base>
    5412             : {
    5413             :   public:
    5414             :     using difference_type = std::ptrdiff_t;
    5415             :     /// shortcut to the reverse iterator adapter
    5416             :     using base_iterator = std::reverse_iterator<Base>;
    5417             :     /// the reference type for the pointed-to element
    5418             :     using reference = typename Base::reference;
    5419             : 
    5420             :     /// create reverse iterator from iterator
    5421         785 :     json_reverse_iterator(const typename base_iterator::iterator_type& it) noexcept
    5422         785 :         : base_iterator(it) {}
    5423             : 
    5424             :     /// create reverse iterator from base class
    5425          74 :     json_reverse_iterator(const base_iterator& it) noexcept : base_iterator(it) {}
    5426             : 
    5427             :     /// post-increment (it++)
    5428          21 :     json_reverse_iterator const operator++(int)
    5429             :     {
    5430          21 :         return static_cast<json_reverse_iterator>(base_iterator::operator++(1));
    5431             :     }
    5432             : 
    5433             :     /// pre-increment (++it)
    5434         146 :     json_reverse_iterator& operator++()
    5435             :     {
    5436         146 :         return static_cast<json_reverse_iterator&>(base_iterator::operator++());
    5437             :     }
    5438             : 
    5439             :     /// post-decrement (it--)
    5440          15 :     json_reverse_iterator const operator--(int)
    5441             :     {
    5442          15 :         return static_cast<json_reverse_iterator>(base_iterator::operator--(1));
    5443             :     }
    5444             : 
    5445             :     /// pre-decrement (--it)
    5446          15 :     json_reverse_iterator& operator--()

    5448          15 :         return static_cast<json_reverse_iterator&>(base_iterator::operator--());
    5449             :     }
    5450             :

    5725             :     /*!

    5729             :

    5731             :     */

    5733             :     {
    5734     1446906 :         return (*reinterpret_cast<char*>(&num) == 1);
    5735             :     }
    5736             : 
    5737             :   private:
    5738             :     /*!
    5739             :     @param[in] get_char  whether a new character should be retrieved from the
    5740             :                          input (true, default) or whether the last read
    5741             :                          character should be considered instead
    5742             : 
    5743             :     @return whether a valid CBOR value was passed to the SAX parser
    5744             :     */

    5746             :     {
    5747    14120337 :         switch (get_char ? get() : current)
    5748             :         {
    5749             :             // EOF

    5751          60 :                 return unexpect_eof();
    5752             :

    5853     1499972 :                         - static_cast<number_integer_t>(number));

    5998             : 
    5999         839 :             case 0xF4: // false
    6000         839 :                 return sax->boolean(false);
    6001             : 
    6002         825 :             case 0xF5: // true
    6003         825 :                 return sax->boolean(true);
    6004             : 
    6005      265981 :             case 0xF6: // null
    6006      265981 :                 return sax->null();
    6007             : 
    6008          25 :             case 0xF9: // Half-Precision Float (two-byte IEEE 754)
    6009             :             {
    6010          25 :                 const int byte1 = get();
    6011          25 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not unexpect_eof()))
    6012             :                 {
    6013           1 :                     return false;
    6014             :                 }
    6015          22 :                 const int byte2 = get();
    6016          22 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not unexpect_eof()))
    6017             :                 {
    6018           1 :                     return false;
    6019             :                 }
    6020             : 
    6021             :                 // code from RFC 7049, Appendix D, Figure 3:
    6022             :                 // As half-precision floating-point numbers were only added
    6023             :                 // to IEEE 754 in 2008, today's programming platforms often
    6024             :                 // still only have limited support for them. It is very
    6025             :                 // easy to include at least decoding support for them even
    6026             :                 // without such support. An example of a small decoder for
    6027             :                 // half-precision floating-point numbers in the C language
    6028             :                 // is shown in Fig. 3.
    6029          19 :                 const int half = (byte1 << 8) + byte2;
    6030          19 :                 const int exp = (half >> 10) & 0x1F;
    6031          19 :                 const int mant = half & 0x3FF;
    6032             :                 double val;
    6033          19 :                 if (exp == 0)
    6034             :                 {
    6035           5 :                     val = std::ldexp(mant, -24);
    6036             :                 }
    6037          14 :                 else if (exp != 31)
    6038             :                 {
    6039           9 :                     val = std::ldexp(mant + 1024, exp - 25);
    6040             :                 }
    6041             :                 else
    6042             :                 {
    6043           5 :                     val = (mant == 0) ? std::numeric_limits<double>::infinity()
    6044             :                           : std::numeric_limits<double>::quiet_NaN();
    6045             :                 }
    6046          19 :                 return sax->number_float((half & 0x8000) != 0 ? -val : val, "");
    6047             :             }
    6048             : 
    6049           9 :             case 0xFA: // Single-Precision Float (four-byte IEEE 754)
    6050             :             {
    6051             :                 float number;
    6052          11 :                 return get_number(number) and sax->number_float(static_cast<double>(number), "");
    6053             :             }
    6054             : 
    6055     3001742 :             case 0xFB: // Double-Precision Float (eight-byte IEEE 754)
    6056             :             {
    6057             :                 double number;
    6058     3001744 :                 return get_number(number) and sax->number_float(number, "");
    6059             :             }
    6060             : 
    6061         305 :             default: // anything else (0xFF is handled inside the other types)
    6062             :             {
    6063         610 :                 auto last_token = get_token_string();
    6064         511 :                 return sax->parse_error(chars_read, last_token, parse_error::create(112, chars_read, "error reading CBOR; last byte: 0x" + last_token));
    6065             :             }
    6066             :         }
    6067             :     }

    6472             :     /*
    6473             :     @brief read a number from the input
    6474             : 
    6475             :     @tparam NumberType the type of the number
    6476             :     @param[out] result  number of type @a NumberType
    6477             : 
    6478             :     @return whether conversion completed
    6479             : 
    6480             :     @note This function needs to respect the system's endianess, because
    6481             :           bytes in CBOR, MessagePack, and UBJSON are stored in network order
    6482             :           (big endian) and therefore need reordering on little endian systems.
    6483             :     */
    6484             :     template<typename NumberType>
    6485    22315108 :     bool get_number(NumberType& result)
    6486             :     {
    6487             :         // step 1: read input into array with system's byte order
    6488             :         std::array<uint8_t, sizeof(NumberType)> vec;

    6490             :         {
    6491   149331847 :             get();
    6492   149331847 :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not unexpect_eof()))
    6493             :             {
    6494          38 :                 return false;
    6495             :             }
    6496             : 
    6497             :             // reverse byte order prior to conversion if necessary
    6498   149331738 :             if (is_little_endian)
    6499             :             {
    6500   149331738 :                 vec[sizeof(NumberType) - i - 1] = static_cast<uint8_t>(current);
    6501             :             }
    6502             :             else
    6503             :             {
    6504             :                 vec[i] = static_cast<uint8_t>(current); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
    6505             :             }
    6506             :         }
    6507             : 
    6508             :         // step 2: convert array into number of type T and return
    6509    22314999 :         std::memcpy(&result, vec.data(), sizeof(NumberType));
    6510    22314999 :         return true;
    6511             :     }

    6513             :     /*!
    6514             :     @brief create a string by reading characters from the input
    6515             : 
    6516             :     @tparam NumberType the type of the number
    6517             :     @param[in] len number of characters to read
    6518             :     @param[out] string created by reading @a len bytes
    6519             : 
    6520             :     @return whether string creation completed
    6521             : 
    6522             :     @note We can not reserve @a len bytes for the result, because @a len
    6523             :           may be too large. Usually, @ref unexpect_eof() detects the end of
    6524             :           the input before we run out of string memory.
    6525             :     */

    7333             : @brief serialization to CBOR and MessagePack values

    7336      492740 : class binary_writer
    7337             : {
    7338             :   public:
    7339             :     /*!
    7340             :     @brief create a binary writer
    7341             :
