    7344      985480 :     explicit binary_writer(output_adapter_t<CharType> adapter) : oa(adapter)
    7345             :     {
    7346      492740 :         assert(oa);
    7347      492740 :     }
    7348             : 
    7349             :     /*!
    7350             :     @brief[in] j  JSON value to serialize
    7351             :     */
    7352     4516290 :     void write_cbor(const BasicJsonType& j)
    7353             :     {
    7354     4516290 :         switch (j.type())
    7355             :         {
    7356      132981 :             case value_t::null:
    7357             :             {
    7358      132981 :                 oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>(0xF6));
    7359      132981 :                 break;
    7360             :             }
    7361             : 
    7362         827 :             case value_t::boolean:
    7363             :             {
    7364         827 :                 oa->write_character(j.m_value.boolean
    7365             :                                     ? static_cast<CharType>(0xF5)
    7366             :                                     : static_cast<CharType>(0xF4));
    7367         827 :                 break;
    7368             :             }
    7369             : 
    7370      631232 :             case value_t::number_integer:
    7371             :             {
    7372      631232 :                 if (j.m_value.number_integer >= 0)
    7373             :                 {
    7374             :                     // CBOR does not differentiate between positive signed
    7375             :                     // integers and unsigned integers. Therefore, we used the
    7376             :                     // code from the value_t::number_unsigned case here.
    7377       65543 :                     if (j.m_value.number_integer <= 0x17)
    7378             :                     {
    7379          26 :                         write_number(static_cast<uint8_t>(j.m_value.number_integer));
    7380             :                     }
    7381       65517 :                     else if (j.m_value.number_integer <= (std::numeric_limits<uint8_t>::max)())
    7382             :                     {
    7383         232 :                         oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>(0x18));
    7384         232 :                         write_number(static_cast<uint8_t>(j.m_value.number_integer));
    7385             :                     }
    7386       65285 :                     else if (j.m_value.number_integer <= (std::numeric_limits<uint16_t>::max)())
    7387             :                     {
    7388       65280 :                         oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>(0x19));
    7389       65280 :                         write_number(static_cast<uint16_t>(j.m_value.number_integer));
    7390             :                     }

    7392             :                     {
    7393           3 :                         oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>(0x1A));
    7394           3 :                         write_number(static_cast<uint32_t>(j.m_value.number_integer));
    7395             :                     }
    7396             :                     else

    7400             :                     }
    7401             :                 }
    7402             :                 else

    7405             :                     // byte, and the value is converted to a positive number.

    7480             :                 {
    7481        3171 :                     oa->write_character(static_cast<CharType>(0x78));
    7482        3171 :                     write_number(static_cast<uint8_t>(N));
    7483             :                 }

    7832             :     /*!

    7974             :                         el.first.size());

    7976             :                 }
    7977             :

    7981             :                 }
    7982             : 
    7983         523 :                 break;
    7984             :             }
    7985             : 
    7986           3 :             default:
    7987           3 :                 break;
    7988             :         }
    7989     1412462 :     }
    7990             : 
    7991             :   private:
    7992             :     /*
    7993             :     @brief write a number to output input
    7994             : 
    7995             :     @param[in] n number of type @a NumberType
    7996             :     @tparam NumberType the type of the number
    7997             : 
    7998             :     @note This function needs to respect the system's endianess, because bytes
    7999             :           in CBOR, MessagePack, and UBJSON are stored in network order (big
    8000             :           endian) and therefore need reordering on little endian systems.
    8001             :     */
    8002             :     template<typename NumberType>
    8003     9978154 :     void write_number(const NumberType n)
    8004             :     {
    8005             :         // step 1: write number to array of length NumberType
    8006             :         std::array<CharType, sizeof(NumberType)> vec;
    8007     9978154 :         std::memcpy(vec.data(), &n, sizeof(NumberType));
    8008             : 
    8009             :         // step 2: write array to output (with possible reordering)
    8010     9978154 :         if (is_little_endian)
    8011             :         {
    8012             :             // reverse byte order prior to conversion if necessary
    8013     9978154 :             std::reverse(vec.begin(), vec.end());
    8014             :         }
    8015             : 
    8016     9978154 :         oa->write_characters(vec.data(), sizeof(NumberType));
    8017     9978154 :     }

    8138             : 
    8139             :     /*!
    8140             :     @brief determine the type prefix of container values
    8141             : 
    8142             :     @note This function does not need to be 100% accurate when it comes to
    8143             :           integer limits. In case a number exceeds the limits of int64_t,
    8144             :           this will be detected by a later call to function
    8145             :           write_number_with_ubjson_prefix. Therefore, we return 'L' for any
    8146             :           value that does not fit the previous limits.
    8147             :     */
    8148       66131 :     CharType ubjson_prefix(const BasicJsonType& j) const noexcept
    8149             :     {
    8150       66131 :         switch (j.type())
    8151             :         {

    8167             :                 }
    8168          13 :                 else if ((std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::min)() <= j.m_value.number_integer and j.m_value.number_integer <= (std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max)())

    8293             : namespace nlohmann
    8294             : {
    8295             : namespace detail
    8296             : {
    8297             : 
    8298             : /*!
    8299             : @brief implements the Grisu2 algorithm for binary to decimal floating-point
    8300             : conversion.
    8301             : 
    8302             : This implementation is a slightly modified version of the reference
    8303             : implementation which may be obtained from
    8304             : http://florian.loitsch.com/publications (bench.tar.gz).
    8305             : 
    8306             : The code is distributed under the MIT license, Copyright (c) 2009 Florian Loitsch.
    8307             : 
    8308             : For a detailed description of the algorithm see:
    8309             : 
    8310             : [1] Loitsch, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately with
    8311             :     Integers", Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 2010 Conference on Programming
    8312             :     Language Design and Implementation, PLDI 2010
    8313             : [2] Burger, Dybvig, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately",
    8314             :     Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 1996 Conference on Programming Language
    8315             :     Design and Implementation, PLDI 1996
    8316             : */
    8317             : namespace dtoa_impl
    8318             : {
    8319             : 
    8320             : template <typename Target, typename Source>
    8321         437 : Target reinterpret_bits(const Source source)
    8322             : {
    8323             :     static_assert(sizeof(Target) == sizeof(Source), "size mismatch");
    8324             : 
    8325             :     Target target;
    8326         437 :     std::memcpy(&target, &source, sizeof(Source));
    8327         437 :     return target;
    8328             : }
    8329             : 
    8330             : struct diyfp // f * 2^e
    8331             : {
    8332             :     static constexpr int kPrecision = 64; // = q
    8333             : 
    8334             :     uint64_t f;
    8335             :     int e;
    8336             : 
    8337             :     constexpr diyfp() noexcept : f(0), e(0) {}
    8338        3887 :     constexpr diyfp(uint64_t f_, int e_) noexcept : f(f_), e(e_) {}
    8339             : 
    8340             :     /*!
    8341             :     @brief returns x - y
    8342             :     @pre x.e == y.e and x.f >= y.f
    8343             :     */
    8344         598 :     static diyfp sub(const diyfp& x, const diyfp& y) noexcept
    8345             :     {
    8346         598 :         assert(x.e == y.e);
    8347         598 :         assert(x.f >= y.f);
    8348             : 
    8349         598 :         return diyfp(x.f - y.f, x.e);
    8350             :     }
    8351             : 
    8352             :     /*!
    8353             :     @brief returns x * y
    8354             :     @note The result is rounded. (Only the upper q bits are returned.)
    8355             :     */
    8356         897 :     static diyfp mul(const diyfp& x, const diyfp& y) noexcept
    8357             :     {
    8358             :         static_assert(kPrecision == 64, "internal error");
    8359             : 
    8360             :         // Computes:
    8361             :         //  f = round((x.f * y.f) / 2^q)
    8362             :         //  e = x.e + y.e + q
    8363             : 
    8364             :         // Emulate the 64-bit * 64-bit multiplication:
    8365             :         //
    8366             :         // p = u * v
    8367             :         //   = (u_lo + 2^32 u_hi) (v_lo + 2^32 v_hi)
    8368             :         //   = (u_lo v_lo         ) + 2^32 ((u_lo v_hi         ) + (u_hi v_lo         )) + 2^64 (u_hi v_hi         )
    8369             :         //   = (p0                ) + 2^32 ((p1                ) + (p2                )) + 2^64 (p3                )
    8370             :         //   = (p0_lo + 2^32 p0_hi) + 2^32 ((p1_lo + 2^32 p1_hi) + (p2_lo + 2^32 p2_hi)) + 2^64 (p3                )
    8371             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (p0_hi + p1_lo + p2_lo                      ) + 2^64 (p1_hi + p2_hi + p3)
    8372             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (Q                                          ) + 2^64 (H                 )
    8373             :         //   = (p0_lo             ) + 2^32 (Q_lo + 2^32 Q_hi                           ) + 2^64 (H                 )
    8374             :         //
    8375             :         // (Since Q might be larger than 2^32 - 1)
    8376             :         //
    8377             :         //   = (p0_lo + 2^32 Q_lo) + 2^64 (Q_hi + H)
    8378             :         //
    8379             :         // (Q_hi + H does not overflow a 64-bit int)
    8380             :         //
    8381             :         //   = p_lo + 2^64 p_hi
    8382             : 
    8383         897 :         const uint64_t u_lo = x.f & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    8384         897 :         const uint64_t u_hi = x.f >> 32;
    8385         897 :         const uint64_t v_lo = y.f & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    8386         897 :         const uint64_t v_hi = y.f >> 32;
    8387             : 
    8388         897 :         const uint64_t p0 = u_lo * v_lo;
    8389         897 :         const uint64_t p1 = u_lo * v_hi;
    8390         897 :         const uint64_t p2 = u_hi * v_lo;
    8391         897 :         const uint64_t p3 = u_hi * v_hi;
    8392             : 
    8393         897 :         const uint64_t p0_hi = p0 >> 32;
    8394         897 :         const uint64_t p1_lo = p1 & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    8395         897 :         const uint64_t p1_hi = p1 >> 32;
    8396         897 :         const uint64_t p2_lo = p2 & 0xFFFFFFFF;
    8397         897 :         const uint64_t p2_hi = p2 >> 32;
    8398             : 
    8399         897 :         uint64_t Q = p0_hi + p1_lo + p2_lo;
    8400             : 
    8401             :         // The full product might now be computed as
    8402             :         //
    8403             :         // p_hi = p3 + p2_hi + p1_hi + (Q >> 32)
    8404             :         // p_lo = p0_lo + (Q << 32)
    8405             :         //
    8406             :         // But in this particular case here, the full p_lo is not required.
    8407             :         // Effectively we only need to add the highest bit in p_lo to p_hi (and
    8408             :         // Q_hi + 1 does not overflow).
    8409             : 
    8410         897 :         Q += uint64_t{1} << (64 - 32 - 1); // round, ties up
    8411             : 
    8412         897 :         const uint64_t h = p3 + p2_hi + p1_hi + (Q >> 32);
    8413             : 
    8414         897 :         return diyfp(h, x.e + y.e + 64);
    8415             :     }
    8416             : 
    8417             :     /*!
    8418             :     @brief normalize x such that the significand is >= 2^(q-1)
    8419             :     @pre x.f != 0
    8420             :     */
    8421         598 :     static diyfp normalize(diyfp x) noexcept
    8422             :     {
    8423         598 :         assert(x.f != 0);
    8424             : 
    8425       23188 :         while ((x.f >> 63) == 0)
    8426             :         {
    8427       11295 :             x.f <<= 1;
    8428       11295 :             x.e--;
    8429             :         }
    8430             : 
    8431         598 :         return x;
    8432             :     }
    8433             : 
    8434             :     /*!
    8435             :     @brief normalize x such that the result has the exponent E
    8436             :     @pre e >= x.e and the upper e - x.e bits of x.f must be zero.
    8437             :     */
    8438         299 :     static diyfp normalize_to(const diyfp& x, const int target_exponent) noexcept
    8439             :     {
    8440         299 :         const int delta = x.e - target_exponent;
    8441             : 
    8442         299 :         assert(delta >= 0);
    8443         299 :         assert(((x.f << delta) >> delta) == x.f);
    8444             : 
    8445         299 :         return diyfp(x.f << delta, target_exponent);
    8446             :     }
    8447             : };
    8448             : 
    8449             : struct boundaries
    8450             : {
    8451             :     diyfp w;
    8452             :     diyfp minus;
    8453             :     diyfp plus;
    8454             : };
    8455             : 
    8456             : /*!
    8457             : Compute the (normalized) diyfp representing the input number 'value' and its
    8458             : boundaries.
    8459             : 
    8460             : @pre value must be finite and positive
    8461             : */
    8462             : template <typename FloatType>
    8463         299 : boundaries compute_boundaries(FloatType value)
    8464             : {
    8465         299 :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    8466         299 :     assert(value > 0);
    8467             : 
    8468             :     // Convert the IEEE representation into a diyfp.
    8469             :     //
    8470             :     // If v is denormal:
    8471             :     //      value = 0.F * 2^(1 - bias) = (          F) * 2^(1 - bias - (p-1))
    8472             :     // If v is normalized:
    8473             :     //      value = 1.F * 2^(E - bias) = (2^(p-1) + F) * 2^(E - bias - (p-1))
    8474             : 
    8475             :     static_assert(std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::is_iec559,
    8476             :                   "internal error: dtoa_short requires an IEEE-754 floating-point implementation");
    8477             : 
    8478         299 :     constexpr int      kPrecision = std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits; // = p (includes the hidden bit)
    8479         299 :     constexpr int      kBias      = std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_exponent - 1 + (kPrecision - 1);
    8480         299 :     constexpr int      kMinExp    = 1 - kBias;
    8481         299 :     constexpr uint64_t kHiddenBit = uint64_t{1} << (kPrecision - 1); // = 2^(p-1)
    8482             : 
    8483             :     using bits_type = typename std::conditional< kPrecision == 24, uint32_t, uint64_t >::type;
    8484             : 
    8485         299 :     const uint64_t bits = reinterpret_bits<bits_type>(value);
    8486         299 :     const uint64_t E = bits >> (kPrecision - 1);
    8487         299 :     const uint64_t F = bits & (kHiddenBit - 1);
    8488             : 
    8489         299 :     const bool is_denormal = (E == 0);
    8490         299 :     const diyfp v = is_denormal
    8491             :                     ? diyfp(F, kMinExp)
    8492             :                     : diyfp(F + kHiddenBit, static_cast<int>(E) - kBias);
    8493             : 
    8494             :     // Compute the boundaries m- and m+ of the floating-point value
    8495             :     // v = f * 2^e.
    8496             :     //
    8497             :     // Determine v- and v+, the floating-point predecessor and successor if v,
    8498             :     // respectively.
    8499             :     //
    8500             :     //      v- = v - 2^e        if f != 2^(p-1) or e == e_min                (A)
    8501             :     //         = v - 2^(e-1)    if f == 2^(p-1) and e > e_min                (B)
    8502             :     //
    8503             :     //      v+ = v + 2^e
    8504             :     //
    8505             :     // Let m- = (v- + v) / 2 and m+ = (v + v+) / 2. All real numbers _strictly_
    8506             :     // between m- and m+ round to v, regardless of how the input rounding
    8507             :     // algorithm breaks ties.
    8508             :     //
    8509             :     //      ---+-------------+-------------+-------------+-------------+---  (A)
    8510             :     //         v-            m-            v             m+            v+
    8511             :     //
    8512             :     //      -----------------+------+------+-------------+-------------+---  (B)
    8513             :     //                       v-     m-     v             m+            v+
    8514             : 
    8515         299 :     const bool lower_boundary_is_closer = (F == 0 and E > 1);
    8516         299 :     const diyfp m_plus = diyfp(2 * v.f + 1, v.e - 1);
    8517         897 :     const diyfp m_minus = lower_boundary_is_closer
    8518          22 :                           ? diyfp(4 * v.f - 1, v.e - 2)  // (B)
    8519         576 :                           : diyfp(2 * v.f - 1, v.e - 1); // (A)
    8520             : 
    8521             :     // Determine the normalized w+ = m+.
    8522         299 :     const diyfp w_plus = diyfp::normalize(m_plus);
    8523             : 
    8524             :     // Determine w- = m- such that e_(w-) = e_(w+).
    8525         299 :     const diyfp w_minus = diyfp::normalize_to(m_minus, w_plus.e);
    8526             : 
    8527         299 :     return {diyfp::normalize(v), w_minus, w_plus};
    8528             : }
    8529             : 
    8530             : // Given normalized diyfp w, Grisu needs to find a (normalized) cached
    8531             : // power-of-ten c, such that the exponent of the product c * w = f * 2^e lies
    8532             : // within a certain range [alpha, gamma] (Definition 3.2 from [1])
    8533             : //
    8534             : //      alpha <= e = e_c + e_w + q <= gamma
    8535             : //
    8536             : // or
    8537             : //
    8538             : //      f_c * f_w * 2^alpha <= f_c 2^(e_c) * f_w 2^(e_w) * 2^q
    8539             : //                          <= f_c * f_w * 2^gamma
    8540             : //
    8541             : // Since c and w are normalized, i.e. 2^(q-1) <= f < 2^q, this implies
    8542             : //
    8543             : //      2^(q-1) * 2^(q-1) * 2^alpha <= c * w * 2^q < 2^q * 2^q * 2^gamma
    8544             : //
    8545             : // or
    8546             : //
    8547             : //      2^(q - 2 + alpha) <= c * w < 2^(q + gamma)
    8548             : //
    8549             : // The choice of (alpha,gamma) determines the size of the table and the form of
    8550             : // the digit generation procedure. Using (alpha,gamma)=(-60,-32) works out well
    8551             : // in practice:
    8552             : //
    8553             : // The idea is to cut the number c * w = f * 2^e into two parts, which can be
    8554             : // processed independently: An integral part p1, and a fractional part p2:
    8555             : //
    8556             : //      f * 2^e = ( (f div 2^-e) * 2^-e + (f mod 2^-e) ) * 2^e
    8557             : //              = (f div 2^-e) + (f mod 2^-e) * 2^e
    8558             : //              = p1 + p2 * 2^e
    8559             : //
    8560             : // The conversion of p1 into decimal form requires a series of divisions and
    8561             : // modulos by (a power of) 10. These operations are faster for 32-bit than for
    8562             : // 64-bit integers, so p1 should ideally fit into a 32-bit integer. This can be
    8563             : // achieved by choosing
    8564             : //
    8565             : //      -e >= 32   or   e <= -32 := gamma
    8566             : //
    8567             : // In order to convert the fractional part
    8568             : //
    8569             : //      p2 * 2^e = p2 / 2^-e = d[-1] / 10^1 + d[-2] / 10^2 + ...
    8570             : //
    8571             : // into decimal form, the fraction is repeatedly multiplied by 10 and the digits
    8572             : // d[-i] are extracted in order:
    8573             : //
    8574             : //      (10 * p2) div 2^-e = d[-1]
    8575             : //      (10 * p2) mod 2^-e = d[-2] / 10^1 + ...
    8576             : //
    8577             : // The multiplication by 10 must not overflow. It is sufficient to choose
    8578             : //
    8579             : //      10 * p2 < 16 * p2 = 2^4 * p2 <= 2^64.
    8580             : //
    8581             : // Since p2 = f mod 2^-e < 2^-e,
    8582             : //
    8583             : //      -e <= 60   or   e >= -60 := alpha
    8584             : 
    8585             : constexpr int kAlpha = -60;
    8586             : constexpr int kGamma = -32;
    8587             : 
    8588             : struct cached_power // c = f * 2^e ~= 10^k
    8589             : {
    8590             :     uint64_t f;
    8591             :     int e;
    8592             :     int k;
    8593             : };
    8594             : 
    8595             : /*!
    8596             : For a normalized diyfp w = f * 2^e, this function returns a (normalized) cached
    8597             : power-of-ten c = f_c * 2^e_c, such that the exponent of the product w * c
    8598             : satisfies (Definition 3.2 from [1])
    8599             : 
    8600             :      alpha <= e_c + e + q <= gamma.
    8601             : */
    8602         299 : inline cached_power get_cached_power_for_binary_exponent(int e)
    8603             : {
    8604             :     // Now
    8605             :     //
    8606             :     //      alpha <= e_c + e + q <= gamma                                    (1)
    8607             :     //      ==> f_c * 2^alpha <= c * 2^e * 2^q
    8608             :     //
    8609             :     // and since the c's are normalized, 2^(q-1) <= f_c,
    8610             :     //
    8611             :     //      ==> 2^(q - 1 + alpha) <= c * 2^(e + q)
    8612             :     //      ==> 2^(alpha - e - 1) <= c
    8613             :     //
    8614             :     // If c were an exakt power of ten, i.e. c = 10^k, one may determine k as
    8615             :     //
    8616             :     //      k = ceil( log_10( 2^(alpha - e - 1) ) )
    8617             :     //        = ceil( (alpha - e - 1) * log_10(2) )
    8618             :     //
    8619             :     // From the paper:
    8620             :     // "In theory the result of the procedure could be wrong since c is rounded,
    8621             :     //  and the computation itself is approximated [...]. In practice, however,
    8622             :     //  this simple function is sufficient."
    8623             :     //
    8624             :     // For IEEE double precision floating-point numbers converted into
    8625             :     // normalized diyfp's w = f * 2^e, with q = 64,
    8626             :     //
    8627             :     //      e >= -1022      (min IEEE exponent)
    8628             :     //           -52        (p - 1)
    8629             :     //           -52        (p - 1, possibly normalize denormal IEEE numbers)
    8630             :     //           -11        (normalize the diyfp)
    8631             :     //         = -1137
    8632             :     //
    8633             :     // and
    8634             :     //
    8635             :     //      e <= +1023      (max IEEE exponent)
    8636             :     //           -52        (p - 1)
    8637             :     //           -11        (normalize the diyfp)
    8638             :     //         = 960
    8639             :     //
    8640             :     // This binary exponent range [-1137,960] results in a decimal exponent
    8641             :     // range [-307,324]. One does not need to store a cached power for each
    8642             :     // k in this range. For each such k it suffices to find a cached power
    8643             :     // such that the exponent of the product lies in [alpha,gamma].
    8644             :     // This implies that the difference of the decimal exponents of adjacent
    8645             :     // table entries must be less than or equal to
    8646             :     //
    8647             :     //      floor( (gamma - alpha) * log_10(2) ) = 8.
    8648             :     //
    8649             :     // (A smaller distance gamma-alpha would require a larger table.)
    8650             : 
    8651             :     // NB:
    8652             :     // Actually this function returns c, such that -60 <= e_c + e + 64 <= -34.
    8653             : 
    8654         299 :     constexpr int kCachedPowersSize = 79;
    8655         299 :     constexpr int kCachedPowersMinDecExp = -300;
    8656         299 :     constexpr int kCachedPowersDecStep = 8;
    8657             : 
    8658             :     static constexpr cached_power kCachedPowers[] =
    8659             :     {
    8660             :         { 0xAB70FE17C79AC6CA, -1060, -300 },
    8661             :         { 0xFF77B1FCBEBCDC4F, -1034, -292 },
    8662             :         { 0xBE5691EF416BD60C, -1007, -284 },
    8663             :         { 0x8DD01FAD907FFC3C,  -980, -276 },
    8664             :         { 0xD3515C2831559A83,  -954, -268 },
    8665             :         { 0x9D71AC8FADA6C9B5,  -927, -260 },
    8666             :         { 0xEA9C227723EE8BCB,  -901, -252 },
    8667             :         { 0xAECC49914078536D,  -874, -244 },
    8668             :         { 0x823C12795DB6CE57,  -847, -236 },
    8669             :         { 0xC21094364DFB5637,  -821, -228 },
    8670             :         { 0x9096EA6F3848984F,  -794, -220 },
    8671             :         { 0xD77485CB25823AC7,  -768, -212 },
    8672             :         { 0xA086CFCD97BF97F4,  -741, -204 },
    8673             :         { 0xEF340A98172AACE5,  -715, -196 },
    8674             :         { 0xB23867FB2A35B28E,  -688, -188 },
    8675             :         { 0x84C8D4DFD2C63F3B,  -661, -180 },
    8676             :         { 0xC5DD44271AD3CDBA,  -635, -172 },
    8677             :         { 0x936B9FCEBB25C996,  -608, -164 },
    8678             :         { 0xDBAC6C247D62A584,  -582, -156 },
    8679             :         { 0xA3AB66580D5FDAF6,  -555, -148 },
    8680             :         { 0xF3E2F893DEC3F126,  -529, -140 },
    8681             :         { 0xB5B5ADA8AAFF80B8,  -502, -132 },
    8682             :         { 0x87625F056C7C4A8B,  -475, -124 },
    8683             :         { 0xC9BCFF6034C13053,  -449, -116 },
    8684             :         { 0x964E858C91BA2655,  -422, -108 },
    8685             :         { 0xDFF9772470297EBD,  -396, -100 },
    8686             :         { 0xA6DFBD9FB8E5B88F,  -369,  -92 },
    8687             :         { 0xF8A95FCF88747D94,  -343,  -84 },
    8688             :         { 0xB94470938FA89BCF,  -316,  -76 },
    8689             :         { 0x8A08F0F8BF0F156B,  -289,  -68 },
    8690             :         { 0xCDB02555653131B6,  -263,  -60 },
    8691             :         { 0x993FE2C6D07B7FAC,  -236,  -52 },
    8692             :         { 0xE45C10C42A2B3B06,  -210,  -44 },
    8693             :         { 0xAA242499697392D3,  -183,  -36 },
    8694             :         { 0xFD87B5F28300CA0E,  -157,  -28 },
    8695             :         { 0xBCE5086492111AEB,  -130,  -20 },
    8696             :         { 0x8CBCCC096F5088CC,  -103,  -12 },
    8697             :         { 0xD1B71758E219652C,   -77,   -4 },
    8698             :         { 0x9C40000000000000,   -50,    4 },
    8699             :         { 0xE8D4A51000000000,   -24,   12 },
    8700             :         { 0xAD78EBC5AC620000,     3,   20 },
    8701             :         { 0x813F3978F8940984,    30,   28 },
    8702             :         { 0xC097CE7BC90715B3,    56,   36 },
    8703             :         { 0x8F7E32CE7BEA5C70,    83,   44 },
    8704             :         { 0xD5D238A4ABE98068,   109,   52 },
    8705             :         { 0x9F4F2726179A2245,   136,   60 },
    8706             :         { 0xED63A231D4C4FB27,   162,   68 },
    8707             :         { 0xB0DE65388CC8ADA8,   189,   76 },
    8708             :         { 0x83C7088E1AAB65DB,   216,   84 },
    8709             :         { 0xC45D1DF942711D9A,   242,   92 },
    8710             :         { 0x924D692CA61BE758,   269,  100 },
    8711             :         { 0xDA01EE641A708DEA,   295,  108 },
    8712             :         { 0xA26DA3999AEF774A,   322,  116 },
    8713             :         { 0xF209787BB47D6B85,   348,  124 },
    8714             :         { 0xB454E4A179DD1877,   375,  132 },
    8715             :         { 0x865B86925B9BC5C2,   402,  140 },
    8716             :         { 0xC83553C5C8965D3D,   428,  148 },
    8717             :         { 0x952AB45CFA97A0B3,   455,  156 },
    8718             :         { 0xDE469FBD99A05FE3,   481,  164 },
    8719             :         { 0xA59BC234DB398C25,   508,  172 },
    8720             :         { 0xF6C69A72A3989F5C,   534,  180 },
    8721             :         { 0xB7DCBF5354E9BECE,   561,  188 },
    8722             :         { 0x88FCF317F22241E2,   588,  196 },
    8723             :         { 0xCC20CE9BD35C78A5,   614,  204 },
    8724             :         { 0x98165AF37B2153DF,   641,  212 },
    8725             :         { 0xE2A0B5DC971F303A,   667,  220 },
    8726             :         { 0xA8D9D1535CE3B396,   694,  228 },
    8727             :         { 0xFB9B7CD9A4A7443C,   720,  236 },
    8728             :         { 0xBB764C4CA7A44410,   747,  244 },
    8729             :         { 0x8BAB8EEFB6409C1A,   774,  252 },
    8730             :         { 0xD01FEF10A657842C,   800,  260 },
    8731             :         { 0x9B10A4E5E9913129,   827,  268 },
    8732             :         { 0xE7109BFBA19C0C9D,   853,  276 },
    8733             :         { 0xAC2820D9623BF429,   880,  284 },
    8734             :         { 0x80444B5E7AA7CF85,   907,  292 },
    8735             :         { 0xBF21E44003ACDD2D,   933,  300 },
    8736             :         { 0x8E679C2F5E44FF8F,   960,  308 },
    8737             :         { 0xD433179D9C8CB841,   986,  316 },
    8738             :         { 0x9E19DB92B4E31BA9,  1013,  324 },
    8739             :     };
    8740             : 
    8741             :     // This computation gives exactly the same results for k as
    8742             :     //      k = ceil((kAlpha - e - 1) * 0.30102999566398114)
    8743             :     // for |e| <= 1500, but doesn't require floating-point operations.
    8744             :     // NB: log_10(2) ~= 78913 / 2^18
    8745         299 :     assert(e >= -1500);
    8746         299 :     assert(e <=  1500);
    8747         299 :     const int f = kAlpha - e - 1;
    8748         299 :     const int k = (f * 78913) / (1 << 18) + (f > 0);
    8749             : 
    8750         299 :     const int index = (-kCachedPowersMinDecExp + k + (kCachedPowersDecStep - 1)) / kCachedPowersDecStep;
    8751         299 :     assert(index >= 0);
    8752         299 :     assert(index < kCachedPowersSize);
    8753             :     static_cast<void>(kCachedPowersSize); // Fix warning.
    8754             : 
    8755         299 :     const cached_power cached = kCachedPowers[index];
    8756         299 :     assert(kAlpha <= cached.e + e + 64);
    8757         299 :     assert(kGamma >= cached.e + e + 64);
    8758             : 
    8759         299 :     return cached;
    8760             : }
    8761             : 
    8762             : /*!
    8763             : For n != 0, returns k, such that pow10 := 10^(k-1) <= n < 10^k.
    8764             : For n == 0, returns 1 and sets pow10 := 1.
    8765             : */
    8766         299 : inline int find_largest_pow10(const uint32_t n, uint32_t& pow10)
    8767             : {
    8768             :     // LCOV_EXCL_START
    8769             :     if (n >= 1000000000)
    8770             :     {
    8771             :         pow10 = 1000000000;
    8772             :         return 10;
    8773             :     }
    8774             :     // LCOV_EXCL_STOP
    8775         299 :     else if (n >= 100000000)
    8776             :     {
    8777          43 :         pow10 = 100000000;
    8778          43 :         return  9;
    8779             :     }
    8780         256 :     else if (n >= 10000000)
    8781             :     {
    8782          32 :         pow10 = 10000000;
    8783          32 :         return  8;
    8784             :     }
    8785         224 :     else if (n >= 1000000)
    8786             :     {
    8787          36 :         pow10 = 1000000;
    8788          36 :         return  7;
    8789             :     }
    8790         188 :     else if (n >= 100000)
    8791             :     {
    8792          36 :         pow10 = 100000;
    8793          36 :         return  6;
    8794             :     }
    8795         152 :     else if (n >= 10000)
    8796             :     {
    8797          37 :         pow10 = 10000;
    8798          37 :         return  5;
    8799             :     }
    8800         115 :     else if (n >= 1000)
    8801             :     {
    8802          36 :         pow10 = 1000;
    8803          36 :         return  4;
    8804             :     }
    8805          79 :     else if (n >= 100)
    8806             :     {
    8807          29 :         pow10 = 100;
    8808          29 :         return  3;
    8809             :     }
    8810          50 :     else if (n >= 10)
    8811             :     {
    8812          39 :         pow10 = 10;
    8813          39 :         return  2;
    8814             :     }
    8815             :     else
    8816             :     {
    8817          11 :         pow10 = 1;
    8818          11 :         return 1;
    8819             :     }
    8820             : }
    8821             : 
    8822         299 : inline void grisu2_round(char* buf, int len, uint64_t dist, uint64_t delta,
    8823             :                          uint64_t rest, uint64_t ten_k)
    8824             : {
    8825         299 :     assert(len >= 1);
    8826         299 :     assert(dist <= delta);
    8827         299 :     assert(rest <= delta);
    8828         299 :     assert(ten_k > 0);
    8829             : 
    8830             :     //               <--------------------------- delta ---->
    8831             :     //                                  <---- dist --------->
    8832             :     // --------------[------------------+-------------------]--------------
    8833             :     //               M-                 w                   M+
    8834             :     //
    8835             :     //                                  ten_k
    8836             :     //                                <------>
    8837             :     //                                       <---- rest ---->
    8838             :     // --------------[------------------+----+--------------]--------------
    8839             :     //                                  w    V
    8840             :     //                                       = buf * 10^k
    8841             :     //
    8842             :     // ten_k represents a unit-in-the-last-place in the decimal representation
    8843             :     // stored in buf.
    8844             :     // Decrement buf by ten_k while this takes buf closer to w.
    8845             : 
    8846             :     // The tests are written in this order to avoid overflow in unsigned
    8847             :     // integer arithmetic.
    8848             : 
    8849          70 :     while (rest < dist
    8850         205 :             and delta - rest >= ten_k
    8851         466 :             and (rest + ten_k < dist or dist - rest > rest + ten_k - dist))
    8852             :     {
    8853          70 :         assert(buf[len - 1] != '0');
    8854          70 :         buf[len - 1]--;
    8855          70 :         rest += ten_k;
    8856             :     }
    8857         299 : }
    8858             : 
    8859             : /*!
    8860             : Generates V = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent, such that M- <= V <= M+.
    8861             : M- and M+ must be normalized and share the same exponent -60 <= e <= -32.
    8862             : */
    8863         299 : inline void grisu2_digit_gen(char* buffer, int& length, int& decimal_exponent,
    8864             :                              diyfp M_minus, diyfp w, diyfp M_plus)
    8865             : {
    8866             :     static_assert(kAlpha >= -60, "internal error");
    8867             :     static_assert(kGamma <= -32, "internal error");
    8868             : 
    8869             :     // Generates the digits (and the exponent) of a decimal floating-point
    8870             :     // number V = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent in the range [M-, M+]. The diyfp's
    8871             :     // w, M- and M+ share the same exponent e, which satisfies alpha <= e <= gamma.
    8872             :     //
    8873             :     //               <--------------------------- delta ---->
    8874             :     //                                  <---- dist --------->
    8875             :     // --------------[------------------+-------------------]--------------
    8876             :     //               M-                 w                   M+
    8877             :     //
    8878             :     // Grisu2 generates the digits of M+ from left to right and stops as soon as
    8879             :     // V is in [M-,M+].
    8880             : 
    8881         299 :     assert(M_plus.e >= kAlpha);
    8882         299 :     assert(M_plus.e <= kGamma);
    8883             : 
    8884         299 :     uint64_t delta = diyfp::sub(M_plus, M_minus).f; // (significand of (M+ - M-), implicit exponent is e)
    8885         299 :     uint64_t dist  = diyfp::sub(M_plus, w      ).f; // (significand of (M+ - w ), implicit exponent is e)
    8886             : 
    8887             :     // Split M+ = f * 2^e into two parts p1 and p2 (note: e < 0):
    8888             :     //
    8889             :     //      M+ = f * 2^e
    8890             :     //         = ((f div 2^-e) * 2^-e + (f mod 2^-e)) * 2^e
    8891             :     //         = ((p1        ) * 2^-e + (p2        )) * 2^e
    8892             :     //         = p1 + p2 * 2^e
    8893             : 
    8894         299 :     const diyfp one(uint64_t{1} << -M_plus.e, M_plus.e);
    8895             : 
    8896         299 :     uint32_t p1 = static_cast<uint32_t>(M_plus.f >> -one.e); // p1 = f div 2^-e (Since -e >= 32, p1 fits into a 32-bit int.)
    8897         299 :     uint64_t p2 = M_plus.f & (one.f - 1);                    // p2 = f mod 2^-e
    8898             : 
    8899             :     // 1)
    8900             :     //
    8901             :     // Generate the digits of the integral part p1 = d[n-1]...d[1]d[0]
    8902             : 
    8903         299 :     assert(p1 > 0);
    8904             : 
    8905             :     uint32_t pow10;
    8906         299 :     const int k = find_largest_pow10(p1, pow10);
    8907             : 
    8908             :     //      10^(k-1) <= p1 < 10^k, pow10 = 10^(k-1)
    8909             :     //
    8910             :     //      p1 = (p1 div 10^(k-1)) * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))
    8911             :     //         = (d[k-1]         ) * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))
    8912             :     //
    8913             :     //      M+ = p1                                             + p2 * 2^e
    8914             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + (p1 mod 10^(k-1))          + p2 * 2^e
    8915             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + ((p1 mod 10^(k-1)) * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e
    8916             :     //         = d[k-1] * 10^(k-1) + (                         rest) * 2^e
    8917             :     //
    8918             :     // Now generate the digits d[n] of p1 from left to right (n = k-1,...,0)
    8919             :     //
    8920             :     //      p1 = d[k-1]...d[n] * 10^n + d[n-1]...d[0]
    8921             :     //
    8922             :     // but stop as soon as
    8923             :     //
    8924             :     //      rest * 2^e = (d[n-1]...d[0] * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    8925             : 
    8926         299 :     int n = k;
    8927        2849 :     while (n > 0)
    8928             :     {
    8929             :         // Invariants:
    8930             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (p1 + p2 * 2^e)    (buffer = 0 for n = k)
    8931             :         //      pow10 = 10^(n-1) <= p1 < 10^n
    8932             :         //
    8933        1379 :         const uint32_t d = p1 / pow10;  // d = p1 div 10^(n-1)
    8934        1379 :         const uint32_t r = p1 % pow10;  // r = p1 mod 10^(n-1)
    8935             :         //
    8936             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (d * 10^(n-1) + r) + p2 * 2^e
    8937             :         //         = (buffer * 10 + d) * 10^(n-1) + (r + p2 * 2^e)
    8938             :         //
    8939        1379 :         assert(d <= 9);
    8940        1379 :         buffer[length++] = static_cast<char>('0' + d); // buffer := buffer * 10 + d
    8941             :         //
    8942             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^(n-1) + (r + p2 * 2^e)
    8943             :         //
    8944        1379 :         p1 = r;
    8945        1379 :         n--;
    8946             :         //
    8947             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^n + (p1 + p2 * 2^e)
    8948             :         //      pow10 = 10^n
    8949             :         //
    8950             : 
    8951             :         // Now check if enough digits have been generated.
    8952             :         // Compute
    8953             :         //
    8954             :         //      p1 + p2 * 2^e = (p1 * 2^-e + p2) * 2^e = rest * 2^e
    8955             :         //
    8956             :         // Note:
    8957             :         // Since rest and delta share the same exponent e, it suffices to
    8958             :         // compare the significands.
    8959        1379 :         const uint64_t rest = (uint64_t{p1} << -one.e) + p2;
    8960        1379 :         if (rest <= delta)
    8961             :         {
    8962             :             // V = buffer * 10^n, with M- <= V <= M+.
    8963             : 
    8964         104 :             decimal_exponent += n;
    8965             : 
    8966             :             // We may now just stop. But instead look if the buffer could be
    8967             :             // decremented to bring V closer to w.
    8968             :             //
    8969             :             // pow10 = 10^n is now 1 ulp in the decimal representation V.
    8970             :             // The rounding procedure works with diyfp's with an implicit
    8971             :             // exponent of e.
    8972             :             //
    8973             :             //      10^n = (10^n * 2^-e) * 2^e = ulp * 2^e
    8974             :             //
    8975         104 :             const uint64_t ten_n = uint64_t{pow10} << -one.e;
    8976         104 :             grisu2_round(buffer, length, dist, delta, rest, ten_n);
    8977             : 
    8978         104 :             return;
    8979             :         }
    8980             : 
    8981        1275 :         pow10 /= 10;
    8982             :         //
    8983             :         //      pow10 = 10^(n-1) <= p1 < 10^n
    8984             :         // Invariants restored.
    8985             :     }
    8986             : 
    8987             :     // 2)
    8988             :     //
    8989             :     // The digits of the integral part have been generated:
    8990             :     //
    8991             :     //      M+ = d[k-1]...d[1]d[0] + p2 * 2^e
    8992             :     //         = buffer            + p2 * 2^e
    8993             :     //
    8994             :     // Now generate the digits of the fractional part p2 * 2^e.
    8995             :     //
    8996             :     // Note:
    8997             :     // No decimal point is generated: the exponent is adjusted instead.
    8998             :     //
    8999             :     // p2 actually represents the fraction
    9000             :     //
    9001             :     //      p2 * 2^e
    9002             :     //          = p2 / 2^-e
    9003             :     //          = d[-1] / 10^1 + d[-2] / 10^2 + ...
    9004             :     //
    9005             :     // Now generate the digits d[-m] of p1 from left to right (m = 1,2,...)
    9006             :     //
    9007             :     //      p2 * 2^e = d[-1]d[-2]...d[-m] * 10^-m
    9008             :     //                      + 10^-m * (d[-m-1] / 10^1 + d[-m-2] / 10^2 + ...)
    9009             :     //
    9010             :     // using
    9011             :     //
    9012             :     //      10^m * p2 = ((10^m * p2) div 2^-e) * 2^-e + ((10^m * p2) mod 2^-e)
    9013             :     //                = (                   d) * 2^-e + (                   r)
    9014             :     //
    9015             :     // or
    9016             :     //      10^m * p2 * 2^e = d + r * 2^e
    9017             :     //
    9018             :     // i.e.
    9019             :     //
    9020             :     //      M+ = buffer + p2 * 2^e
    9021             :     //         = buffer + 10^-m * (d + r * 2^e)
    9022             :     //         = (buffer * 10^m + d) * 10^-m + 10^-m * r * 2^e
    9023             :     //
    9024             :     // and stop as soon as 10^-m * r * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    9025             : 
    9026         195 :     assert(p2 > delta);
    9027             : 
    9028         195 :     int m = 0;
    9029             :     for (;;)
    9030             :     {
    9031             :         // Invariant:
    9032             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (d[-m-1] / 10 + d[-m-2] / 10^2 + ...) * 2^e
    9033             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (p2                                 ) * 2^e
    9034             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (10 * p2)                   ) * 2^e
    9035             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * ((10*p2 div 2^-e) * 2^-e + (10*p2 mod 2^-e)) * 2^e
    9036             :         //
    9037        1531 :         assert(p2 <= UINT64_MAX / 10);
    9038        1531 :         p2 *= 10;
    9039        1531 :         const uint64_t d = p2 >> -one.e;     // d = (10 * p2) div 2^-e
    9040        1531 :         const uint64_t r = p2 & (one.f - 1); // r = (10 * p2) mod 2^-e
    9041             :         //
    9042             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (d * 2^-e + r) * 2^e
    9043             :         //         = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * (1/10 * (d + r * 2^e))
    9044             :         //         = (buffer * 10 + d) * 10^(-m-1) + 10^(-m-1) * r * 2^e
    9045             :         //
    9046        1531 :         assert(d <= 9);
    9047        1531 :         buffer[length++] = static_cast<char>('0' + d); // buffer := buffer * 10 + d
    9048             :         //
    9049             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^(-m-1) + 10^(-m-1) * r * 2^e
    9050             :         //
    9051        1531 :         p2 = r;
    9052        1531 :         m++;
    9053             :         //
    9054             :         //      M+ = buffer * 10^-m + 10^-m * p2 * 2^e
    9055             :         // Invariant restored.
    9056             : 
    9057             :         // Check if enough digits have been generated.
    9058             :         //
    9059             :         //      10^-m * p2 * 2^e <= delta * 2^e
    9060             :         //              p2 * 2^e <= 10^m * delta * 2^e
    9061             :         //                    p2 <= 10^m * delta
    9062        1531 :         delta *= 10;
    9063        1531 :         dist  *= 10;
    9064        1531 :         if (p2 <= delta)
    9065             :         {
    9066         195 :             break;
    9067             :         }
    9068        1336 :     }
    9069             : 
    9070             :     // V = buffer * 10^-m, with M- <= V <= M+.
    9071             : 
    9072         195 :     decimal_exponent -= m;
    9073             : 
    9074             :     // 1 ulp in the decimal representation is now 10^-m.
    9075             :     // Since delta and dist are now scaled by 10^m, we need to do the
    9076             :     // same with ulp in order to keep the units in sync.
    9077             :     //
    9078             :     //      10^m * 10^-m = 1 = 2^-e * 2^e = ten_m * 2^e
    9079             :     //
    9080         195 :     const uint64_t ten_m = one.f;
    9081         195 :     grisu2_round(buffer, length, dist, delta, p2, ten_m);
    9082             : 
    9083             :     // By construction this algorithm generates the shortest possible decimal
    9084             :     // number (Loitsch, Theorem 6.2) which rounds back to w.
    9085             :     // For an input number of precision p, at least
    9086             :     //
    9087             :     //      N = 1 + ceil(p * log_10(2))
    9088             :     //
    9089             :     // decimal digits are sufficient to identify all binary floating-point
    9090             :     // numbers (Matula, "In-and-Out conversions").
    9091             :     // This implies that the algorithm does not produce more than N decimal
    9092             :     // digits.
    9093             :     //
    9094             :     //      N = 17 for p = 53 (IEEE double precision)
    9095             :     //      N = 9  for p = 24 (IEEE single precision)
    9096             : }
    9097             : 
    9098             : /*!
    9099             : v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    9100             : len is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    9101             : The buffer must be large enough, i.e. >= max_digits10.
    9102             : */
    9103         299 : inline void grisu2(char* buf, int& len, int& decimal_exponent,
    9104             :                    diyfp m_minus, diyfp v, diyfp m_plus)
    9105             : {
    9106         299 :     assert(m_plus.e == m_minus.e);
    9107         299 :     assert(m_plus.e == v.e);
    9108             : 
    9109             :     //  --------(-----------------------+-----------------------)--------    (A)
    9110             :     //          m-                      v                       m+
    9111             :     //
    9112             :     //  --------------------(-----------+-----------------------)--------    (B)
    9113             :     //                      m-          v                       m+
    9114             :     //
    9115             :     // First scale v (and m- and m+) such that the exponent is in the range
    9116             :     // [alpha, gamma].
    9117             : 
    9118         299 :     const cached_power cached = get_cached_power_for_binary_exponent(m_plus.e);
    9119             : 
    9120         299 :     const diyfp c_minus_k(cached.f, cached.e); // = c ~= 10^-k
    9121             : 
    9122             :     // The exponent of the products is = v.e + c_minus_k.e + q and is in the range [alpha,gamma]
    9123         299 :     const diyfp w       = diyfp::mul(v,       c_minus_k);
    9124         299 :     const diyfp w_minus = diyfp::mul(m_minus, c_minus_k);
    9125         299 :     const diyfp w_plus  = diyfp::mul(m_plus,  c_minus_k);
    9126             : 
    9127             :     //  ----(---+---)---------------(---+---)---------------(---+---)----
    9128             :     //          w-                      w                       w+
    9129             :     //          = c*m-                  = c*v                   = c*m+
    9130             :     //
    9131             :     // diyfp::mul rounds its result and c_minus_k is approximated too. w, w- and
    9132             :     // w+ are now off by a small amount.
    9133             :     // In fact:
    9134             :     //
    9135             :     //      w - v * 10^k < 1 ulp
    9136             :     //
    9137             :     // To account for this inaccuracy, add resp. subtract 1 ulp.
    9138             :     //
    9139             :     //  --------+---[---------------(---+---)---------------]---+--------
    9140             :     //          w-  M-                  w                   M+  w+
    9141             :     //
    9142             :     // Now any number in [M-, M+] (bounds included) will round to w when input,
    9143             :     // regardless of how the input rounding algorithm breaks ties.
    9144             :     //
    9145             :     // And digit_gen generates the shortest possible such number in [M-, M+].
    9146             :     // Note that this does not mean that Grisu2 always generates the shortest
    9147             :     // possible number in the interval (m-, m+).
    9148         299 :     const diyfp M_minus(w_minus.f + 1, w_minus.e);
    9149         299 :     const diyfp M_plus (w_plus.f  - 1, w_plus.e );
    9150             : 
    9151         299 :     decimal_exponent = -cached.k; // = -(-k) = k
    9152             : 
    9153         299 :     grisu2_digit_gen(buf, len, decimal_exponent, M_minus, w, M_plus);
    9154         299 : }
    9155             : 
    9156             : /*!
    9157             : v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    9158             : len is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    9159             : The buffer must be large enough, i.e. >= max_digits10.
    9160             : */
    9161             : template <typename FloatType>
    9162         299 : void grisu2(char* buf, int& len, int& decimal_exponent, FloatType value)
    9163             : {
    9164             :     static_assert(diyfp::kPrecision >= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits + 3,
    9165             :                   "internal error: not enough precision");
    9166             : 
    9167         299 :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    9168         299 :     assert(value > 0);
    9169             : 
    9170             :     // If the neighbors (and boundaries) of 'value' are always computed for double-precision
    9171             :     // numbers, all float's can be recovered using strtod (and strtof). However, the resulting
    9172             :     // decimal representations are not exactly "short".
    9173             :     //
    9174             :     // The documentation for 'std::to_chars' (http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/to_chars)
    9175             :     // says "value is converted to a string as if by std::sprintf in the default ("C") locale"
    9176             :     // and since sprintf promotes float's to double's, I think this is exactly what 'std::to_chars'
    9177             :     // does.
    9178             :     // On the other hand, the documentation for 'std::to_chars' requires that "parsing the
    9179             :     // representation using the corresponding std::from_chars function recovers value exactly". That
    9180             :     // indicates that single precision floating-point numbers should be recovered using
    9181             :     // 'std::strtof'.
    9182             :     //
    9183             :     // NB: If the neighbors are computed for single-precision numbers, there is a single float
    9184             :     //     (7.0385307e-26f) which can't be recovered using strtod. The resulting double precision
    9185             :     //     value is off by 1 ulp.
    9186             : #if 0
    9187             :     const boundaries w = compute_boundaries(static_cast<double>(value));
    9188             : #else
    9189         299 :     const boundaries w = compute_boundaries(value);
    9190             : #endif
    9191             : 
    9192         299 :     grisu2(buf, len, decimal_exponent, w.minus, w.w, w.plus);
    9193         299 : }
    9194             : 
    9195             : /*!
    9196             : @brief appends a decimal representation of e to buf
    9197             : @return a pointer to the element following the exponent.
    9198             : @pre -1000 < e < 1000
    9199             : */
    9200          83 : inline char* append_exponent(char* buf, int e)
    9201             : {
    9202          83 :     assert(e > -1000);
    9203          83 :     assert(e <  1000);
    9204             : 
    9205          83 :     if (e < 0)
    9206             :     {
    9207          50 :         e = -e;
    9208          50 :         *buf++ = '-';
    9209             :     }
    9210             :     else
    9211             :     {
    9212          33 :         *buf++ = '+';
    9213             :     }
    9214             : 
    9215          83 :     uint32_t k = static_cast<uint32_t>(e);
    9216          83 :     if (k < 10)
    9217             :     {
    9218             :         // Always print at least two digits in the exponent.
    9219             :         // This is for compatibility with printf("%g").
    9220          19 :         *buf++ = '0';
    9221          19 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    9222             :     }
    9223          64 :     else if (k < 100)
    9224             :     {
    9225          63 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 10);
    9226          63 :         k %= 10;
    9227          63 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    9228             :     }
    9229             :     else
    9230             :     {
    9231           1 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 100);
    9232           1 :         k %= 100;
    9233           1 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k / 10);
    9234           1 :         k %= 10;
    9235           1 :         *buf++ = static_cast<char>('0' + k);
    9236             :     }
    9237             : 
    9238          83 :     return buf;
    9239             : }
    9240             : 
    9241             : /*!
    9242             : @brief prettify v = buf * 10^decimal_exponent
    9243             : 
    9244             : If v is in the range [10^min_exp, 10^max_exp) it will be printed in fixed-point
    9245             : notation. Otherwise it will be printed in exponential notation.
    9246             : 
    9247             : @pre min_exp < 0
    9248             : @pre max_exp > 0
    9249             : */
    9250         152 : inline char* format_buffer(char* buf, int len, int decimal_exponent,
    9251             :                            int min_exp, int max_exp)
    9252             : {
    9253         152 :     assert(min_exp < 0);
    9254         152 :     assert(max_exp > 0);
    9255             : 
    9256         152 :     const int k = len;
    9257         152 :     const int n = len + decimal_exponent;
    9258             : 
    9259             :     // v = buf * 10^(n-k)
    9260             :     // k is the length of the buffer (number of decimal digits)
    9261             :     // n is the position of the decimal point relative to the start of the buffer.
    9262             : 
    9263         152 :     if (k <= n and n <= max_exp)
    9264             :     {
    9265             :         // digits[000]
    9266             :         // len <= max_exp + 2
    9267             : 
    9268          16 :         std::memset(buf + k, '0', static_cast<size_t>(n - k));
    9269             :         // Make it look like a floating-point number (#362, #378)
    9270          16 :         buf[n + 0] = '.';
    9271          16 :         buf[n + 1] = '0';
    9272          16 :         return buf + (n + 2);
    9273             :     }
    9274             : 
    9275         136 :     if (0 < n and n <= max_exp)
    9276             :     {
    9277             :         // dig.its
    9278             :         // len <= max_digits10 + 1
    9279             : 
    9280          41 :         assert(k > n);
    9281             : 
    9282          41 :         std::memmove(buf + (n + 1), buf + n, static_cast<size_t>(k - n));
    9283          41 :         buf[n] = '.';
    9284          41 :         return buf + (k + 1);
    9285             :     }
    9286             : 
    9287          95 :     if (min_exp < n and n <= 0)
    9288             :     {
    9289             :         // 0.[000]digits
    9290             :         // len <= 2 + (-min_exp - 1) + max_digits10
    9291             : 
    9292          12 :         std::memmove(buf + (2 + -n), buf, static_cast<size_t>(k));
    9293          12 :         buf[0] = '0';
    9294          12 :         buf[1] = '.';
    9295          12 :         std::memset(buf + 2, '0', static_cast<size_t>(-n));
    9296          12 :         return buf + (2 + (-n) + k);
    9297             :     }
    9298             : 
    9299          83 :     if (k == 1)
    9300             :     {
    9301             :         // dE+123
    9302             :         // len <= 1 + 5
    9303             : 
    9304           0 :         buf += 1;
    9305             :     }
    9306             :     else
    9307             :     {
    9308             :         // d.igitsE+123
    9309             :         // len <= max_digits10 + 1 + 5
    9310             : 
    9311          83 :         std::memmove(buf + 2, buf + 1, static_cast<size_t>(k - 1));
    9312          83 :         buf[1] = '.';
    9313          83 :         buf += 1 + k;
    9314             :     }
    9315             : 
    9316          83 :     *buf++ = 'e';
    9317          83 :     return append_exponent(buf, n - 1);
    9318             : }
    9319             : 
    9320             : } // namespace dtoa_impl
    9321             : 
    9322             : /*!
    9323             : @brief generates a decimal representation of the floating-point number value in [first, last).
    9324             : 
    9325             : The format of the resulting decimal representation is similar to printf's %g
    9326             : format. Returns an iterator pointing past-the-end of the decimal representation.
    9327             : 
    9328             : @note The input number must be finite, i.e. NaN's and Inf's are not supported.
    9329             : @note The buffer must be large enough.
    9330             : @note The result is NOT null-terminated.
    9331             : */
    9332             : template <typename FloatType>
    9333         156 : char* to_chars(char* first, char* last, FloatType value)
    9334             : {
    9335             :     static_cast<void>(last); // maybe unused - fix warning
    9336         156 :     assert(std::isfinite(value));
    9337             : 
    9338             :     // Use signbit(value) instead of (value < 0) since signbit works for -0.
    9339         156 :     if (std::signbit(value))
    9340             :     {
    9341          46 :         value = -value;
    9342          46 :         *first++ = '-';
    9343             :     }
    9344             : 
    9345         156 :     if (value == 0) // +-0
    9346             :     {
    9347           4 :         *first++ = '0';
    9348             :         // Make it look like a floating-point number (#362, #378)
    9349           4 :         *first++ = '.';
    9350           4 :         *first++ = '0';
    9351           4 :         return first;
    9352             :     }
    9353             : 
    9354         152 :     assert(last - first >= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);
    9355             : 
    9356             :     // Compute v = buffer * 10^decimal_exponent.
    9357             :     // The decimal digits are stored in the buffer, which needs to be interpreted
    9358             :     // as an unsigned decimal integer.
    9359             :     // len is the length of the buffer, i.e. the number of decimal digits.
    9360         152 :     int len = 0;
    9361         152 :     int decimal_exponent = 0;

    9363             : 
    9364         152 :     assert(len <= std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);
    9365             : 
    9366             :     // Format the buffer like printf("%.*g", prec, value)
    9367         152 :     constexpr int kMinExp = -4;

    9369         152 :     constexpr int kMaxExp = std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::digits10;

    9371         152 :     assert(last - first >= kMaxExp + 2);
    9372         152 :     assert(last - first >= 2 + (-kMinExp - 1) + std::numeric_limits<FloatType>::max_digits10);

    9423             : 
    9424             :     /*!
    9425             :     @brief internal implementation of the serialization function
    9426             : 
    9427             :     This function is called by the public member function dump and organizes
    9428             :     the serialization internally. The indentation level is propagated as
    9429             :     additional parameter. In case of arrays and objects, the function is
    9430             :     called recursively.
    9431             : 
    9432             :     - strings and object keys are escaped using `escape_string()`
    9433             :     - integer numbers are converted implicitly via `operator<<`
    9434             :     - floating-point numbers are converted to a string using `"%g"` format
    9435             : 
    9436             :     @param[in] val             value to serialize
    9437             :     @param[in] pretty_print    whether the output shall be pretty-printed
    9438             :     @param[in] indent_step     the indent level
    9439             :     @param[in] current_indent  the current indent level (only used internally)
    9440             :     */
    9441     1112661 :     void dump(const BasicJsonType& val, const bool pretty_print,
    9442             :               const bool ensure_ascii,
    9443             :               const unsigned int indent_step,
    9444             :               const unsigned int current_indent = 0)

    9633             :   private:
    9634             :     /*!
    9635             :     @brief dump escaped string
    9636             : 
    9637             :     Escape a string by replacing certain special characters by a sequence of an
    9638             :     escape character (backslash) and another character and other control
    9639             :     characters by a sequence of "\u" followed by a four-digit hex
    9640             :     representation. The escaped string is written to output stream @a o.
    9641             : 
    9642             :     @param[in] s  the string to escape
    9643             :     @param[in] ensure_ascii  whether to escape non-ASCII characters with
    9644             :                              \uXXXX sequences
    9645             : 
    9646             :     @complexity Linear in the length of string @a s.
    9647             :     */
    9648     1112534 :     void dump_escaped(const string_t& s, const bool ensure_ascii)
    9649             :     {
    9650             :         uint32_t codepoint;
    9651     1112534 :         uint8_t state = UTF8_ACCEPT;
    9652     1112534 :         std::size_t bytes = 0;  // number of bytes written to string_buffer
    9653             : 
    9654     5496836 :         for (std::size_t i = 0; i < s.size(); ++i)
    9655             :         {
    9656     4384366 :             const auto byte = static_cast<uint8_t>(s[i]);
    9657             : 
    9658     4384366 :             switch (decode(state, codepoint, byte))
    9659             :             {
    9660     1113334 :                 case UTF8_ACCEPT:  // decode found a new code point
    9661             :                 {
    9662     1113334 :                     switch (codepoint)
    9663             :                     {
    9664           3 :                         case 0x08: // backspace
    9665             :                         {
    9666           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9667           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = 'b';
    9668           3 :                             break;
    9669             :                         }
    9670             : 
    9671           3 :                         case 0x09: // horizontal tab
    9672             :                         {
    9673           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9674           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = 't';
    9675           3 :                             break;
    9676             :                         }
    9677             : 
    9678           4 :                         case 0x0A: // newline
    9679             :                         {
    9680           4 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9681           4 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = 'n';
    9682           4 :                             break;
    9683             :                         }
    9684             : 
    9685           3 :                         case 0x0C: // formfeed
    9686             :                         {
    9687           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9688           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = 'f';
    9689           3 :                             break;
    9690             :                         }
    9691             : 
    9692           3 :                         case 0x0D: // carriage return

    9694           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9695           3 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = 'r';
    9696           3 :                             break;
    9697             :                         }
    9698             : 
    9699          10 :                         case 0x22: // quotation mark
    9700             :                         {
    9701          10 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9702          10 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\"';
    9703          10 :                             break;
    9704             :                         }
    9705             : 
    9706           4 :                         case 0x5C: // reverse solidus
    9707             :                         {
    9708           4 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9709           4 :                             string_buffer[bytes++] = '\\';
    9710           4 :                             break;
    9711             :                         }
    9712             : 
    9713     1113304 :                         default:

    9720             :                                 {

    9723       63422 :                                     bytes += 6;
    9724             :                                 }
    9725             :                                 else
    9726             :                                 {
    9727     2097152 :                                     std::snprintf(string_buffer.data() + bytes, 13, "\\u%04x\\u%04x",

    9731             :                                 }
    9732             :                             }
    9733             :                             else

    9736             :                                 // been copied have in default case above)
    9737        1306 :                                 string_buffer[bytes++] = s[i];

    9787             :         }
    9788     1112467 :     }
    9789             : 
    9790             :     /*!
    9791             :     @brief dump an integer
    9792             : 
    9793             :     Dump a given integer to output stream @a o. Works internally with
    9794             :     @a number_buffer.
    9795             : 
    9796             :     @param[in] x  integer number (signed or unsigned) to dump
    9797             :     @tparam NumberType either @a number_integer_t or @a number_unsigned_t
    9798             :     */
    9799             :     template<typename NumberType, detail::enable_if_t<
    9800             :                  std::is_same<NumberType, number_unsigned_t>::value or
    9801             :                  std::is_same<NumberType, number_integer_t>::value,
    9802             :                  int> = 0>
    9803         101 :     void dump_integer(NumberType x)
    9804             :     {
    9805             :         // special case for "0"
    9806         101 :         if (x == 0)
    9807             :         {
    9808           2 :             o->write_character('0');
    9809           2 :             return;
    9810             :         }
    9811             : 
    9812          99 :         const bool is_negative = (x <= 0) and (x != 0);  // see issue #755
    9813          99 :         std::size_t i = 0;
    9814             : 
    9815         351 :         while (x != 0)
    9816             :         {
    9817             :             // spare 1 byte for '\0'
    9818         126 :             assert(i < number_buffer.size() - 1);
    9819             : 
    9820         126 :             const auto digit = std::labs(static_cast<long>(x % 10));
    9821         126 :             number_buffer[i++] = static_cast<char>('0' + digit);
    9822         126 :             x /= 10;
    9823             :         }
    9824             : 
    9825          99 :         if (is_negative)
    9826             :         {
    9827             :             // make sure there is capacity for the '-'
    9828           0 :             assert(i < number_buffer.size() - 2);
    9829           0 :             number_buffer[i++] = '-';
    9830             :         }
    9831             : 
    9832          99 :         std::reverse(number_buffer.begin(), number_buffer.begin() + i);
    9833          99 :         o->write_characters(number_buffer.data(), i);
    9834             :     }
    9835             : 
    9836             :     /*!
    9837             :     @brief dump a floating-point number
    9838             : 
    9839             :     Dump a given floating-point number to output stream @a o. Works internally
    9840             :     with @a number_buffer.
    9841             : 
    9842             :     @param[in] x  floating-point number to dump
    9843             :     */
    9844          72 :     void dump_float(number_float_t x)
    9845             :     {
    9846             :         // NaN / inf
    9847          72 :         if (not std::isfinite(x))
    9848             :         {
    9849          10 :             o->write_characters("null", 4);
    9850          10 :             return;
    9851             :         }
    9852             : 
    9853             :         // If number_float_t is an IEEE-754 single or double precision number,
    9854             :         // use the Grisu2 algorithm to produce short numbers which are
    9855             :         // guaranteed to round-trip, using strtof and strtod, resp.
    9856             :         //
    9857             :         // NB: The test below works if <long double> == <double>.

    9861             : 
    9862          62 :         dump_float(x, std::integral_constant<bool, is_ieee_single_or_double>());

    9873             :     void dump_float(number_float_t x, std::false_type /*is_ieee_single_or_double*/)
    9874             :     {
    9875             :         // get number of digits for a float -> text -> float round-trip
    9876             :         static constexpr auto d = std::numeric_limits<number_float_t>::max_digits10;
    9877             : 
    9878             :         // the actual conversion
    9879             :         std::ptrdiff_t len = snprintf(number_buffer.data(), number_buffer.size(), "%.*g", d, x);

    9881             :         // negative value indicates an error
    9882             :         assert(len > 0);
    9883             :         // check if buffer was large enough
