   11640        8056 :                     object = create<object_t>();
   11641        8055 :                     break;
   11642             :                 }
   11643             : 
   11644        9139 :                 case value_t::array:
   11645             :                 {
   11646        9139 :                     array = create<array_t>();
   11647        9139 :                     break;
   11648             :                 }
   11649             : 
   11650          20 :                 case value_t::string:
   11651             :                 {
   11652          20 :                     string = create<string_t>("");
   11653          20 :                     break;
   11654             :                 }
   11655             : 
   11656          18 :                 case value_t::boolean:
   11657             :                 {
   11658          18 :                     boolean = boolean_t(false);
   11659          18 :                     break;
   11660             :                 }
   11661             : 
   11662          20 :                 case value_t::number_integer:
   11663             :                 {
   11664          20 :                     number_integer = number_integer_t(0);
   11665          20 :                     break;
   11666             :                 }
   11667             : 
   11668          17 :                 case value_t::number_unsigned:
   11669             :                 {
   11670          17 :                     number_unsigned = number_unsigned_t(0);
   11671          17 :                     break;
   11672             :                 }
   11673             : 
   11674          20 :                 case value_t::number_float:
   11675             :                 {
   11676          20 :                     number_float = number_float_t(0.0);
   11677          20 :                     break;
   11678             :                 }
   11679             : 
   11680    12276320 :                 case value_t::null:
   11681             :                 {
   11682    12276320 :                     object = nullptr;  // silence warning, see #821
   11683    12276320 :                     break;
   11684             :                 }
   11685             : 
   11686         626 :                 default:
   11687             :                 {
   11688         626 :                     object = nullptr;  // silence warning, see #821
   11689         626 :                     if (JSON_UNLIKELY(t == value_t::null))
   11690             :                     {
   11691             :                         JSON_THROW(other_error::create(500, "961c151d2e87f2686a955a9be24d316f1362bf21 3.1.2")); // LCOV_EXCL_LINE
   11692             :                     }
   11693         626 :                     break;
   11694             :                 }
   11695             :             }
   11696    12294235 :         }
   11697             : 
   11698             :         /// constructor for strings
   11699    33517768 :         json_value(const string_t& value)
   11700             :         {
   11701    33517768 :             string = create<string_t>(value);
   11702    33517768 :         }
   11703             : 
   11704             :         /// constructor for rvalue strings
   11705        1613 :         json_value(string_t&& value)
   11706             :         {
   11707        1613 :             string = create<string_t>(std::move(value));
   11708        1612 :         }
   11709             : 
   11710             :         /// constructor for objects
   11711        5703 :         json_value(const object_t& value)
   11712             :         {
   11713        5703 :             object = create<object_t>(value);
   11714        5703 :         }
   11715             : 
   11716             :         /// constructor for rvalue objects
   11717           8 :         json_value(object_t&& value)
   11718             :         {
   11719           8 :             object = create<object_t>(std::move(value));
   11720           8 :         }
   11721             : 
   11722             :         /// constructor for arrays
   11723        6926 :         json_value(const array_t& value)
   11724             :         {
   11725        6926 :             array = create<array_t>(value);
   11726        6926 :         }
   11727             : 
   11728             :         /// constructor for rvalue arrays
   11729           8 :         json_value(array_t&& value)
   11730             :         {
   11731           8 :             array = create<array_t>(std::move(value));
   11732           8 :         }
   11733             : 
   11734   159693635 :         void destroy(value_t t) noexcept
   11735             :         {
   11736   159693635 :             switch (t)
   11737             :             {
   11738       13802 :                 case value_t::object:
   11739             :                 {
   11740       27604 :                     AllocatorType<object_t> alloc;
   11741       13802 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, object);
   11742       13802 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, object, 1);
   11743       13802 :                     break;
   11744             :                 }
   11745             : 
   11746       17585 :                 case value_t::array:
   11747             :                 {
   11748       35170 :                     AllocatorType<array_t> alloc;
   11749       17585 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, array);
   11750       17585 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, array, 1);
   11751       17585 :                     break;
   11752             :                 }
   11753             : 
   11754    33519394 :                 case value_t::string:
   11755             :                 {
   11756    67038788 :                     AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   11757    33519394 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, string);
   11758    33519394 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, string, 1);
   11759    33519394 :                     break;
   11760             :                 }
   11761             : 
   11762   126142854 :                 default:
   11763             :                 {
   11764   126142854 :                     break;
   11765             :                 }
   11766             :             }
   11767   159693635 :         }
   11768             :     };
   11769             : 
   11770             :     /*!
   11771             :     @brief checks the class invariants
   11772             : 
   11773             :     This function asserts the class invariants. It needs to be called at the
   11774             :     end of every constructor to make sure that created objects respect the
   11775             :     invariant. Furthermore, it has to be called each time the type of a JSON
   11776             :     value is changed, because the invariant expresses a relationship between
   11777             :     @a m_type and @a m_value.
   11778             :     */
   11779   488218498 :     void assert_invariant() const noexcept
   11780             :     {
   11781   488218498 :         assert(m_type != value_t::object or m_value.object != nullptr);
   11782   488218498 :         assert(m_type != value_t::array or m_value.array != nullptr);
   11783   488218498 :         assert(m_type != value_t::string or m_value.string != nullptr);
   11784   488218498 :     }
   11785             : 
   11786             :   public:
   11787             :     //////////////////////////
   11788             :     // JSON parser callback //
   11789             :     //////////////////////////
   11790             : 
   11791             :     /*!
   11792             :     @brief parser event types
   11793             : 
   11794             :     The parser callback distinguishes the following events:
   11795             :     - `object_start`: the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object
   11796             :     - `key`: the parser read a key of a value in an object
   11797             :     - `object_end`: the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object
   11798             :     - `array_start`: the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array
   11799             :     - `array_end`: the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array
   11800             :     - `value`: the parser finished reading a JSON value
   11801             : 
   11802             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are triggered"
   11803             : 
   11804             :     @sa @ref parser_callback_t for more information and examples
   11805             :     */
   11806             :     using parse_event_t = typename parser::parse_event_t;
   11807             : 
   11808             :     /*!
   11809             :     @brief per-element parser callback type
   11810             : 
   11811             :     With a parser callback function, the result of parsing a JSON text can be
   11812             :     influenced. When passed to @ref parse, it is called on certain events
   11813             :     (passed as @ref parse_event_t via parameter @a event) with a set recursion
   11814             :     depth @a depth and context JSON value @a parsed. The return value of the
   11815             :     callback function is a boolean indicating whether the element that emitted
   11816             :     the callback shall be kept or not.
   11817             : 
   11818             :     We distinguish six scenarios (determined by the event type) in which the
   11819             :     callback function can be called. The following table describes the values
   11820             :     of the parameters @a depth, @a event, and @a parsed.
   11821             : 
   11822             :     parameter @a event | description | parameter @a depth | parameter @a parsed
   11823             :     ------------------ | ----------- | ------------------ | -------------------
   11824             :     parse_event_t::object_start | the parser read `{` and started to process a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | a JSON value with type discarded
   11825             :     parse_event_t::key | the parser read a key of a value in an object | depth of the currently parsed JSON object | a JSON string containing the key
   11826             :     parse_event_t::object_end | the parser read `}` and finished processing a JSON object | depth of the parent of the JSON object | the parsed JSON object
   11827             :     parse_event_t::array_start | the parser read `[` and started to process a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | a JSON value with type discarded
   11828             :     parse_event_t::array_end | the parser read `]` and finished processing a JSON array | depth of the parent of the JSON array | the parsed JSON array
   11829             :     parse_event_t::value | the parser finished reading a JSON value | depth of the value | the parsed JSON value
   11830             : 
   11831             :     @image html callback_events.png "Example when certain parse events are triggered"
   11832             : 
   11833             :     Discarding a value (i.e., returning `false`) has different effects
   11834             :     depending on the context in which function was called:
   11835             : 
   11836             :     - Discarded values in structured types are skipped. That is, the parser
   11837             :       will behave as if the discarded value was never read.
   11838             :     - In case a value outside a structured type is skipped, it is replaced
   11839             :       with `null`. This case happens if the top-level element is skipped.
   11840             : 
   11841             :     @param[in] depth  the depth of the recursion during parsing
   11842             : 
   11843             :     @param[in] event  an event of type parse_event_t indicating the context in
   11844             :     the callback function has been called
   11845             : 
   11846             :     @param[in,out] parsed  the current intermediate parse result; note that
   11847             :     writing to this value has no effect for parse_event_t::key events
   11848             : 
   11849             :     @return Whether the JSON value which called the function during parsing
   11850             :     should be kept (`true`) or not (`false`). In the latter case, it is either
   11851             :     skipped completely or replaced by an empty discarded object.
   11852             : 
   11853             :     @sa @ref parse for examples
   11854             : 
   11855             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11856             :     */
   11857             :     using parser_callback_t = typename parser::parser_callback_t;
   11858             : 
   11859             :     using json_sax_t = typename parser::json_sax_t;
   11860             : 
   11861             :     //////////////////
   11862             :     // constructors //
   11863             :     //////////////////
   11864             : 
   11865             :     /// @name constructors and destructors
   11866             :     /// Constructors of class @ref basic_json, copy/move constructor, copy
   11867             :     /// assignment, static functions creating objects, and the destructor.
   11868             :     /// @{
   11869             : 
   11870             :     /*!
   11871             :     @brief create an empty value with a given type
   11872             : 
   11873             :     Create an empty JSON value with a given type. The value will be default
   11874             :     initialized with an empty value which depends on the type:
   11875             : 
   11876             :     Value type  | initial value
   11877             :     ----------- | -------------
   11878             :     null        | `null`
   11879             :     boolean     | `false`
   11880             :     string      | `""`
   11881             :     number      | `0`
   11882             :     object      | `{}`
   11883             :     array       | `[]`
   11884             : 
   11885             :     @param[in] v  the type of the value to create
   11886             : 
   11887             :     @complexity Constant.
   11888             : 
   11889             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   11890             :     changes to any JSON value.
   11891             : 
   11892             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor for different @ref
   11893             :     value_t values,basic_json__value_t}
   11894             : 
   11895             :     @sa @ref clear() -- restores the postcondition of this constructor
   11896             : 
   11897             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11898             :     */
   11899    12293727 :     basic_json(const value_t v)
   11900    12293727 :         : m_type(v), m_value(v)
   11901             :     {
   11902    12293726 :         assert_invariant();
   11903    12293726 :     }
   11904             : 
   11905             :     /*!
   11906             :     @brief create a null object
   11907             : 
   11908             :     Create a `null` JSON value. It either takes a null pointer as parameter
   11909             :     (explicitly creating `null`) or no parameter (implicitly creating `null`).
   11910             :     The passed null pointer itself is not read -- it is only used to choose
   11911             :     the right constructor.
   11912             : 
   11913             :     @complexity Constant.
   11914             : 
   11915             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
   11916             :     exceptions.
   11917             : 
   11918             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with and without a
   11919             :     null pointer parameter.,basic_json__nullptr_t}
   11920             : 
   11921             :     @since version 1.0.0
   11922             :     */
   11923    12276278 :     basic_json(std::nullptr_t = nullptr) noexcept
   11924    12276278 :         : basic_json(value_t::null)
   11925             :     {
   11926    12276278 :         assert_invariant();
   11927    12276278 :     }
   11928             : 
   11929             :     /*!
   11930             :     @brief create a JSON value
   11931             : 
   11932             :     This is a "catch all" constructor for all compatible JSON types; that is,
   11933             :     types for which a `to_json()` method exists. The constructor forwards the
   11934             :     parameter @a val to that method (to `json_serializer<U>::to_json` method
   11935             :     with `U = uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`, to be exact).
   11936             : 
   11937             :     Template type @a CompatibleType includes, but is not limited to, the
   11938             :     following types:
   11939             :     - **arrays**: @ref array_t and all kinds of compatible containers such as
   11940             :       `std::vector`, `std::deque`, `std::list`, `std::forward_list`,
   11941             :       `std::array`, `std::valarray`, `std::set`, `std::unordered_set`,
   11942             :       `std::multiset`, and `std::unordered_multiset` with a `value_type` from
   11943             :       which a @ref basic_json value can be constructed.
   11944             :     - **objects**: @ref object_t and all kinds of compatible associative
   11945             :       containers such as `std::map`, `std::unordered_map`, `std::multimap`,
   11946             :       and `std::unordered_multimap` with a `key_type` compatible to
   11947             :       @ref string_t and a `value_type` from which a @ref basic_json value can
   11948             :       be constructed.
   11949             :     - **strings**: @ref string_t, string literals, and all compatible string
   11950             :       containers can be used.
   11951             :     - **numbers**: @ref number_integer_t, @ref number_unsigned_t,
   11952             :       @ref number_float_t, and all convertible number types such as `int`,
   11953             :       `size_t`, `int64_t`, `float` or `double` can be used.
   11954             :     - **boolean**: @ref boolean_t / `bool` can be used.
   11955             : 
   11956             :     See the examples below.
   11957             : 
   11958             :     @tparam CompatibleType a type such that:
   11959             :     - @a CompatibleType is not derived from `std::istream`,
   11960             :     - @a CompatibleType is not @ref basic_json (to avoid hijacking copy/move
   11961             :          constructors),
   11962             :     - @a CompatibleType is not a different @ref basic_json type (i.e. with different template arguments)
   11963             :     - @a CompatibleType is not a @ref basic_json nested type (e.g.,
   11964             :          @ref json_pointer, @ref iterator, etc ...)
   11965             :     - @ref @ref json_serializer<U> has a
   11966             :          `to_json(basic_json_t&, CompatibleType&&)` method
   11967             : 
   11968             :     @tparam U = `uncvref_t<CompatibleType>`
   11969             : 
   11970             :     @param[in] val the value to be forwarded to the respective constructor
   11971             : 
   11972             :     @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
   11973             :                 depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
   11974             :                 method.
   11975             : 
   11976             :     @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
   11977             :     supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
   11978             :     was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
   11979             :     no changes to any JSON value.
   11980             : 
   11981             :     @liveexample{The following code shows the constructor with several
   11982             :     compatible types.,basic_json__CompatibleType}
   11983             : 
   11984             :     @since version 2.1.0
   11985             :     */
   11986             :     template <typename CompatibleType,
   11987             :               typename U = detail::uncvref_t<CompatibleType>,
   11988             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   11989             :                   detail::is_compatible_type<basic_json_t, U>::value, int> = 0>
   11990    49743756 :     basic_json(CompatibleType && val) noexcept(noexcept(
   11991             :                 JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(std::declval<basic_json_t&>(),
   11992             :                                            std::forward<CompatibleType>(val))))
   11993    49743756 :     {
   11994    49743756 :         JSONSerializer<U>::to_json(*this, std::forward<CompatibleType>(val));
   11995    49743755 :         assert_invariant();
   11996    49743755 :     }
   11997             : 
   11998             :     /*!
   11999             :     @brief create a JSON value from an existing one
   12000             : 
   12001             :     This is a constructor for existing @ref basic_json types.
   12002             :     It does not hijack copy/move constructors, since the parameter has different
   12003             :     template arguments than the current ones.
   12004             : 
   12005             :     The constructor tries to convert the internal @ref m_value of the parameter.
   12006             : 
   12007             :     @tparam BasicJsonType a type such that:
   12008             :     - @a BasicJsonType is a @ref basic_json type.
   12009             :     - @a BasicJsonType has different template arguments than @ref basic_json_t.
   12010             : 
   12011             :     @param[in] val the @ref basic_json value to be converted.
   12012             : 
   12013             :     @complexity Usually linear in the size of the passed @a val, also
   12014             :                 depending on the implementation of the called `to_json()`
   12015             :                 method.
   12016             : 
   12017             :     @exceptionsafety Depends on the called constructor. For types directly
   12018             :     supported by the library (i.e., all types for which no `to_json()` function
   12019             :     was provided), strong guarantee holds: if an exception is thrown, there are
   12020             :     no changes to any JSON value.
   12021             : 
   12022             :     @since version 3.1.2
   12023             :     */
   12024             :     template <typename BasicJsonType,
   12025             :               detail::enable_if_t<
   12026             :                   detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value and not std::is_same<basic_json, BasicJsonType>::value, int> = 0>
   12027          20 :     basic_json(const BasicJsonType& val)
   12028          20 :     {
   12029             :         using other_boolean_t = typename BasicJsonType::boolean_t;
   12030             :         using other_number_float_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_float_t;
   12031             :         using other_number_integer_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_integer_t;
   12032             :         using other_number_unsigned_t = typename BasicJsonType::number_unsigned_t;
   12033             :         using other_string_t = typename BasicJsonType::string_t;
   12034             :         using other_object_t = typename BasicJsonType::object_t;
   12035             :         using other_array_t = typename BasicJsonType::array_t;
   12036             : 
   12037          20 :         switch (val.type())
   12038             :         {
   12039           1 :             case value_t::boolean:
   12040           1 :                 JSONSerializer<other_boolean_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_boolean_t>());
   12041           1 :                 break;
   12042           1 :             case value_t::number_float:
   12043           1 :                 JSONSerializer<other_number_float_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_float_t>());
   12044           1 :                 break;
   12045           6 :             case value_t::number_integer:
   12046           6 :                 JSONSerializer<other_number_integer_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_integer_t>());
   12047           6 :                 break;
   12048           4 :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   12049           4 :                 JSONSerializer<other_number_unsigned_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get<other_number_unsigned_t>());
   12050           4 :                 break;
   12051           2 :             case value_t::string:
   12052           2 :                 JSONSerializer<other_string_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_string_t&>());
   12053           2 :                 break;
   12054           2 :             case value_t::object:
   12055           2 :                 JSONSerializer<other_object_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_object_t&>());
   12056           2 :                 break;
   12057           2 :             case value_t::array:
   12058           2 :                 JSONSerializer<other_array_t>::to_json(*this, val.template get_ref<const other_array_t&>());
   12059           2 :                 break;
   12060           1 :             case value_t::null:
   12061           1 :                 *this = nullptr;
   12062           1 :                 break;
   12063           1 :             case value_t::discarded:
   12064           1 :                 m_type = value_t::discarded;
   12065           1 :                 break;
   12066             :         }
   12067          20 :         assert_invariant();
   12068          20 :     }
   12069             : 
   12070             :     /*!
   12071             :     @brief create a container (array or object) from an initializer list
   12072             : 
   12073             :     Creates a JSON value of type array or object from the passed initializer
   12074             :     list @a init. In case @a type_deduction is `true` (default), the type of
   12075             :     the JSON value to be created is deducted from the initializer list @a init
   12076             :     according to the following rules:
   12077             : 
   12078             :     1. If the list is empty, an empty JSON object value `{}` is created.
   12079             :     2. If the list consists of pairs whose first element is a string, a JSON
   12080             :        object value is created where the first elements of the pairs are
   12081             :        treated as keys and the second elements are as values.
   12082             :     3. In all other cases, an array is created.
   12083             : 
   12084             :     The rules aim to create the best fit between a C++ initializer list and
   12085             :     JSON values. The rationale is as follows:
   12086             : 
   12087             :     1. The empty initializer list is written as `{}` which is exactly an empty
   12088             :        JSON object.
   12089             :     2. C++ has no way of describing mapped types other than to list a list of
   12090             :        pairs. As JSON requires that keys must be of type string, rule 2 is the
   12091             :        weakest constraint one can pose on initializer lists to interpret them
   12092             :        as an object.
   12093             :     3. In all other cases, the initializer list could not be interpreted as
   12094             :        JSON object type, so interpreting it as JSON array type is safe.
   12095             : 
   12096             :     With the rules described above, the following JSON values cannot be
   12097             :     expressed by an initializer list:
   12098             : 
   12099             :     - the empty array (`[]`): use @ref array(initializer_list_t)
   12100             :       with an empty initializer list in this case
   12101             :     - arrays whose elements satisfy rule 2: use @ref
   12102             :       array(initializer_list_t) with the same initializer list
   12103             :       in this case
   12104             : 
   12105             :     @note When used without parentheses around an empty initializer list, @ref
   12106             :     basic_json() is called instead of this function, yielding the JSON null
   12107             :     value.
   12108             : 
   12109             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values
   12110             : 
   12111             :     @param[in] type_deduction internal parameter; when set to `true`, the type
   12112             :     of the JSON value is deducted from the initializer list @a init; when set
   12113             :     to `false`, the type provided via @a manual_type is forced. This mode is
   12114             :     used by the functions @ref array(initializer_list_t) and
   12115             :     @ref object(initializer_list_t).
   12116             : 
   12117             :     @param[in] manual_type internal parameter; when @a type_deduction is set
   12118             :     to `false`, the created JSON value will use the provided type (only @ref
   12119             :     value_t::array and @ref value_t::object are valid); when @a type_deduction
   12120             :     is set to `true`, this parameter has no effect
   12121             : 
   12122             :     @throw type_error.301 if @a type_deduction is `false`, @a manual_type is
   12123             :     `value_t::object`, but @a init contains an element which is not a pair
   12124             :     whose first element is a string. In this case, the constructor could not
   12125             :     create an object. If @a type_deduction would have be `true`, an array
   12126             :     would have been created. See @ref object(initializer_list_t)
   12127             :     for an example.
   12128             : 
   12129             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
   12130             : 
   12131             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12132             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12133             : 
   12134             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values are created from
   12135             :     initializer lists.,basic_json__list_init_t}
   12136             : 
   12137             :     @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
   12138             :     value from an initializer list
   12139             :     @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
   12140             :     value from an initializer list
   12141             : 
   12142             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12143             :     */
   12144        1914 :     basic_json(initializer_list_t init,
   12145             :                bool type_deduction = true,
   12146             :                value_t manual_type = value_t::array)
   12147        1914 :     {
   12148             :         // check if each element is an array with two elements whose first
   12149             :         // element is a string
   12150        1914 :         bool is_an_object = std::all_of(init.begin(), init.end(),
   12151        2308 :                                         [](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref)
   12152             :         {
   12153        2308 :             return (element_ref->is_array() and element_ref->size() == 2 and (*element_ref)[0].is_string());
   12154        2308 :         });
   12155             : 
   12156             :         // adjust type if type deduction is not wanted
   12157        1914 :         if (not type_deduction)
   12158             :         {
   12159             :             // if array is wanted, do not create an object though possible
   12160         119 :             if (manual_type == value_t::array)
   12161             :             {
   12162          28 :                 is_an_object = false;
   12163             :             }
   12164             : 
   12165             :             // if object is wanted but impossible, throw an exception
   12166         119 :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(manual_type == value_t::object and not is_an_object))
   12167             :             {
   12168           1 :                 JSON_THROW(type_error::create(301, "cannot create object from initializer list"));
   12169             :             }
   12170             :         }
   12171             : 
   12172        1913 :         if (is_an_object)
   12173             :         {
   12174             :             // the initializer list is a list of pairs -> create object
   12175         454 :             m_type = value_t::object;
   12176         454 :             m_value = value_t::object;
   12177             : 
   12178        1311 :             std::for_each(init.begin(), init.end(), [this](const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& element_ref)
   12179         857 :             {
   12180        1714 :                 auto element = element_ref.moved_or_copied();
   12181        1714 :                 m_value.object->emplace(
   12182         857 :                     std::move(*((*element.m_value.array)[0].m_value.string)),
   12183         857 :                     std::move((*element.m_value.array)[1]));
   12184         857 :             });
   12185             :         }
   12186             :         else
   12187             :         {
   12188             :             // the initializer list describes an array -> create array
   12189        1459 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   12190        1459 :             m_value.array = create<array_t>(init.begin(), init.end());
   12191             :         }
   12192             : 
   12193        1913 :         assert_invariant();
   12194        1913 :     }
   12195             : 
   12196             :     /*!
   12197             :     @brief explicitly create an array from an initializer list
   12198             : 
   12199             :     Creates a JSON array value from a given initializer list. That is, given a
   12200             :     list of values `a, b, c`, creates the JSON value `[a, b, c]`. If the
   12201             :     initializer list is empty, the empty array `[]` is created.
   12202             : 
   12203             :     @note This function is only needed to express two edge cases that cannot
   12204             :     be realized with the initializer list constructor (@ref
   12205             :     basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t)). These cases
   12206             :     are:
   12207             :     1. creating an array whose elements are all pairs whose first element is a
   12208             :     string -- in this case, the initializer list constructor would create an
   12209             :     object, taking the first elements as keys
   12210             :     2. creating an empty array -- passing the empty initializer list to the
   12211             :     initializer list constructor yields an empty object
   12212             : 
   12213             :     @param[in] init  initializer list with JSON values to create an array from
   12214             :     (optional)
   12215             : 
   12216             :     @return JSON array value
   12217             : 
   12218             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
   12219             : 
   12220             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12221             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12222             : 
   12223             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `array`
   12224             :     function.,array}
   12225             : 
   12226             :     @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
   12227             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
   12228             :     @sa @ref object(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON object
   12229             :     value from an initializer list
   12230             : 
   12231             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12232             :     */
   12233          28 :     static basic_json array(initializer_list_t init = {})
   12234             :     {
   12235          28 :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::array);
   12236             :     }
   12237             : 
   12238             :     /*!
   12239             :     @brief explicitly create an object from an initializer list
   12240             : 
   12241             :     Creates a JSON object value from a given initializer list. The initializer
   12242             :     lists elements must be pairs, and their first elements must be strings. If
   12243             :     the initializer list is empty, the empty object `{}` is created.
   12244             : 
   12245             :     @note This function is only added for symmetry reasons. In contrast to the
   12246             :     related function @ref array(initializer_list_t), there are
   12247             :     no cases which can only be expressed by this function. That is, any
   12248             :     initializer list @a init can also be passed to the initializer list
   12249             :     constructor @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t).
   12250             : 
   12251             :     @param[in] init  initializer list to create an object from (optional)
   12252             : 
   12253             :     @return JSON object value
   12254             : 
   12255             :     @throw type_error.301 if @a init is not a list of pairs whose first
   12256             :     elements are strings. In this case, no object can be created. When such a
   12257             :     value is passed to @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t),
   12258             :     an array would have been created from the passed initializer list @a init.
   12259             :     See example below.
   12260             : 
   12261             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a init.
   12262             : 
   12263             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12264             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12265             : 
   12266             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the `object`
   12267             :     function.,object}
   12268             : 
   12269             :     @sa @ref basic_json(initializer_list_t, bool, value_t) --
   12270             :     create a JSON value from an initializer list
   12271             :     @sa @ref array(initializer_list_t) -- create a JSON array
   12272             :     value from an initializer list
   12273             : 
   12274             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12275             :     */
   12276          91 :     static basic_json object(initializer_list_t init = {})
   12277             :     {
   12278          91 :         return basic_json(init, false, value_t::object);
   12279             :     }
   12280             : 
   12281             :     /*!
   12282             :     @brief construct an array with count copies of given value
   12283             : 
   12284             :     Constructs a JSON array value by creating @a cnt copies of a passed value.
   12285             :     In case @a cnt is `0`, an empty array is created.
   12286             : 
   12287             :     @param[in] cnt  the number of JSON copies of @a val to create
   12288             :     @param[in] val  the JSON value to copy
   12289             : 
   12290             :     @post `std::distance(begin(),end()) == cnt` holds.
   12291             : 
   12292             :     @complexity Linear in @a cnt.
   12293             : 
   12294             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12295             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12296             : 
   12297             :     @liveexample{The following code shows examples for the @ref
   12298             :     basic_json(size_type\, const basic_json&)
   12299             :     constructor.,basic_json__size_type_basic_json}
   12300             : 
   12301             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12302             :     */
   12303          14 :     basic_json(size_type cnt, const basic_json& val)
   12304          14 :         : m_type(value_t::array)
   12305             :     {
   12306          14 :         m_value.array = create<array_t>(cnt, val);
   12307          14 :         assert_invariant();
   12308          14 :     }
   12309             : 
   12310             :     /*!
   12311             :     @brief construct a JSON container given an iterator range
   12312             : 
   12313             :     Constructs the JSON value with the contents of the range `[first, last)`.
   12314             :     The semantics depends on the different types a JSON value can have:
   12315             :     - In case of a null type, invalid_iterator.206 is thrown.
   12316             :     - In case of other primitive types (number, boolean, or string), @a first
   12317             :       must be `begin()` and @a last must be `end()`. In this case, the value is
   12318             :       copied. Otherwise, invalid_iterator.204 is thrown.
   12319             :     - In case of structured types (array, object), the constructor behaves as
   12320             :       similar versions for `std::vector` or `std::map`; that is, a JSON array
   12321             :       or object is constructed from the values in the range.
   12322             : 
   12323             :     @tparam InputIT an input iterator type (@ref iterator or @ref
   12324             :     const_iterator)
   12325             : 
   12326             :     @param[in] first begin of the range to copy from (included)
   12327             :     @param[in] last end of the range to copy from (excluded)
   12328             : 
   12329             :     @pre Iterators @a first and @a last must be initialized. **This
   12330             :          precondition is enforced with an assertion (see warning).** If
   12331             :          assertions are switched off, a violation of this precondition yields
   12332             :          undefined behavior.
   12333             : 
   12334             :     @pre Range `[first, last)` is valid. Usually, this precondition cannot be
   12335             :          checked efficiently. Only certain edge cases are detected; see the
   12336             :          description of the exceptions below. A violation of this precondition
   12337             :          yields undefined behavior.
   12338             : 
   12339             :     @warning A precondition is enforced with a runtime assertion that will
   12340             :              result in calling `std::abort` if this precondition is not met.
   12341             :              Assertions can be disabled by defining `NDEBUG` at compile time.
   12342             :              See http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/error/assert for more
   12343             :              information.
   12344             : 
   12345             :     @throw invalid_iterator.201 if iterators @a first and @a last are not
   12346             :     compatible (i.e., do not belong to the same JSON value). In this case,
   12347             :     the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
   12348             :     @throw invalid_iterator.204 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
   12349             :     primitive type (number, boolean, or string), but @a first does not point
   12350             :     to the first element any more. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is
   12351             :     undefined. See example code below.
   12352             :     @throw invalid_iterator.206 if iterators @a first and @a last belong to a
   12353             :     null value. In this case, the range `[first, last)` is undefined.
   12354             : 
   12355             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a first and @a last.
   12356             : 
   12357             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12358             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12359             : 
   12360             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several ways to create JSON values by
   12361             :     specifying a subrange with iterators.,basic_json__InputIt_InputIt}
   12362             : 
   12363             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12364             :     */
   12365             :     template<class InputIT, typename std::enable_if<
   12366             :                  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   12367             :                  std::is_same<InputIT, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type = 0>
   12368          51 :     basic_json(InputIT first, InputIT last)
   12369          51 :     {
   12370          51 :         assert(first.m_object != nullptr);
   12371          51 :         assert(last.m_object != nullptr);
   12372             : 
   12373             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   12374          51 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(first.m_object != last.m_object))
   12375             :         {
   12376           8 :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(201, "iterators are not compatible"));
   12377             :         }
   12378             : 
   12379             :         // copy type from first iterator
   12380          43 :         m_type = first.m_object->m_type;
   12381             : 
   12382             :         // check if iterator range is complete for primitive values
   12383          43 :         switch (m_type)
   12384             :         {
   12385          30 :             case value_t::boolean:
   12386             :             case value_t::number_float:
   12387             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   12388             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   12389             :             case value_t::string:
   12390             :             {
   12391          30 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()
   12392             :                                   or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
   12393             :                 {
   12394          20 :                     JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
   12395             :                 }
   12396          10 :                 break;
   12397             :             }
   12398             : 
   12399          13 :             default:
   12400          13 :                 break;
   12401             :         }
   12402             : 
   12403          23 :         switch (m_type)
   12404             :         {
   12405           2 :             case value_t::number_integer:
   12406             :             {
   12407           2 :                 m_value.number_integer = first.m_object->m_value.number_integer;
   12408           2 :                 break;
   12409             :             }
   12410             : 
   12411           2 :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   12412             :             {
   12413           2 :                 m_value.number_unsigned = first.m_object->m_value.number_unsigned;
   12414           2 :                 break;
   12415             :             }
   12416             : 
   12417           2 :             case value_t::number_float:
   12418             :             {
   12419           2 :                 m_value.number_float = first.m_object->m_value.number_float;
   12420           2 :                 break;
   12421             :             }
   12422             : 
   12423           2 :             case value_t::boolean:
   12424             :             {
   12425           2 :                 m_value.boolean = first.m_object->m_value.boolean;
   12426           2 :                 break;
   12427             :             }
   12428             : 
   12429           2 :             case value_t::string:
   12430             :             {
   12431           2 :                 m_value = *first.m_object->m_value.string;
   12432           2 :                 break;
   12433             :             }
   12434             : 
   12435           5 :             case value_t::object:
   12436             :             {
   12437           5 :                 m_value.object = create<object_t>(first.m_it.object_iterator,
   12438             :                                                   last.m_it.object_iterator);
   12439           5 :                 break;
   12440             :             }
   12441             : 
   12442           6 :             case value_t::array:
   12443             :             {
   12444           6 :                 m_value.array = create<array_t>(first.m_it.array_iterator,
   12445             :                                                 last.m_it.array_iterator);
   12446           6 :                 break;
   12447             :             }
   12448             : 
   12449           2 :             default:
   12450           2 :                 JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(206, "cannot construct with iterators from " +
   12451             :                                                     std::string(first.m_object->type_name())));
   12452             :         }
   12453             : 
   12454          21 :         assert_invariant();
   12455          21 :     }
   12456             : 
   12457             :

   12462             :     /// @private
   12463        3910 :     basic_json(const detail::json_ref<basic_json>& ref)

   12465        3910 :     {}
   12466             : 
   12467             :     /*!
   12468             :     @brief copy constructor
   12469             : 
   12470             :     Creates a copy of a given JSON value.
   12471             : 
   12472             :     @param[in] other  the JSON value to copy
   12473             : 
   12474             :     @post `*this == other`
   12475             : 
   12476             :     @complexity Linear in the size of @a other.
   12477             : 
   12478             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12479             :     changes to any JSON value.
   12480             : 
   12481             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12482             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   12483             :     requirements:
   12484             :     - The complexity is linear.
   12485             :     - As postcondition, it holds: `other == basic_json(other)`.
   12486             : 
   12487             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for the copy
   12488             :     constructor.,basic_json__basic_json}

   12549             :     /*!
   12550             :     @brief move constructor
   12551             : 
   12552             :     Move constructor. Constructs a JSON value with the contents of the given
   12553             :     value @a other using move semantics. It "steals" the resources from @a
   12554             :     other and leaves it as JSON null value.
   12555             : 
   12556             :     @param[in,out] other  value to move to this object
   12557             : 
   12558             :     @post `*this` has the same value as @a other before the call.
   12559             :     @post @a other is a JSON null value.
   12560             : 
   12561             :     @complexity Constant.
   12562             : 
   12563             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this constructor never throws
   12564             :     exceptions.
   12565             : 
   12566             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12567             :     [MoveConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/MoveConstructible)
   12568             :     requirements.
   12569             : 
   12570             :     @liveexample{The code below shows the move constructor explicitly called
   12571             :     via std::move.,basic_json__moveconstructor}
   12572             : 
   12573             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12574             :     */
   12575    65177293 :     basic_json(basic_json&& other) noexcept
   12576    65177293 :         : m_type(std::move(other.m_type)),
   12577    65177293 :           m_value(std::move(other.m_value))
   12578             :     {
   12579             :         // check that passed value is valid
   12580    65177293 :         other.assert_invariant();
   12581             : 
   12582             :         // invalidate payload
   12583    65177293 :         other.m_type = value_t::null;
   12584    65177293 :         other.m_value = {};
   12585             : 
   12586    65177293 :         assert_invariant();
   12587    65177293 :     }

   12589             :     /*!
   12590             :     @brief copy assignment
   12591             : 
   12592             :     Copy assignment operator. Copies a JSON value via the "copy and swap"
   12593             :     strategy: It is expressed in terms of the copy constructor, destructor,
   12594             :     and the `swap()` member function.
   12595             : 
   12596             :     @param[in] other  value to copy from
   12597             : 
   12598             :     @complexity Linear.
   12599             : 
   12600             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   12601             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   12602             :     requirements:
   12603             :     - The complexity is linear.
   12604             : 
   12605             :     @liveexample{The code below shows and example for the copy assignment. It
   12606             :     creates a copy of value `a` which is then swapped with `b`. Finally\, the
   12607             :     copy of `a` (which is the null value after the swap) is
   12608             :     destroyed.,basic_json__copyassignment}
   12609             : 
   12610             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12611             :     */
   12612     3465585 :     reference& operator=(basic_json other) noexcept (
   12613             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
   12614             :         std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
   12615             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
   12616             :         std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value
   12617             :     )
   12618             :     {
   12619             :         // check that passed value is valid
   12620     3465585 :         other.assert_invariant();
   12621             : 
   12622             :         using std::swap;
   12623     3465585 :         swap(m_type, other.m_type);
   12624     3465585 :         swap(m_value, other.m_value);

   12659             :     /// Functions to inspect the type of a JSON value.
   12660             :     /// @{
   12661             : 
   12662             :     /*!
   12663             :     @brief serialization
   12664             : 
   12665             :     Serialization function for JSON values. The function tries to mimic
   12666             :     Python's `json.dumps()` function, and currently supports its @a indent
   12667             :     and @a ensure_ascii parameters.
   12668             : 
   12669             :     @param[in] indent If indent is nonnegative, then array elements and object
   12670             :     members will be pretty-printed with that indent level. An indent level of
   12671             :     `0` will only insert newlines. `-1` (the default) selects the most compact
   12672             :     representation.
   12673             :     @param[in] indent_char The character to use for indentation if @a indent is
   12674             :     greater than `0`. The default is ` ` (space).
   12675             :     @param[in] ensure_ascii If @a ensure_ascii is true, all non-ASCII characters
   12676             :     in the output are escaped with `\uXXXX` sequences, and the result consists
   12677             :     of ASCII characters only.
   12678             : 
   12679             :     @return string containing the serialization of the JSON value
   12680             : 
   12681             :     @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
   12682             :                           UTF-8 encoded
   12683             : 
   12684             :     @complexity Linear.
   12685             : 
   12686             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   12687             :     changes in the JSON value.
   12688             : 
   12689             :     @liveexample{The following example shows the effect of different @a indent\,
   12690             :     @a indent_char\, and @a ensure_ascii parameters to the result of the
   12691             :     serialization.,dump}
   12692             : 
   12693             :     @see https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump
   12694             : 
   12695             :     @since version 1.0.0; indentation character @a indent_char, option
   12696             :            @a ensure_ascii and exceptions added in version 3.0.0
   12697             :     */
   12698         312 :     string_t dump(const int indent = -1, const char indent_char = ' ',
   12699             :                   const bool ensure_ascii = false) const
   12700             :     {
   12701         312 :         string_t result;
   12702         559 :         serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char, string_t>(result), indent_char);
   12703             : 
   12704         312 :         if (indent >= 0)
   12705             :         {
   12706           9 :             s.dump(*this, true, ensure_ascii, static_cast<unsigned int>(indent));
   12707             :         }
   12708             :         else
   12709             :         {
   12710         303 :             s.dump(*this, false, ensure_ascii, 0);
   12711             :         }
   12712             : 
   12713         494 :         return result;
   12714             :     }
   12715             : 
   12716             :     /*!
   12717             :     @brief return the type of the JSON value (explicit)
   12718             : 
   12719             :     Return the type of the JSON value as a value from the @ref value_t
   12720             :     enumeration.
   12721             : 
   12722             :     @return the type of the JSON value
   12723             :             Value type                | return value
   12724             :             ------------------------- | -------------------------
   12725             :             null                      | value_t::null
   12726             :             boolean                   | value_t::boolean
   12727             :             string                    | value_t::string
   12728             :             number (integer)          | value_t::number_integer
   12729             :             number (unsigned integer) | value_t::number_unsigned
   12730             :             number (floating-point)   | value_t::number_float
   12731             :             object                    | value_t::object
   12732             :             array                     | value_t::array
   12733             :             discarded                 | value_t::discarded
   12734             : 
   12735             :     @complexity Constant.
   12736             : 
   12737             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12738             :     exceptions.
   12739             : 
   12740             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type()` for all JSON
   12741             :     types.,type}
   12742             : 
   12743             :     @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
   12744             :     @sa @ref type_name() -- return the type as string
   12745             :

   12747             :     */

   12753             :     /*!
   12754             :     @brief return whether type is primitive
   12755             : 
   12756             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is primitive
   12757             :     (string, number, boolean, or null).
   12758             : 
   12759             :     @return `true` if type is primitive (string, number, boolean, or null),
   12760             :     `false` otherwise.
   12761             : 
   12762             :     @complexity Constant.
   12763             : 
   12764             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12765             :     exceptions.
   12766             : 
   12767             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_primitive()` for all JSON
   12768             :     types.,is_primitive}
   12769             : 
   12770             :     @sa @ref is_structured() -- returns whether JSON value is structured
   12771             :     @sa @ref is_null() -- returns whether JSON value is `null`
   12772             :     @sa @ref is_string() -- returns whether JSON value is a string
   12773             :     @sa @ref is_boolean() -- returns whether JSON value is a boolean
   12774             :     @sa @ref is_number() -- returns whether JSON value is a number
   12775             : 
   12776             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12777             :     */
   12778          81 :     constexpr bool is_primitive() const noexcept
   12779             :     {
   12780          81 :         return is_null() or is_string() or is_boolean() or is_number();
   12781             :     }
   12782             : 
   12783             :     /*!
   12784             :     @brief return whether type is structured
   12785             : 
   12786             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON type is structured
   12787             :     (array or object).
   12788             : 
   12789             :     @return `true` if type is structured (array or object), `false` otherwise.
   12790             : 
   12791             :     @complexity Constant.
   12792             : 
   12793             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12794             :     exceptions.
   12795             : 
   12796             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_structured()` for all JSON
   12797             :     types.,is_structured}
   12798             : 
   12799             :     @sa @ref is_primitive() -- returns whether value is primitive
   12800             :     @sa @ref is_array() -- returns whether value is an array
   12801             :     @sa @ref is_object() -- returns whether value is an object
   12802             : 
   12803             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12804             :     */
   12805           9 :     constexpr bool is_structured() const noexcept
   12806             :     {
   12807           9 :         return is_array() or is_object();
   12808             :     }
   12809             : 
   12810             :     /*!
   12811             :     @brief return whether value is null
   12812             : 
   12813             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is null.
   12814             : 
   12815             :     @return `true` if type is null, `false` otherwise.
   12816             : 
   12817             :     @complexity Constant.
   12818             : 
   12819             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12820             :     exceptions.
   12821             : 
   12822             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `is_null()` for all JSON
   12823             :     types.,is_null}
   12824             : 
   12825             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12826             :     */
   12827      269259 :     constexpr bool is_null() const noexcept
   12828             :     {
   12829      269259 :         return (m_type == value_t::null);
   12830             :     }
   12831             : 
   12832             :     /*!
   12833             :     @brief return whether value is a boolean
   12834             : 
   12835             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a boolean.
   12836             : 
   12837             :     @return `true` if type is boolean, `false` otherwise.
   12838             : 
   12839             :     @complexity Constant.
   12840             : 
   12841             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12842             :     exceptions.
   12843             :

   12845             :     types.,is_boolean}
   12846             :

   12848             :     */
   12849         229 :     constexpr bool is_boolean() const noexcept
   12850             :     {
   12851         229 :         return (m_type == value_t::boolean);
   12852             :     }
   12853             : 
   12854             :     /*!
   12855             :     @brief return whether value is a number
   12856             : 
   12857             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value is a number. This
   12858             :     includes both integer (signed and unsigned) and floating-point values.
   12859             : 
   12860             :     @return `true` if type is number (regardless whether integer, unsigned
   12861             :     integer or floating-type), `false` otherwise.
   12862             : 
   12863             :     @complexity Constant.
   12864             : 
   12865             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this member function never throws
   12866             :     exceptions.
   12867             :

   12869             :     types.,is_number}
   12870             : 
   12871             :     @sa @ref is_number_integer() -- check if value is an integer or unsigned
   12872             :     integer number
   12873             :     @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
   12874             :     number
   12875             :     @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
   12876             : 
   12877             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12878             :     */

   12880             :     {
   12881          77 :         return is_number_integer() or is_number_float();
   12882             :     }

   12888             :     unsigned integer number. This excludes floating-point values.

   12891             :     otherwise.

   12896             :     exceptions.

   12899             :     JSON types.,is_number_integer}

   12902             :     @sa @ref is_number_unsigned() -- check if value is an unsigned integer
   12903             :     number
   12904             :     @sa @ref is_number_float() -- check if value is a floating-point number
   12905             : 
   12906             :     @since version 1.0.0
   12907             :     */

   13035             :     /*!
   13036             :     @brief return whether value is discarded
   13037             : 
   13038             :     This function returns true if and only if the JSON value was discarded
   13039             :     during parsing with a callback function (see @ref parser_callback_t).
   13040             : 
   13041             :     @note This function will always be `false` for JSON values after parsing.
   13042             :     That is, discarded values can only occur during parsing, but will be
   13043             :     removed when inside a structured value or replaced by null in other cases.
   13044             : 
   13045             :     @return `true` if type is discarded, `false` otherwise.
   13046             : 
   13047             :     @complexity Constant.

   13050             :     exceptions.
