   13186             :     {
   13187         169 :         return is_number_float() ? &m_value.number_float : nullptr;
   13188             :     }
   13189             : 
   13190             :     /*!
   13191             :     @brief helper function to implement get_ref()
   13192             : 
   13193             :     This function helps to implement get_ref() without code duplication for
   13194             :     const and non-const overloads
   13195             : 
   13196             :     @tparam ThisType will be deduced as `basic_json` or `const basic_json`
   13197             : 
   13198             :     @throw type_error.303 if ReferenceType does not match underlying value
   13199             :     type of the current JSON
   13200             :     */
   13201             :     template<typename ReferenceType, typename ThisType>
   13202      163941 :     static ReferenceType get_ref_impl(ThisType& obj)
   13203             :     {
   13204             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr<>()
   13205      163941 :         auto ptr = obj.template get_ptr<typename std::add_pointer<ReferenceType>::type>();
   13206             : 
   13207      163941 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(ptr != nullptr))
   13208             :         {
   13209      327798 :             return *ptr;
   13210             :         }
   13211             : 
   13212          42 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(303, "incompatible ReferenceType for get_ref, actual type is " + std::string(obj.type_name())));
   13213             :     }
   13214             : 
   13215             :   public:
   13216             :     /// @name value access
   13217             :     /// Direct access to the stored value of a JSON value.
   13218             :     /// @{
   13219             : 
   13220             :     /*!
   13221             :     @brief get special-case overload
   13222             : 
   13223             :     This overloads avoids a lot of template boilerplate, it can be seen as the
   13224             :     identity method
   13225             : 
   13226             :     @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
   13227             : 
   13228             :     @return a copy of *this
   13229             : 
   13230             :     @complexity Constant.
   13231             : 
   13232             :     @since version 2.1.0
   13233             :     */
   13234             :     template<typename BasicJsonType, detail::enable_if_t<
   13235             :                  std::is_same<typename std::remove_const<BasicJsonType>::type, basic_json_t>::value,
   13236             :                  int> = 0>
   13237         120 :     basic_json get() const
   13238             :     {
   13239         120 :         return *this;
   13240             :     }
   13241             : 
   13242             :     /*!
   13243             :     @brief get special-case overload
   13244             : 
   13245             :     This overloads converts the current @ref basic_json in a different
   13246             :     @ref basic_json type
   13247             : 
   13248             :     @tparam BasicJsonType == @ref basic_json
   13249             : 
   13250             :     @return a copy of *this, converted into @tparam BasicJsonType
   13251             : 
   13252             :     @complexity Depending on the implementation of the called `from_json()`
   13253             :                 method.
   13254             : 
   13255             :     @since version 3.1.2
   13256             :     */
   13257             :     template<typename BasicJsonType, detail::enable_if_t<
   13258             :                  not std::is_same<BasicJsonType, basic_json>::value and
   13259             :                  detail::is_basic_json<BasicJsonType>::value, int> = 0>
   13260           1 :     BasicJsonType get() const
   13261             :     {
   13262           1 :         return *this;
   13263             :     }
   13264             : 
   13265             :     /*!
   13266             :     @brief get a value (explicit)
   13267             : 
   13268             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
   13269             :     which is [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
   13270             :     and [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
   13271             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
   13272             :     `from_json()` method.
   13273             : 
   13274             :     The function is equivalent to executing
   13275             :     @code {.cpp}
   13276             :     ValueType ret;
   13277             :     JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
   13278             :     return ret;
   13279             :     @endcode
   13280             : 
   13281             :     This overloads is chosen if:
   13282             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json,
   13283             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
   13284             :       `void from_json(const basic_json&, ValueType&)`, and
   13285             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> does not have a `from_json()` method of
   13286             :       the form `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
   13287             : 
   13288             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
   13289             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
   13290             : 
   13291             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
   13292             : 
   13293             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
   13294             : 
   13295             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
   13296             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
   13297             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
   13298             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
   13299             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
   13300             :     json>`.,get__ValueType_const}
   13301             : 
   13302             :     @since version 2.1.0
   13303             :     */
   13304             :     template<typename ValueTypeCV, typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
   13305             :              detail::enable_if_t <
   13306             :                  not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value and
   13307             :                  detail::has_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
   13308             :                  not detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
   13309             :                  int> = 0>
   13310     1113532 :     ValueType get() const noexcept(noexcept(
   13311             :                                        JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>(), std::declval<ValueType&>())))
   13312             :     {
   13313             :         // we cannot static_assert on ValueTypeCV being non-const, because
   13314             :         // there is support for get<const basic_json_t>(), which is why we
   13315             :         // still need the uncvref
   13316             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
   13317             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might want to use get_ref()");
   13318             :         static_assert(std::is_default_constructible<ValueType>::value,
   13319             :                       "types must be DefaultConstructible when used with get()");
   13320             : 
   13321     1112965 :         ValueType ret;
   13322     1113532 :         JSONSerializer<ValueType>::from_json(*this, ret);
   13323     1113479 :         return ret;
   13324             :     }
   13325             : 
   13326             :     /*!
   13327             :     @brief get a value (explicit); special case
   13328             : 
   13329             :     Explicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value
   13330             :     which is **not** [CopyConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/CopyConstructible)
   13331             :     and **not** [DefaultConstructible](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/DefaultConstructible).
   13332             :     The value is converted by calling the @ref json_serializer<ValueType>
   13333             :     `from_json()` method.
   13334             : 
   13335             :     The function is equivalent to executing
   13336             :     @code {.cpp}
   13337             :     return JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(*this);
   13338             :     @endcode
   13339             : 
   13340             :     This overloads is chosen if:
   13341             :     - @a ValueType is not @ref basic_json and
   13342             :     - @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has a `from_json()` method of the form
   13343             :       `ValueType from_json(const basic_json&)`
   13344             : 
   13345             :     @note If @ref json_serializer<ValueType> has both overloads of
   13346             :     `from_json()`, this one is chosen.
   13347             : 
   13348             :     @tparam ValueTypeCV the provided value type
   13349             :     @tparam ValueType the returned value type
   13350             : 
   13351             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to @a ValueType
   13352             : 
   13353             :     @throw what @ref json_serializer<ValueType> `from_json()` method throws
   13354             : 
   13355             :     @since version 2.1.0
   13356             :     */
   13357             :     template<typename ValueTypeCV, typename ValueType = detail::uncvref_t<ValueTypeCV>,
   13358             :              detail::enable_if_t<not std::is_same<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value and
   13359             :                                  detail::has_non_default_from_json<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value,
   13360             :                                  int> = 0>
   13361           3 :     ValueType get() const noexcept(noexcept(
   13362             :                                        JSONSerializer<ValueTypeCV>::from_json(std::declval<const basic_json_t&>())))
   13363             :     {
   13364             :         static_assert(not std::is_reference<ValueTypeCV>::value,
   13365             :                       "get() cannot be used with reference types, you might want to use get_ref()");

   13367             :     }
   13368             : 
   13369             :     /*!
   13370             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
   13371             : 
   13372             :     Explicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
   13373             :     made.
   13374             : 
   13375             :     @warning The pointer becomes invalid if the underlying JSON object
   13376             :     changes.
   13377             : 
   13378             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
   13379             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
   13380             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t.
   13381             : 
   13382             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
   13383             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
   13384             : 
   13385             :     @complexity Constant.
   13386             : 
   13387             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
   13388             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
   13389             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
   13390             :     match.,get__PointerType}
   13391             : 
   13392             :     @sa @ref get_ptr() for explicit pointer-member access
   13393             : 
   13394             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13395             :     */
   13396             :     template<typename PointerType, typename std::enable_if<
   13397             :                  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   13398             :     PointerType get() noexcept
   13399             :     {
   13400             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
   13401             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();
   13402             :     }

   13405             :     @brief get a pointer value (explicit)
   13406             :     @copydoc get()

   13409             :                  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>

   13412             :         // delegate the call to get_ptr
   13413             :         return get_ptr<PointerType>();

   13415             : 
   13416             :     /*!
   13417             :     @brief get a pointer value (implicit)
   13418             : 
   13419             :     Implicit pointer access to the internally stored JSON value. No copies are
   13420             :     made.
   13421             : 
   13422             :     @warning Writing data to the pointee of the result yields an undefined
   13423             :     state.
   13424             : 
   13425             :     @tparam PointerType pointer type; must be a pointer to @ref array_t, @ref
   13426             :     object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t,
   13427             :     @ref number_unsigned_t, or @ref number_float_t. Enforced by a static
   13428             :     assertion.
   13429             : 
   13430             :     @return pointer to the internally stored JSON value if the requested
   13431             :     pointer type @a PointerType fits to the JSON value; `nullptr` otherwise
   13432             : 
   13433             :     @complexity Constant.
   13434             : 
   13435             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how pointers to internal values of a
   13436             :     JSON value can be requested. Note that no type conversions are made and a
   13437             :     `nullptr` is returned if the value and the requested pointer type does not
   13438             :     match.,get_ptr}
   13439             : 
   13440             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13441             :     */

   13443             :                  std::is_pointer<PointerType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   13444      164039 :     PointerType get_ptr() noexcept

   13446             :         // get the type of the PointerType (remove pointer and const)
   13447             :         using pointee_t = typename std::remove_const<typename
   13448             :                           std::remove_pointer<typename
   13449             :                           std::remove_const<PointerType>::type>::type>::type;

   13451             :         static_assert(

   13458             :             or std::is_same<number_float_t, pointee_t>::value

   13493             :     /*!
   13494             :     @brief get a reference value (implicit)
   13495             :

   13497             :     are made.
   13498             : 
   13499             :     @warning Writing data to the referee of the result yields an undefined
   13500             :     state.
   13501             :

   13503             :     @ref object_t, @ref string_t, @ref boolean_t, @ref number_integer_t, or
   13504             :     @ref number_float_t. Enforced by static assertion.

   13507             :     reference type @a ReferenceType fits to the JSON value; throws
   13508             :     type_error.303 otherwise
   13509             :

   13511             :     with the stored JSON value; see example below

   13513             :     @complexity Constant.
   13514             : 
   13515             :     @liveexample{The example shows several calls to `get_ref()`.,get_ref}
   13516             : 
   13517             :     @since version 1.1.0
   13518             :     */

   13520             :                  std::is_reference<ReferenceType>::value, int>::type = 0>

   13539             : 
   13540             :     /*!
   13541             :     @brief get a value (implicit)
   13542             : 
   13543             :     Implicit type conversion between the JSON value and a compatible value.
   13544             :     The call is realized by calling @ref get() const.
   13545             : 
   13546             :     @tparam ValueType non-pointer type compatible to the JSON value, for
   13547             :     instance `int` for JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or
   13548             :     `std::vector` types for JSON arrays. The character type of @ref string_t
   13549             :     as well as an initializer list of this type is excluded to avoid
   13550             :     ambiguities as these types implicitly convert to `std::string`.
   13551             : 
   13552             :     @return copy of the JSON value, converted to type @a ValueType
   13553             : 
   13554             :     @throw type_error.302 in case passed type @a ValueType is incompatible
   13555             :     to the JSON value type (e.g., the JSON value is of type boolean, but a
   13556             :     string is requested); see example below
   13557             : 
   13558             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
   13559             : 
   13560             :     @liveexample{The example below shows several conversions from JSON values
   13561             :     to other types. There a few things to note: (1) Floating-point numbers can
   13562             :     be converted to integers\, (2) A JSON array can be converted to a standard
   13563             :     `std::vector<short>`\, (3) A JSON object can be converted to C++
   13564             :     associative containers such as `std::unordered_map<std::string\,
   13565             :     json>`.,operator__ValueType}
   13566             : 
   13567             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13568             :     */
   13569             :     template < typename ValueType, typename std::enable_if <
   13570             :                    not std::is_pointer<ValueType>::value and
   13571             :                    not std::is_same<ValueType, detail::json_ref<basic_json>>::value and
   13572             :                    not std::is_same<ValueType, typename string_t::value_type>::value and
   13573             :                    not detail::is_basic_json<ValueType>::value
   13574             : #ifndef _MSC_VER  // fix for issue #167 operator<< ambiguity under VS2015
   13575             :                    and not std::is_same<ValueType, std::initializer_list<typename string_t::value_type>>::value
   13576             : #endif
   13577             : #if defined(JSON_HAS_CPP_17)
   13578             :                    and not std::is_same<ValueType, typename std::string_view>::value
   13579             : #endif
   13580             :                    , int >::type = 0 >
   13581     1112696 :     operator ValueType() const
   13582             :     {
   13583             :         // delegate the call to get<>() const
   13584     1112696 :         return get<ValueType>();
   13585             :     }
   13586             : 
   13587             :     /// @}
   13588             :

   13590             :     ////////////////////
   13591             :     // element access //

   13593             : 
   13594             :     /// @name element access
   13595             :     /// Access to the JSON value.
   13596             :     /// @{
   13597             : 
   13598             :     /*!
   13599             :     @brief access specified array element with bounds checking
   13600             : 
   13601             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx, with
   13602             :     bounds checking.
   13603             : 
   13604             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13605             : 
   13606             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
   13607             : 
   13608             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an array; in this case,
   13609             :     calling `at` with an index makes no sense. See example below.
   13610             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if the index @a idx is out of range of the array;
   13611             :     that is, `idx >= size()`. See example below.
   13612             : 
   13613             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13614             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13615             : 
   13616             :     @complexity Constant.
   13617             : 
   13618             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13619             : 
   13620             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
   13621             :     written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
   13622             :     can be thrown.,at__size_type}
   13623             :     */
   13624          53 :     reference at(size_type idx)
   13625             :     {
   13626             :         // at only works for arrays
   13627          53 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13628             :         {

   13630             :             {

   13634             :             {

   13636           4 :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));

   13638             :         }
   13639             :         else
   13640             :         {

   13692             :     /*!
   13693             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
   13694             : 
   13695             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key, with
   13696             :     bounds checking.
   13697             : 
   13698             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13699             : 
   13700             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
   13701             : 
   13702             :     @throw type_error.304 if the JSON value is not an object; in this case,
   13703             :     calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
   13704             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
   13705             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
   13706             : 
   13707             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13708             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13709             : 
   13710             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13711             : 
   13712             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
   13713             :     access by reference
   13714             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13715             : 
   13716             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13717             : 
   13718             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
   13719             :     written using `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that
   13720             :     can be thrown.,at__object_t_key_type}
   13721             :     */
   13722         176 :     reference at(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   13723             :     {
   13724             :         // at only works for objects
   13725         176 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))

   13727             :             JSON_TRY

   13729         326 :                 return m_value.object->at(key);
   13730             :             }

   13732             :             {
   13733             :                 // create better exception explanation
   13734          12 :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
   13735             :             }
   13736             :         }
   13737             :         else
   13738             :         {
   13739           7 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   13740             :         }
   13741             :     }
   13742             : 
   13743             :     /*!
   13744             :     @brief access specified object element with bounds checking
   13745             : 
   13746             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified key @a key,
   13747             :     with bounds checking.
   13748             : 
   13749             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13750             : 
   13751             :     @return const reference to the element at key @a key

   13754             :     calling `at` with a key makes no sense. See example below.
   13755             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the key @a key is is not stored in the object;
   13756             :     that is, `find(key) == end()`. See example below.
   13757             : 
   13758             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   13759             :     changes in the JSON value.
   13760             : 
   13761             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13762             :

   13764             :     access by reference

   13766             :

   13770             :     `at()`. It also demonstrates the different exceptions that can be thrown.,
   13771             :     at__object_t_key_type_const}

   13774             :     {

   13783             :             {

   13785          16 :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(403, "key '" + key + "' not found"));
   13786             :             }
   13787             :         }
   13788             :         else
   13789             :         {
   13790           7 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(304, "cannot use at() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   13791             :         }
   13792             :     }
   13793             : 
   13794             :     /*!
   13795             :     @brief access specified array element
   13796             : 
   13797             :     Returns a reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
   13798             : 
   13799             :     @note If @a idx is beyond the range of the array (i.e., `idx >= size()`),
   13800             :     then the array is silently filled up with `null` values to make `idx` a
   13801             :     valid reference to the last stored element.
   13802             : 
   13803             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13804             : 
   13805             :     @return reference to the element at index @a idx
   13806             : 
   13807             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array or null; in that
   13808             :     cases, using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
   13809             : 
   13810             :     @complexity Constant if @a idx is in the range of the array. Otherwise
   13811             :     linear in `idx - size()`.
   13812             : 
   13813             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read and
   13814             :     written using `[]` operator. Note the addition of `null`
   13815             :     values.,operatorarray__size_type}
   13816             : 
   13817             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13818             :     */
   13819        5303 :     reference operator[](size_type idx)
   13820             :     {
   13821             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty array
   13822        5303 :         if (is_null())
   13823             :         {
   13824           5 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   13825           5 :             m_value.array = create<array_t>();
   13826           5 :             assert_invariant();
   13827             :         }
   13828             : 
   13829             :         // operator[] only works for arrays
   13830        5303 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13831             :         {
   13832             :             // fill up array with null values if given idx is outside range
   13833        5297 :             if (idx >= m_value.array->size())
   13834             :             {
   13835          34 :                 m_value.array->insert(m_value.array->end(),
   13836          17 :                                       idx - m_value.array->size() + 1,
   13837             :                                       basic_json());
   13838             :             }
   13839             : 
   13840       10594 :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
   13841             :         }
   13842             : 
   13843           6 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with " + std::string(type_name())));
   13844             :     }
   13845             : 
   13846             :     /*!
   13847             :     @brief access specified array element
   13848             : 
   13849             :     Returns a const reference to the element at specified location @a idx.
   13850             : 
   13851             :     @param[in] idx  index of the element to access
   13852             : 
   13853             :     @return const reference to the element at index @a idx
   13854             : 
   13855             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an array; in that case,
   13856             :     using the [] operator with an index makes no sense.
   13857             : 
   13858             :     @complexity Constant.
   13859             : 
   13860             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how array elements can be read using
   13861             :     the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__size_type_const}
   13862             : 
   13863             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13864             :     */
   13865         942 :     const_reference operator[](size_type idx) const
   13866             :     {
   13867             :         // const operator[] only works for arrays
   13868         942 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   13869             :         {
   13870        1870 :             return m_value.array->operator[](idx);
   13871             :         }
   13872             : 
   13873           7 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(305, "cannot use operator[] with " + std::string(type_name())));
   13874             :     }
   13875             : 
   13876             :     /*!
   13877             :     @brief access specified object element
   13878             : 
   13879             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified key @a key.
   13880             : 
   13881             :     @note If @a key is not found in the object, then it is silently added to
   13882             :     the object and filled with a `null` value to make `key` a valid reference.
   13883             :     In case the value was `null` before, it is converted to an object.
   13884             : 
   13885             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   13886             : 
   13887             :     @return reference to the element at key @a key
   13888             : 
   13889             :     @throw type_error.305 if the JSON value is not an object or null; in that
   13890             :     cases, using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.
   13891             : 
   13892             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   13893             : 
   13894             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be read and
   13895             :     written using the `[]` operator.,operatorarray__key_type}
   13896             : 
   13897             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
   13898             :     with range checking
   13899             :     @sa @ref value() for access by value with a default value
   13900             : 
   13901             :     @since version 1.0.0
   13902             :     */
   13903         215 :     reference operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   13904             :     {
   13905             :         // implicitly convert null value to an empty object
   13906         215 :         if (is_null())

   13917             :         }

   13922             :     /*!
   13923             :     @brief read-only access specified object element

   13929             :     undefined.

   13936             :          enforced with an assertion.**

   13939             :     using the [] operator with a key makes no sense.

   13947             :     with range checking

   14053             : 
   14054             :     /*!
   14055             :     @brief access specified object element with default value
   14056             : 
   14057             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
   14058             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
   14059             : 
   14060             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
   14061             :     @code {.cpp}
   14062             :     try {
   14063             :         return at(key);
   14064             :     } catch(out_of_range) {
   14065             :         return default_value;
   14066             :     }
   14067             :     @endcode
   14068             : 
   14069             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&), this function
   14070             :     does not throw if the given key @a key was not found.
   14071             : 
   14072             :     @note Unlike @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type& key), this
   14073             :     function does not implicitly add an element to the position defined by @a
   14074             :     key. This function is furthermore also applicable to const objects.
   14075             : 
   14076             :     @param[in] key  key of the element to access
   14077             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a key is not found
   14078             : 
   14079             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
   14080             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
   14081             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
   14082             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
   14083             : 
   14084             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
   14085             :     is not found
   14086             : 
   14087             :     @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
   14088             :     using `value()` with a key makes no sense.
   14089             : 
   14090             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container.
   14091             : 
   14092             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
   14093             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value}
   14094             : 
   14095             :     @sa @ref at(const typename object_t::key_type&) for access by reference
   14096             :     with range checking
   14097             :     @sa @ref operator[](const typename object_t::key_type&) for unchecked
   14098             :     access by reference
   14099             : 
   14100             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14101             :     */
   14102             :     template<class ValueType, typename std::enable_if<
   14103             :                  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   14104         227 :     ValueType value(const typename object_t::key_type& key, const ValueType& default_value) const
   14105             :     {
   14106             :         // at only works for objects
   14107         227 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   14108             :         {
   14109             :             // if key is found, return value and given default value otherwise
   14110         213 :             const auto it = find(key);
   14111         213 :             if (it != end())
   14112             :             {
   14113          93 :                 return *it;
   14114             :             }
   14115             : 
   14116         120 :             return default_value;
   14117             :         }
   14118             : 
   14119          14 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(306, "cannot use value() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   14120             :     }
   14121             : 
   14122             :     /*!
   14123             :     @brief overload for a default value of type const char*

   14125             :     */

   14130             : 
   14131             :     /*!
   14132             :     @brief access specified object element via JSON Pointer with default value
   14133             : 
   14134             :     Returns either a copy of an object's element at the specified key @a key
   14135             :     or a given default value if no element with key @a key exists.
   14136             : 
   14137             :     The function is basically equivalent to executing
   14138             :     @code {.cpp}
   14139             :     try {
   14140             :         return at(ptr);
   14141             :     } catch(out_of_range) {
   14142             :         return default_value;
   14143             :     }
   14144             :     @endcode
   14145             : 
   14146             :     @note Unlike @ref at(const json_pointer&), this function does not throw
   14147             :     if the given key @a key was not found.
   14148             : 
   14149             :     @param[in] ptr  a JSON pointer to the element to access
   14150             :     @param[in] default_value  the value to return if @a ptr found no value
   14151             : 
   14152             :     @tparam ValueType type compatible to JSON values, for instance `int` for
   14153             :     JSON integer numbers, `bool` for JSON booleans, or `std::vector` types for
   14154             :     JSON arrays. Note the type of the expected value at @a key and the default
   14155             :     value @a default_value must be compatible.
   14156             : 
   14157             :     @return copy of the element at key @a key or @a default_value if @a key
   14158             :     is not found

   14160             :     @throw type_error.306 if the JSON value is not an object; in that case,
   14161             :     using `value()` with a key makes no sense.

   14164             : 
   14165             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how object elements can be queried
   14166             :     with a default value.,basic_json__value_ptr}
   14167             : 
   14168             :     @sa @ref operator[](const json_pointer&) for unchecked access by reference
   14169             : 
   14170             :     @since version 2.0.2
   14171             :     */
   14172             :     template<class ValueType, typename std::enable_if<
   14173             :                  std::is_convertible<basic_json_t, ValueType>::value, int>::type = 0>

   14176             :         // at only works for objects

   14179             :             // if pointer resolves a value, return it or use default value
   14180             :             JSON_TRY

   14187             :             }

   14191             :     }
   14192             : 
   14193             :     /*!

   14201             : 
   14202             :     /*!
   14203             :     @brief access the first element
   14204             : 
   14205             :     Returns a reference to the first element in the container. For a JSON
   14206             :     container `c`, the expression `c.front()` is equivalent to `*c.begin()`.
   14207             : 
   14208             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
   14209             :     first element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
   14210             :     reference to the value is returned.
   14211             : 
   14212             :     @complexity Constant.
   14213             : 
   14214             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
   14215             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
   14216             :     assertions**).
   14217             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
   14218             : 
   14219             :     @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on `null` value
   14220             : 
   14221             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `front()`.,front}
   14222             : 
   14223             :     @sa @ref back() -- access the last element
   14224             : 
   14225             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14226             :     */
   14227           8 :     reference front()
   14228             :     {
   14229           8 :         return *begin();
   14230             :     }
   14231             : 
   14232             :     /*!
   14233             :     @copydoc basic_json::front()
   14234             :     */
   14235          47 :     const_reference front() const
   14236             :     {
   14237          47 :         return *cbegin();
   14238             :     }
   14239             : 
   14240             :     /*!
   14241             :     @brief access the last element
   14242             : 
   14243             :     Returns a reference to the last element in the container. For a JSON
   14244             :     container `c`, the expression `c.back()` is equivalent to
   14245             :     @code {.cpp}
   14246             :     auto tmp = c.end();
   14247             :     --tmp;
   14248             :     return *tmp;
   14249             :     @endcode
   14250             : 
   14251             :     @return In case of a structured type (array or object), a reference to the
   14252             :     last element is returned. In case of number, string, or boolean values, a
   14253             :     reference to the value is returned.
   14254             : 
   14255             :     @complexity Constant.
   14256             : 
   14257             :     @pre The JSON value must not be `null` (would throw `std::out_of_range`)
   14258             :     or an empty array or object (undefined behavior, **guarded by
   14259             :     assertions**).
   14260             :     @post The JSON value remains unchanged.
   14261             : 
   14262             :     @throw invalid_iterator.214 when called on a `null` value. See example
   14263             :     below.
   14264             : 
   14265             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `back()`.,back}
   14266             : 
   14267             :     @sa @ref front() -- access the first element
   14268             : 
   14269             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14270             :     */
   14271           8 :     reference back()
   14272             :     {
   14273           8 :         auto tmp = end();
   14274           8 :         --tmp;
   14275           8 :         return *tmp;
   14276             :     }
   14277             : 
   14278             :     /*!
   14279             :     @copydoc basic_json::back()
   14280             :     */
   14281           8 :     const_reference back() const
   14282             :     {
   14283           8 :         auto tmp = cend();
   14284           8 :         --tmp;
   14285           8 :         return *tmp;
   14286             :     }
   14287             : 
   14288             :     /*!
   14289             :     @brief remove element given an iterator
   14290             : 
   14291             :     Removes the element specified by iterator @a pos. The iterator @a pos must
   14292             :     be valid and dereferenceable. Thus the `end()` iterator (which is valid,
   14293             :     but is not dereferenceable) cannot be used as a value for @a pos.
   14294             : 
   14295             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
   14296             :     will be `null`.
   14297             : 
   14298             :     @param[in] pos iterator to the element to remove
   14299             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
   14300             :     pos refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
   14301             : 
   14302             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
   14303             : 
   14304             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
   14305             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
   14306             : 
   14307             :     @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
   14308             :     erase() with null"`
   14309             :     @throw invalid_iterator.202 if called on an iterator which does not belong
   14310             :     to the current JSON value; example: `"iterator does not fit current
   14311             :     value"`
   14312             :     @throw invalid_iterator.205 if called on a primitive type with invalid
   14313             :     iterator (i.e., any iterator which is not `begin()`); example: `"iterator
   14314             :     out of range"`
   14315             : 
   14316             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
   14317             :     - objects: amortized constant
   14318             :     - arrays: linear in distance between @a pos and the end of the container
   14319             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
   14320             :     - other types: constant
   14321             : 
   14322             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
   14323             :     types.,erase__IteratorType}
   14324             : 
   14325             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   14326             :     the given range
   14327             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   14328             :     from an object at the given key
   14329             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   14330             :     the given index
   14331             : 
   14332             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14333             :     */
   14334             :     template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
   14335             :                  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   14336             :                  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type
   14337             :              = 0>
   14338          67 :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType pos)
   14339             :     {
   14340             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   14341          67 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != pos.m_object))
   14342             :         {
   14343           4 :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterator does not fit current value"));
   14344             :         }
   14345             : 
   14346          63 :         IteratorType result = end();
   14347             : 
   14348          63 :         switch (m_type)
   14349             :         {
   14350          20 :             case value_t::boolean:
   14351             :             case value_t::number_float:
   14352             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   14353             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   14354             :             case value_t::string:
   14355             :             {
   14356          20 :                 if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not pos.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()))
   14357             :                 {
   14358          10 :                     JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(205, "iterator out of range"));
   14359             :                 }
   14360             : 
   14361          10 :                 if (is_string())
   14362             :                 {
   14363           4 :                     AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   14364           2 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, m_value.string);
   14365           2 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, m_value.string, 1);
   14366           2 :                     m_value.string = nullptr;
   14367             :                 }
   14368             : 
   14369          10 :                 m_type = value_t::null;
   14370          10 :                 assert_invariant();
   14371          10 :                 break;
   14372             :             }
   14373             : 
   14374          37 :             case value_t::object:
   14375             :             {
   14376          37 :                 result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(pos.m_it.object_iterator);
   14377          37 :                 break;
   14378             :             }
   14379             : 
   14380           4 :             case value_t::array:
   14381             :             {
   14382           4 :                 result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(pos.m_it.array_iterator);
   14383           4 :                 break;
   14384             :             }
   14385             : 
   14386           2 :             default:
   14387           2 :                 JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   14388             :         }
   14389             : 
   14390          51 :         return result;
   14391             :     }
   14392             : 
   14393             :     /*!
   14394             :     @brief remove elements given an iterator range
   14395             : 
   14396             :     Removes the element specified by the range `[first; last)`. The iterator
   14397             :     @a first does not need to be dereferenceable if `first == last`: erasing
   14398             :     an empty range is a no-op.
   14399             : 
   14400             :     If called on a primitive type other than `null`, the resulting JSON value
   14401             :     will be `null`.
   14402             : 
   14403             :     @param[in] first iterator to the beginning of the range to remove
   14404             :     @param[in] last iterator past the end of the range to remove
   14405             :     @return Iterator following the last removed element. If the iterator @a
   14406             :     second refers to the last element, the `end()` iterator is returned.
   14407             : 
   14408             :     @tparam IteratorType an @ref iterator or @ref const_iterator
   14409             : 
   14410             :     @post Invalidates iterators and references at or after the point of the
   14411             :     erase, including the `end()` iterator.
   14412             : 
   14413             :     @throw type_error.307 if called on a `null` value; example: `"cannot use
   14414             :     erase() with null"`
   14415             :     @throw invalid_iterator.203 if called on iterators which does not belong
   14416             :     to the current JSON value; example: `"iterators do not fit current value"`
   14417             :     @throw invalid_iterator.204 if called on a primitive type with invalid
   14418             :     iterators (i.e., if `first != begin()` and `last != end()`); example:
   14419             :     `"iterators out of range"`
   14420             : 
   14421             :     @complexity The complexity depends on the type:
   14422             :     - objects: `log(size()) + std::distance(first, last)`
   14423             :     - arrays: linear in the distance between @a first and @a last, plus linear
   14424             :       in the distance between @a last and end of the container
   14425             :     - strings: linear in the length of the string
   14426             :     - other types: constant
   14427             : 
   14428             :     @liveexample{The example shows the result of `erase()` for different JSON
   14429             :     types.,erase__IteratorType_IteratorType}
   14430             : 
   14431             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   14432             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   14433             :     from an object at the given key
   14434             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   14435             :     the given index
   14436             : 
   14437             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14438             :     */
   14439             :     template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
   14440             :                  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::iterator>::value or
   14441             :                  std::is_same<IteratorType, typename basic_json_t::const_iterator>::value, int>::type
   14442             :              = 0>
   14443          56 :     IteratorType erase(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
   14444             :     {
   14445             :         // make sure iterator fits the current value
   14446          56 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(this != first.m_object or this != last.m_object))
   14447             :         {
   14448          12 :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(203, "iterators do not fit current value"));
   14449             :         }
   14450             : 
   14451          44 :         IteratorType result = end();
   14452             : 
   14453          44 :         switch (m_type)
   14454             :         {
   14455          30 :             case value_t::boolean:
   14456             :             case value_t::number_float:
   14457             :             case value_t::number_integer:
   14458             :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   14459             :             case value_t::string:
   14460             :             {
   14461          30 :                 if (JSON_LIKELY(not first.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_begin()
   14462             :                                 or not last.m_it.primitive_iterator.is_end()))
   14463             :                 {
   14464          20 :                     JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(204, "iterators out of range"));
   14465             :                 }
   14466             : 
   14467          10 :                 if (is_string())
   14468             :                 {
   14469           4 :                     AllocatorType<string_t> alloc;
   14470           2 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::destroy(alloc, m_value.string);
   14471           2 :                     std::allocator_traits<decltype(alloc)>::deallocate(alloc, m_value.string, 1);
   14472           2 :                     m_value.string = nullptr;
   14473             :                 }
   14474             : 
   14475          10 :                 m_type = value_t::null;
   14476          10 :                 assert_invariant();
   14477          10 :                 break;
   14478             :             }
   14479             : 
   14480           6 :             case value_t::object:
   14481             :             {
   14482           6 :                 result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->erase(first.m_it.object_iterator,
   14483             :                                               last.m_it.object_iterator);
   14484           6 :                 break;
   14485             :             }
   14486             : 
   14487           6 :             case value_t::array:
   14488             :             {
   14489           6 :                 result.m_it.array_iterator = m_value.array->erase(first.m_it.array_iterator,
   14490             :                                              last.m_it.array_iterator);
   14491           6 :                 break;
   14492             :             }
   14493             : 
   14494           2 :             default:
   14495           2 :                 JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   14496             :         }
   14497             : 
   14498          22 :         return result;
   14499             :     }
   14500             : 
   14501             :     /*!
   14502             :     @brief remove element from a JSON object given a key
   14503             : 
   14504             :     Removes elements from a JSON object with the key value @a key.
   14505             : 
   14506             :     @param[in] key value of the elements to remove
   14507             : 
   14508             :     @return Number of elements removed. If @a ObjectType is the default
   14509             :     `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was not
   14510             :     found) or `1` (@a key was found).
   14511             : 
   14512             :     @post References and iterators to the erased elements are invalidated.
   14513             :     Other references and iterators are not affected.
   14514             : 
   14515             :     @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
   14516             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
   14517             : 
   14518             :     @complexity `log(size()) + count(key)`
   14519             : 
   14520             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__key_type}
   14521             : 
   14522             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   14523             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   14524             :     the given range
   14525             :     @sa @ref erase(const size_type) -- removes the element from an array at
   14526             :     the given index
   14527             : 
   14528             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14529             :     */
   14530          29 :     size_type erase(const typename object_t::key_type& key)
   14531             :     {
   14532             :         // this erase only works for objects
   14533          29 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_object()))
   14534             :         {
   14535          46 :             return m_value.object->erase(key);
   14536             :         }
   14537             : 
   14538           6 :         JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   14539             :     }
   14540             : 
   14541             :     /*!
   14542             :     @brief remove element from a JSON array given an index
   14543             : 
   14544             :     Removes element from a JSON array at the index @a idx.
   14545             : 
   14546             :     @param[in] idx index of the element to remove
   14547             : 
   14548             :     @throw type_error.307 when called on a type other than JSON object;
   14549             :     example: `"cannot use erase() with null"`
   14550             :     @throw out_of_range.401 when `idx >= size()`; example: `"array index 17
   14551             :     is out of range"`
   14552             : 
   14553             :     @complexity Linear in distance between @a idx and the end of the container.
   14554             : 
   14555             :     @liveexample{The example shows the effect of `erase()`.,erase__size_type}
   14556             : 
   14557             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType) -- removes the element at a given position
   14558             :     @sa @ref erase(IteratorType, IteratorType) -- removes the elements in
   14559             :     the given range
   14560             :     @sa @ref erase(const typename object_t::key_type&) -- removes the element
   14561             :     from an object at the given key
   14562             : 
   14563             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14564             :     */
   14565          30 :     void erase(const size_type idx)
   14566             :     {
   14567             :         // this erase only works for arrays
   14568          30 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))
   14569             :         {
   14570          23 :             if (JSON_UNLIKELY(idx >= size()))
   14571             :             {
   14572           3 :                 JSON_THROW(out_of_range::create(401, "array index " + std::to_string(idx) + " is out of range"));
   14573             :             }
   14574             : 
   14575          20 :             m_value.array->erase(m_value.array->begin() + static_cast<difference_type>(idx));
   14576             :         }
   14577             :         else
   14578             :         {
   14579           7 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(307, "cannot use erase() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   14580             :         }
   14581          20 :     }
   14582             : 
   14583             :     /// @}
   14584             :

   14587             :     // lookup //

   14590             :     /// @name lookup
   14591             :     /// @{
   14592             : 
   14593             :     /*!
   14594             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
   14595             : 
   14596             :     Finds an element in a JSON object with key equivalent to @a key. If the
   14597             :     element is not found or the JSON value is not an object, end() is
   14598             :     returned.
   14599             : 
   14600             :     @note This method always returns @ref end() when executed on a JSON type
   14601             :           that is not an object.
   14602             : 
   14603             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to search for.
   14604             : 
   14605             :     @return Iterator to an element with key equivalent to @a key. If no such
   14606             :     element is found or the JSON value is not an object, past-the-end (see
   14607             :     @ref end()) iterator is returned.
   14608             : 
   14609             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
   14610             : 
   14611             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `find()` is used.,find__key_type}
   14612             : 
   14613             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14614             :     */
   14615             :     template<typename KeyT>
   14616          80 :     iterator find(KeyT&& key)
   14617             :     {
   14618          80 :         auto result = end();
   14619             : 
   14620          80 :         if (is_object())
   14621             :         {
   14622          73 :             result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
   14623             :         }
   14624             : 
   14625          80 :         return result;
   14626             :     }
   14627             : 
   14628             :     /*!
   14629             :     @brief find an element in a JSON object
   14630             :     @copydoc find(KeyT&&)
   14631             :     */

   14634             :     {
   14635         308 :         auto result = cend();
   14636             :

   14638             :         {
   14639         301 :             result.m_it.object_iterator = m_value.object->find(std::forward<KeyT>(key));
   14640             :         }
   14641             : 
   14642         308 :         return result;
   14643             :     }
   14644             : 
   14645             :     /*!
   14646             :     @brief returns the number of occurrences of a key in a JSON object
   14647             : 
   14648             :     Returns the number of elements with key @a key. If ObjectType is the
   14649             :     default `std::map` type, the return value will always be `0` (@a key was
   14650             :     not found) or `1` (@a key was found).
   14651             : 
   14652             :     @note This method always returns `0` when executed on a JSON type that is
   14653             :           not an object.
   14654             : 
   14655             :     @param[in] key key value of the element to count
   14656             : 
   14657             :     @return Number of elements with key @a key. If the JSON value is not an
   14658             :     object, the return value will be `0`.
   14659             : 
   14660             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the JSON object.
   14661             : 
   14662             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `count()` is used.,count}
   14663             : 
   14664             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14665             :     */
   14666             :     template<typename KeyT>
   14667         134 :     size_type count(KeyT&& key) const
   14668             :     {
   14669             :         // return 0 for all nonobject types
   14670         134 :         return is_object() ? m_value.object->count(std::forward<KeyT>(key)) : 0;
   14671             :     }

   14684             :     @brief returns an iterator to the first element
   14685             :

   14687             : 
   14688             :     @image html range-begin-end.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14689             : 
   14690             :     @return iterator to the first element
   14691             : 
   14692             :     @complexity Constant.
   14693             : 
   14694             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14695             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   14696             :     requirements:
   14697             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14698             : 
   14699             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `begin()`.,begin}
   14700             : 
   14701             :     @sa @ref cbegin() -- returns a const iterator to the beginning
   14702             :     @sa @ref end() -- returns an iterator to the end
   14703             :     @sa @ref cend() -- returns a const iterator to the end
   14704             : 
   14705             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14706             :     */
   14707      132349 :     iterator begin() noexcept
   14708             :     {
   14709      132349 :         iterator result(this);
   14710      132349 :         result.set_begin();
   14711      132349 :         return result;
   14712             :     }
   14713             :
