   14926             : 
   14927             :     /*!
   14928             :     @brief returns a const reverse iterator to one before the first
   14929             : 
   14930             :     Returns a const reverse iterator to the reverse-end; that is, one before
   14931             :     the first element.
   14932             : 
   14933             :     @image html range-rbegin-rend.svg "Illustration from cppreference.com"
   14934             : 
   14935             :     @complexity Constant.
   14936             : 
   14937             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   14938             :     [ReversibleContainer](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/ReversibleContainer)
   14939             :     requirements:
   14940             :     - The complexity is constant.
   14941             :     - Has the semantics of `const_cast<const basic_json&>(*this).rend()`.
   14942             : 
   14943             :     @liveexample{The following code shows an example for `crend()`.,crend}
   14944             : 
   14945             :     @sa @ref rend() -- returns a reverse iterator to the end
   14946             :     @sa @ref rbegin() -- returns a reverse iterator to the beginning
   14947             :     @sa @ref crbegin() -- returns a const reverse iterator to the beginning
   14948             : 
   14949             :     @since version 1.0.0
   14950             :     */
   14951          83 :     const_reverse_iterator crend() const noexcept
   14952             :     {
   14953          83 :         return const_reverse_iterator(cbegin());
   14954             :     }
   14955             : 
   14956             :   public:
   14957             :     /*!
   14958             :     @brief wrapper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
   14959             : 
   14960             :     This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
   14961             :     iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
   14962             :     reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
   14963             :     underlying iterator.
   14964             : 
   14965             :     For loop without iterator_wrapper:
   14966             : 
   14967             :     @code{cpp}
   14968             :     for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
   14969             :     {
   14970             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14971             :     }
   14972             :     @endcode
   14973             : 
   14974             :     Range-based for loop without iterator proxy:
   14975             : 
   14976             :     @code{cpp}
   14977             :     for (auto it : j_object)
   14978             :     {
   14979             :         // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
   14980             :         std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
   14981             :     }
   14982             :     @endcode
   14983             : 
   14984             :     Range-based for loop with iterator proxy:
   14985             : 
   14986             :     @code{cpp}
   14987             :     for (auto it : json::iterator_wrapper(j_object))
   14988             :     {
   14989             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   14990             :     }
   14991             :     @endcode
   14992             : 
   14993             :     @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
   14994             :           element as string (see example).
   14995             : 
   14996             :     @param[in] ref  reference to a JSON value
   14997             :     @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
   14998             :             range-based for loops
   14999             : 
   15000             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how the wrapper is used,iterator_wrapper}
   15001             : 
   15002             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   15003             :     changes in the JSON value.
   15004             : 
   15005             :     @complexity Constant.
   15006             : 
   15007             :     @note The name of this function is not yet final and may change in the
   15008             :     future.
   15009             : 
   15010             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   15011             :                 future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use @ref items() instead;
   15012             :                 that is, replace `json::iterator_wrapper(j)` with `j.items()`.
   15013             :     */
   15014             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   15015          12 :     static iteration_proxy<iterator> iterator_wrapper(reference ref) noexcept
   15016             :     {
   15017          12 :         return ref.items();
   15018             :     }
   15019             : 
   15020             :     /*!
   15021             :     @copydoc iterator_wrapper(reference)
   15022             :     */
   15023             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   15024          12 :     static iteration_proxy<const_iterator> iterator_wrapper(const_reference ref) noexcept
   15025             :     {
   15026          12 :         return ref.items();
   15027             :     }
   15028             : 
   15029             :     /*!
   15030             :     @brief helper to access iterator member functions in range-based for
   15031             : 
   15032             :     This function allows to access @ref iterator::key() and @ref
   15033             :     iterator::value() during range-based for loops. In these loops, a
   15034             :     reference to the JSON values is returned, so there is no access to the
   15035             :     underlying iterator.
   15036             : 
   15037             :     For loop without `items()` function:
   15038             : 
   15039             :     @code{cpp}
   15040             :     for (auto it = j_object.begin(); it != j_object.end(); ++it)
   15041             :     {
   15042             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   15043             :     }
   15044             :     @endcode
   15045             : 
   15046             :     Range-based for loop without `items()` function:
   15047             : 
   15048             :     @code{cpp}
   15049             :     for (auto it : j_object)
   15050             :     {
   15051             :         // "it" is of type json::reference and has no key() member
   15052             :         std::cout << "value: " << it << '\n';
   15053             :     }
   15054             :     @endcode
   15055             : 
   15056             :     Range-based for loop with `items()` function:
   15057             : 
   15058             :     @code{cpp}
   15059             :     for (auto it : j_object.items())
   15060             :     {
   15061             :         std::cout << "key: " << it.key() << ", value:" << it.value() << '\n';
   15062             :     }
   15063             :     @endcode
   15064             : 
   15065             :     @note When iterating over an array, `key()` will return the index of the
   15066             :           element as string (see example). For primitive types (e.g., numbers),
   15067             :           `key()` returns an empty string.
   15068             : 
   15069             :     @return iteration proxy object wrapping @a ref with an interface to use in
   15070             :             range-based for loops
   15071             : 
   15072             :     @liveexample{The following code shows how the function is used.,items}
   15073             : 
   15074             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   15075             :     changes in the JSON value.
   15076             : 
   15077             :     @complexity Constant.
   15078             : 
   15079             :     @since version 3.x.x.
   15080             :     */
   15081          24 :     iteration_proxy<iterator> items() noexcept
   15082             :     {
   15083          24 :         return iteration_proxy<iterator>(*this);
   15084             :     }
   15085             : 
   15086             :     /*!
   15087             :     @copydoc items()
   15088             :     */
   15089          24 :     iteration_proxy<const_iterator> items() const noexcept
   15090             :     {
   15091          24 :         return iteration_proxy<const_iterator>(*this);
   15092             :     }
   15093             : 
   15094             :     /// @}
   15095             : 
   15096             : 
   15097             :     //////////////
   15098             :     // capacity //
   15099             :     //////////////
   15100             : 
   15101             :     /// @name capacity
   15102             :     /// @{
   15103             : 
   15104             :     /*!
   15105             :     @brief checks whether the container is empty.
   15106             : 
   15107             :     Checks if a JSON value has no elements (i.e. whether its @ref size is `0`).
   15108             : 
   15109             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   15110             :             defined as follows:
   15111             :             Value type  | return value
   15112             :             ----------- | -------------
   15113             :             null        | `true`
   15114             :             boolean     | `false`
   15115             :             string      | `false`
   15116             :             number      | `false`
   15117             :             object      | result of function `object_t::empty()`
   15118             :             array       | result of function `array_t::empty()`
   15119             : 
   15120             :     @liveexample{The following code uses `empty()` to check if a JSON
   15121             :     object contains any elements.,empty}
   15122             : 
   15123             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   15124             :     the Container concept; that is, their `empty()` functions have constant
   15125             :     complexity.
   15126             : 
   15127             :     @iterators No changes.
   15128             : 
   15129             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15130             : 
   15131             :     @note This function does not return whether a string stored as JSON value
   15132             :     is empty - it returns whether the JSON container itself is empty which is
   15133             :     false in the case of a string.
   15134             : 
   15135             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   15136             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   15137             :     requirements:
   15138             :     - The complexity is constant.
   15139             :     - Has the semantics of `begin() == end()`.
   15140             : 
   15141             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
   15142             : 
   15143             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15144             :     */
   15145          47 :     bool empty() const noexcept
   15146             :     {
   15147          47 :         switch (m_type)
   15148             :         {
   15149           6 :             case value_t::null:
   15150             :             {
   15151             :                 // null values are empty
   15152           6 :                 return true;
   15153             :             }
   15154             : 
   15155          11 :             case value_t::array:
   15156             :             {
   15157             :                 // delegate call to array_t::empty()
   15158          11 :                 return m_value.array->empty();
   15159             :             }
   15160             : 
   15161          10 :             case value_t::object:
   15162             :             {
   15163             :                 // delegate call to object_t::empty()
   15164          10 :                 return m_value.object->empty();
   15165             :             }
   15166             : 
   15167          20 :             default:
   15168             :             {
   15169             :                 // all other types are nonempty
   15170          20 :                 return false;
   15171             :             }
   15172             :         }
   15173             :     }
   15174             : 
   15175             :     /*!
   15176             :     @brief returns the number of elements
   15177             : 
   15178             :     Returns the number of elements in a JSON value.
   15179             : 
   15180             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   15181             :             defined as follows:
   15182             :             Value type  | return value
   15183             :             ----------- | -------------
   15184             :             null        | `0`
   15185             :             boolean     | `1`
   15186             :             string      | `1`
   15187             :             number      | `1`
   15188             :             object      | result of function object_t::size()
   15189             :             array       | result of function array_t::size()
   15190             : 
   15191             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `size()` on the different value
   15192             :     types.,size}
   15193             : 
   15194             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   15195             :     the Container concept; that is, their size() functions have constant
   15196             :     complexity.
   15197             : 
   15198             :     @iterators No changes.
   15199             : 
   15200             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15201             : 
   15202             :     @note This function does not return the length of a string stored as JSON
   15203             :     value - it returns the number of elements in the JSON value which is 1 in
   15204             :     the case of a string.
   15205             : 
   15206             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   15207             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   15208             :     requirements:
   15209             :     - The complexity is constant.
   15210             :     - Has the semantics of `std::distance(begin(), end())`.
   15211             : 
   15212             :     @sa @ref empty() -- checks whether the container is empty
   15213             :     @sa @ref max_size() -- returns the maximal number of elements
   15214             : 
   15215             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15216             :     */
   15217        2965 :     size_type size() const noexcept
   15218             :     {
   15219        2965 :         switch (m_type)
   15220             :         {
   15221           9 :             case value_t::null:
   15222             :             {
   15223             :                 // null values are empty
   15224           9 :                 return 0;
   15225             :             }
   15226             : 
   15227        2854 :             case value_t::array:
   15228             :             {
   15229             :                 // delegate call to array_t::size()
   15230        2854 :                 return m_value.array->size();
   15231             :             }
   15232             : 
   15233          30 :             case value_t::object:
   15234             :             {
   15235             :                 // delegate call to object_t::size()
   15236          30 :                 return m_value.object->size();
   15237             :             }
   15238             : 
   15239          72 :             default:
   15240             :             {
   15241             :                 // all other types have size 1
   15242          72 :                 return 1;
   15243             :             }
   15244             :         }
   15245             :     }
   15246             : 
   15247             :     /*!
   15248             :     @brief returns the maximum possible number of elements
   15249             : 
   15250             :     Returns the maximum number of elements a JSON value is able to hold due to
   15251             :     system or library implementation limitations, i.e. `std::distance(begin(),
   15252             :     end())` for the JSON value.
   15253             : 
   15254             :     @return The return value depends on the different types and is
   15255             :             defined as follows:
   15256             :             Value type  | return value
   15257             :             ----------- | -------------
   15258             :             null        | `0` (same as `size()`)
   15259             :             boolean     | `1` (same as `size()`)
   15260             :             string      | `1` (same as `size()`)
   15261             :             number      | `1` (same as `size()`)
   15262             :             object      | result of function `object_t::max_size()`
   15263             :             array       | result of function `array_t::max_size()`
   15264             : 
   15265             :     @liveexample{The following code calls `max_size()` on the different value
   15266             :     types. Note the output is implementation specific.,max_size}
   15267             : 
   15268             :     @complexity Constant, as long as @ref array_t and @ref object_t satisfy
   15269             :     the Container concept; that is, their `max_size()` functions have constant
   15270             :     complexity.
   15271             : 
   15272             :     @iterators No changes.
   15273             : 
   15274             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15275             : 
   15276             :     @requirement This function helps `basic_json` satisfying the
   15277             :     [Container](http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/concept/Container)
   15278             :     requirements:
   15279             :     - The complexity is constant.
   15280             :     - Has the semantics of returning `b.size()` where `b` is the largest
   15281             :       possible JSON value.
   15282             : 
   15283             :     @sa @ref size() -- returns the number of elements
   15284             : 
   15285             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15286             :     */
   15287        8891 :     size_type max_size() const noexcept
   15288             :     {
   15289        8891 :         switch (m_type)
   15290             :         {
   15291        5019 :             case value_t::array:
   15292             :             {
   15293             :                 // delegate call to array_t::max_size()
   15294        5019 :                 return m_value.array->max_size();
   15295             :             }
   15296             : 
   15297        3860 :             case value_t::object:
   15298             :             {
   15299             :                 // delegate call to object_t::max_size()
   15300        3860 :                 return m_value.object->max_size();
   15301             :             }
   15302             : 
   15303          12 :             default:
   15304             :             {
   15305             :                 // all other types have max_size() == size()
   15306          12 :                 return size();
   15307             :             }
   15308             :         }
   15309             :     }
   15310             : 
   15311             :     /// @}
   15312             : 
   15313             : 
   15314             :     ///////////////
   15315             :     // modifiers //
   15316             :     ///////////////
   15317             : 
   15318             :     /// @name modifiers
   15319             :     /// @{
   15320             : 
   15321             :     /*!
   15322             :     @brief clears the contents
   15323             : 
   15324             :     Clears the content of a JSON value and resets it to the default value as
   15325             :     if @ref basic_json(value_t) would have been called with the current value
   15326             :     type from @ref type():
   15327             : 
   15328             :     Value type  | initial value
   15329             :     ----------- | -------------
   15330             :     null        | `null`
   15331             :     boolean     | `false`
   15332             :     string      | `""`
   15333             :     number      | `0`
   15334             :     object      | `{}`
   15335             :     array       | `[]`
   15336             : 
   15337             :     @post Has the same effect as calling
   15338             :     @code {.cpp}
   15339             :     *this = basic_json(type());
   15340             :     @endcode
   15341             : 
   15342             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the effect of `clear()` to different
   15343             :     JSON types.,clear}
   15344             : 
   15345             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value.
   15346             : 
   15347             :     @iterators All iterators, pointers and references related to this container
   15348             :                are invalidated.
   15349             : 
   15350             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   15351             : 
   15352             :     @sa @ref basic_json(value_t) -- constructor that creates an object with the
   15353             :         same value than calling `clear()`
   15354             : 
   15355             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15356             :     */
   15357          11 :     void clear() noexcept
   15358             :     {
   15359          11 :         switch (m_type)
   15360             :         {
   15361           1 :             case value_t::number_integer:
   15362             :             {
   15363           1 :                 m_value.number_integer = 0;
   15364           1 :                 break;
   15365             :             }
   15366             : 
   15367           1 :             case value_t::number_unsigned:
   15368             :             {
   15369           1 :                 m_value.number_unsigned = 0;
   15370           1 :                 break;
   15371             :             }
   15372             : 
   15373           1 :             case value_t::number_float:
   15374             :             {
   15375           1 :                 m_value.number_float = 0.0;
   15376           1 :                 break;
   15377             :             }
   15378             : 
   15379           1 :             case value_t::boolean:
   15380             :             {
   15381           1 :                 m_value.boolean = false;
   15382           1 :                 break;
   15383             :             }
   15384             : 
   15385           1 :             case value_t::string:
   15386             :             {
   15387           1 :                 m_value.string->clear();
   15388           1 :                 break;
   15389             :             }
   15390             : 
   15391           3 :             case value_t::array:
   15392             :             {
   15393           3 :                 m_value.array->clear();
   15394           3 :                 break;
   15395             :             }
   15396             : 
   15397           2 :             case value_t::object:
   15398             :             {
   15399           2 :                 m_value.object->clear();
   15400           2 :                 break;
   15401             :             }
   15402             : 
   15403           1 :             default:
   15404           1 :                 break;
   15405             :         }
   15406          11 :     }
   15407             : 
   15408             :     /*!
   15409             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15410             : 
   15411             :     Appends the given element @a val to the end of the JSON value. If the
   15412             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array is created before
   15413             :     appending @a val.
   15414             : 
   15415             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON array
   15416             : 
   15417             :     @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON array or
   15418             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
   15419             : 
   15420             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
   15421             : 
   15422             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
   15423             :     add elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently
   15424             :     converted to a JSON array.,push_back}
   15425             : 
   15426             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15427             :     */
   15428          59 :     void push_back(basic_json&& val)
   15429             :     {
   15430             :         // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
   15431          59 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   15432             :         {
   15433           6 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   15434             :         }
   15435             : 
   15436             :         // transform null object into an array
   15437          53 :         if (is_null())
   15438             :         {
   15439           8 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   15440           8 :             m_value = value_t::array;
   15441           8 :             assert_invariant();
   15442             :         }
   15443             : 
   15444             :         // add element to array (move semantics)
   15445          53 :         m_value.array->push_back(std::move(val));
   15446             :         // invalidate object
   15447          53 :         val.m_type = value_t::null;
   15448          53 :     }
   15449             : 
   15450             :     /*!
   15451             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15452             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   15453             :     */
   15454           4 :     reference operator+=(basic_json&& val)
   15455             :     {
   15456           4 :         push_back(std::move(val));
   15457           3 :         return *this;
   15458             :     }
   15459             : 
   15460             :     /*!
   15461             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15462             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   15463             :     */
   15464          45 :     void push_back(const basic_json& val)
   15465             :     {
   15466             :         // push_back only works for null objects or arrays
   15467          45 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   15468             :         {
   15469           2 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   15470             :         }
   15471             : 
   15472             :         // transform null object into an array
   15473          43 :         if (is_null())
   15474             :         {
   15475           7 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   15476           7 :             m_value = value_t::array;
   15477           7 :             assert_invariant();
   15478             :         }
   15479             : 
   15480             :         // add element to array
   15481          43 :         m_value.array->push_back(val);
   15482          43 :     }
   15483             : 
   15484             :     /*!
   15485             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15486             :     @copydoc push_back(basic_json&&)
   15487             :     */
   15488           4 :     reference operator+=(const basic_json& val)
   15489             :     {
   15490           4 :         push_back(val);
   15491           3 :         return *this;
   15492             :     }
   15493             : 
   15494             :     /*!
   15495             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15496             : 
   15497             :     Inserts the given element @a val to the JSON object. If the function is
   15498             :     called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before inserting
   15499             :     @a val.
   15500             : 
   15501             :     @param[in] val the value to add to the JSON object
   15502             : 
   15503             :     @throw type_error.308 when called on a type other than JSON object or
   15504             :     null; example: `"cannot use push_back() with number"`
   15505             : 
   15506             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
   15507             : 
   15508             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` and `+=` can be used to
   15509             :     add elements to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently
   15510             :     converted to a JSON object.,push_back__object_t__value}
   15511             : 
   15512             :     @since version 1.0.0
   15513             :     */
   15514          14 :     void push_back(const typename object_t::value_type& val)
   15515             :     {
   15516             :         // push_back only works for null objects or objects
   15517          14 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))
   15518             :         {
   15519           2 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(308, "cannot use push_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   15520             :         }
   15521             : 
   15522             :         // transform null object into an object
   15523          12 :         if (is_null())

   15534             :     /*!
   15535             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15536             :     @copydoc push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&)
   15537             :     */
   15538           5 :     reference operator+=(const typename object_t::value_type& val)

   15541           4 :         return *this;

   15543             : 
   15544             :     /*!
   15545             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15546             : 
   15547             :     This function allows to use `push_back` with an initializer list. In case
   15548             : 
   15549             :     1. the current value is an object,
   15550             :     2. the initializer list @a init contains only two elements, and
   15551             :     3. the first element of @a init is a string,
   15552             : 
   15553             :     @a init is converted into an object element and added using
   15554             :     @ref push_back(const typename object_t::value_type&). Otherwise, @a init
   15555             :     is converted to a JSON value and added using @ref push_back(basic_json&&).
   15556             : 
   15557             :     @param[in] init  an initializer list
   15558             : 
   15559             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the initializer list @a init.
   15560             : 
   15561             :     @note This function is required to resolve an ambiguous overload error,
   15562             :           because pairs like `{"key", "value"}` can be both interpreted as
   15563             :           `object_t::value_type` or `std::initializer_list<basic_json>`, see
   15564             :           https://github.com/nlohmann/json/issues/235 for more information.
   15565             : 
   15566             :     @liveexample{The example shows how initializer lists are treated as
   15567             :     objects when possible.,push_back__initializer_list}
   15568             :     */
   15569          40 :     void push_back(initializer_list_t init)
   15570             :     {
   15571          40 :         if (is_object() and init.size() == 2 and (*init.begin())->is_string())
   15572             :         {
   15573           8 :             basic_json&& key = init.begin()->moved_or_copied();
   15574           8 :             push_back(typename object_t::value_type(
   15575           8 :                           std::move(key.get_ref<string_t&>()), (init.begin() + 1)->moved_or_copied()));
   15576             :         }
   15577             :         else
   15578             :         {
   15579          40 :             push_back(basic_json(init));
   15580             :         }
   15581          36 :     }
   15582             : 
   15583             :     /*!
   15584             :     @brief add an object to an object
   15585             :     @copydoc push_back(initializer_list_t)
   15586             :     */
   15587           7 :     reference operator+=(initializer_list_t init)
   15588             :     {
   15589           7 :         push_back(init);
   15590           6 :         return *this;
   15591             :     }
   15592             : 
   15593             :     /*!
   15594             :     @brief add an object to an array
   15595             : 
   15596             :     Creates a JSON value from the passed parameters @a args to the end of the
   15597             :     JSON value. If the function is called on a JSON null value, an empty array
   15598             :     is created before appending the value created from @a args.
   15599             : 
   15600             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
   15601             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
   15602             : 
   15603             :     @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON array or
   15604             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace_back() with number"`
   15605             : 
   15606             :     @complexity Amortized constant.
   15607             : 
   15608             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `push_back()` can be used to add
   15609             :     elements to a JSON array. Note how the `null` value was silently converted
   15610             :     to a JSON array.,emplace_back}
   15611             : 
   15612             :     @since version 2.0.8
   15613             :     */
   15614             :     template<class... Args>
   15615           5 :     void emplace_back(Args&& ... args)
   15616             :     {
   15617             :         // emplace_back only works for null objects or arrays
   15618           5 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_array())))
   15619             :         {
   15620           1 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(311, "cannot use emplace_back() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   15621             :         }
   15622             : 
   15623             :         // transform null object into an array
   15624           4 :         if (is_null())
   15625             :         {
   15626           2 :             m_type = value_t::array;
   15627           2 :             m_value = value_t::array;
   15628           2 :             assert_invariant();
   15629             :         }
   15630             : 
   15631             :         // add element to array (perfect forwarding)
   15632           4 :         m_value.array->emplace_back(std::forward<Args>(args)...);

   15634             : 
   15635             :     /*!
   15636             :     @brief add an object to an object if key does not exist
   15637             : 
   15638             :     Inserts a new element into a JSON object constructed in-place with the
   15639             :     given @a args if there is no element with the key in the container. If the
   15640             :     function is called on a JSON null value, an empty object is created before
   15641             :     appending the value created from @a args.
   15642             : 
   15643             :     @param[in] args arguments to forward to a constructor of @ref basic_json
   15644             :     @tparam Args compatible types to create a @ref basic_json object
   15645             : 
   15646             :     @return a pair consisting of an iterator to the inserted element, or the
   15647             :             already-existing element if no insertion happened, and a bool
   15648             :             denoting whether the insertion took place.
   15649             : 
   15650             :     @throw type_error.311 when called on a type other than JSON object or
   15651             :     null; example: `"cannot use emplace() with number"`
   15652             : 
   15653             :     @complexity Logarithmic in the size of the container, O(log(`size()`)).
   15654             : 
   15655             :     @liveexample{The example shows how `emplace()` can be used to add elements
   15656             :     to a JSON object. Note how the `null` value was silently converted to a
   15657             :     JSON object. Further note how no value is added if there was already one
   15658             :     value stored with the same key.,emplace}
   15659             : 
   15660             :     @since version 2.0.8
   15661             :     */
   15662             :     template<class... Args>
   15663      131589 :     std::pair<iterator, bool> emplace(Args&& ... args)

   15665             :         // emplace only works for null objects or arrays
   15666      131589 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not(is_null() or is_object())))

   15669             :         }

   15672      131588 :         if (is_null())

   15674           5 :             m_type = value_t::object;

   15676           5 :             assert_invariant();
   15677             :         }

   15801             :     container for which insert is called; example: `"passed iterators may not

   16025             :         {
   16026           1 :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(210, "iterators do not fit"));
   16027             :         }
   16028             : 
   16029             :         // passed iterators must belong to objects
   16030           4 :         if (JSON_UNLIKELY(not first.m_object->is_object()
   16031             :                           or not last.m_object->is_object()))
   16032             :         {
   16033           1 :             JSON_THROW(invalid_iterator::create(202, "iterators first and last must point to objects"));
   16034             :         }
   16035             : 
   16036           7 :         for (auto it = first; it != last; ++it)
   16037             :         {
   16038           4 :             m_value.object->operator[](it.key()) = it.value();
   16039             :         }
   16040           3 :     }
   16041             : 
   16042             :     /*!
   16043             :     @brief exchanges the values
   16044             : 
   16045             :     Exchanges the contents of the JSON value with those of @a other. Does not
   16046             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   16047             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   16048             :     invalidated.
   16049             : 
   16050             :     @param[in,out] other JSON value to exchange the contents with
   16051             : 
   16052             :     @complexity Constant.
   16053             : 
   16054             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how JSON values can be swapped with
   16055             :     `swap()`.,swap__reference}
   16056             : 
   16057             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16058             :     */
   16059          16 :     void swap(reference other) noexcept (
   16060             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<value_t>::value and
   16061             :         std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<value_t>::value and
   16062             :         std::is_nothrow_move_constructible<json_value>::value and
   16063             :         std::is_nothrow_move_assignable<json_value>::value
   16064             :     )

   16067          16 :         std::swap(m_value, other.m_value);

   16070             : 
   16071             :     /*!
   16072             :     @brief exchanges the values
   16073             : 
   16074             :     Exchanges the contents of a JSON array with those of @a other. Does not
   16075             :     invoke any move, copy, or swap operations on individual elements. All
   16076             :     iterators and references remain valid. The past-the-end iterator is
   16077             :     invalidated.
   16078             : 
   16079             :     @param[in,out] other array to exchange the contents with
   16080             : 
   16081             :     @throw type_error.310 when JSON value is not an array; example: `"cannot
   16082             :     use swap() with string"`
   16083             : 
   16084             :     @complexity Constant.
   16085             : 
   16086             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how arrays can be swapped with
   16087             :     `swap()`.,swap__array_t}
   16088             : 
   16089             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16090             :     */
   16091           3 :     void swap(array_t& other)
   16092             :     {
   16093             :         // swap only works for arrays
   16094           3 :         if (JSON_LIKELY(is_array()))

   16097             :         }

   16100           1 :             JSON_THROW(type_error::create(310, "cannot use swap() with " + std::string(type_name())));
   16101             :         }
   16102           2 :     }

   16169             : 
   16170             :     /// @}
   16171             : 
   16172             :   public:
   16173             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16174             :     // lexicographical comparison operators //
   16175             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16176             : 
   16177             :     /// @name lexicographical comparison operators
   16178             :     /// @{
   16179             : 
   16180             :     /*!
   16181             :     @brief comparison: equal
   16182             : 
   16183             :     Compares two JSON values for equality according to the following rules:
   16184             :     - Two JSON values are equal if (1) they are from the same type and (2)
   16185             :       their stored values are the same according to their respective
   16186             :       `operator==`.
   16187             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
   16188             :       comparison. Note than two NaN values are always treated as unequal.
   16189             :     - Two JSON null values are equal.
   16190             : 
   16191             :     @note Floating-point inside JSON values numbers are compared with
   16192             :     `json::number_float_t::operator==` which is `double::operator==` by
   16193             :     default. To compare floating-point while respecting an epsilon, an alternative
   16194             :     [comparison function](https://github.com/mariokonrad/marnav/blob/master/src/marnav/math/floatingpoint.hpp#L34-#L39)
   16195             :     could be used, for instance
   16196             :     @code {.cpp}
   16197             :     template<typename T, typename = typename std::enable_if<std::is_floating_point<T>::value, T>::type>
   16198             :     inline bool is_same(T a, T b, T epsilon = std::numeric_limits<T>::epsilon()) noexcept
   16199             :     {
   16200             :         return std::abs(a - b) <= epsilon;
   16201             :     }
   16202             :     @endcode
   16203             : 
   16204             :     @note NaN values never compare equal to themselves or to other NaN values.
   16205             : 
   16206             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16207             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16208             :     @return whether the values @a lhs and @a rhs are equal
   16209             : 
   16210             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16211             : 
   16212             :     @complexity Linear.
   16213             : 
   16214             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16215             :     types.,operator__equal}
   16216             : 
   16217             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16218             :     */
   16219    31036479 :     friend bool operator==(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16220             :     {
   16221    31036479 :         const auto lhs_type = lhs.type();
   16222    31036479 :         const auto rhs_type = rhs.type();
   16223             : 
   16224    31036479 :         if (lhs_type == rhs_type)
   16225             :         {
   16226    30707031 :             switch (lhs_type)
   16227             :             {
   16228        6950 :                 case value_t::array:
   16229        6950 :                     return (*lhs.m_value.array == *rhs.m_value.array);
   16230             : 
   16231        5664 :                 case value_t::object:
   16232        5664 :                     return (*lhs.m_value.object == *rhs.m_value.object);
   16233             : 
   16234      927755 :                 case value_t::null:
   16235      927755 :                     return true;
   16236             : 
   16237    11128459 :                 case value_t::string:
   16238    11128459 :                     return (*lhs.m_value.string == *rhs.m_value.string);
   16239             : 
   16240        4779 :                 case value_t::boolean:
   16241        4779 :                     return (lhs.m_value.boolean == rhs.m_value.boolean);
   16242             : 
   16243     3361751 :                 case value_t::number_integer:
   16244     3361751 :                     return (lhs.m_value.number_integer == rhs.m_value.number_integer);
   16245             : 
   16246     9266507 :                 case value_t::number_unsigned:
   16247     9266507 :                     return (lhs.m_value.number_unsigned == rhs.m_value.number_unsigned);
   16248             : 
   16249     6005150 :                 case value_t::number_float:
   16250     6005150 :                     return (lhs.m_value.number_float == rhs.m_value.number_float);

   16254             :             }

   16256      329448 :         else if (lhs_type == value_t::number_integer and rhs_type == value_t::number_float)

   16259             :         }

   16350             : 
   16351             :     /*!
   16352             :     @brief comparison: less than
   16353             : 
   16354             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is less than another JSON value @a
   16355             :     rhs according to the following rules:
   16356             :     - If @a lhs and @a rhs have the same type, the values are compared using
   16357             :       the default `<` operator.
   16358             :     - Integer and floating-point numbers are automatically converted before
   16359             :       comparison
   16360             :     - In case @a lhs and @a rhs have different types, the values are ignored
   16361             :       and the order of the types is considered, see
   16362             :       @ref operator<(const value_t, const value_t).
   16363             : 
   16364             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16365             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16366             :     @return whether @a lhs is less than @a rhs
   16367             : 
   16368             :     @complexity Linear.
   16369             : 
   16370             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16371             : 
   16372             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16373             :     types.,operator__less}
   16374             : 
   16375             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16376             :     */

   16471             :     JSON value by calculating `not (rhs < lhs)`.

   16505             :     */
   16506             :     template<typename ScalarType, typename std::enable_if<
   16507             :                  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>

   16511             :     }
   16512             : 
   16513             :     /*!
   16514             :     @brief comparison: greater than
   16515             : 
   16516             :     Compares whether one JSON value @a lhs is greater than another
   16517             :     JSON value by calculating `not (lhs <= rhs)`.
   16518             : 
   16519             :     @param[in] lhs  first JSON value to consider
   16520             :     @param[in] rhs  second JSON value to consider
   16521             :     @return whether @a lhs is greater than to @a rhs
   16522             : 
   16523             :     @complexity Linear.
   16524             : 
   16525             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16526             : 
   16527             :     @liveexample{The example demonstrates comparing several JSON
   16528             :     types.,operator__lessequal}
   16529             : 
   16530             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16531             :     */
   16532         260 :     friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const_reference rhs) noexcept
   16533             :     {
   16534         260 :         return not (lhs <= rhs);
   16535             :     }
   16536             :

   16542             :                  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>
   16543           2 :     friend bool operator>(const_reference lhs, const ScalarType rhs) noexcept

   16546             :     }

   16553             :                  std::is_scalar<ScalarType>::value, int>::type = 0>

   16557             :     }

   16606             : 
   16607             :     ///////////////////
   16608             :     // serialization //
   16609             :     ///////////////////
   16610             : 
   16611             :     /// @name serialization
   16612             :     /// @{
   16613             : 
   16614             :     /*!
   16615             :     @brief serialize to stream
   16616             : 
   16617             :     Serialize the given JSON value @a j to the output stream @a o. The JSON
   16618             :     value will be serialized using the @ref dump member function.
   16619             : 
   16620             :     - The indentation of the output can be controlled with the member variable
   16621             :       `width` of the output stream @a o. For instance, using the manipulator
   16622             :       `std::setw(4)` on @a o sets the indentation level to `4` and the
   16623             :       serialization result is the same as calling `dump(4)`.
   16624             : 
   16625             :     - The indentation character can be controlled with the member variable
   16626             :       `fill` of the output stream @a o. For instance, the manipulator
   16627             :       `std::setfill('\\t')` sets indentation to use a tab character rather than
   16628             :       the default space character.
   16629             : 
   16630             :     @param[in,out] o  stream to serialize to
   16631             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   16632             : 
   16633             :     @return the stream @a o
   16634             : 
   16635             :     @throw type_error.316 if a string stored inside the JSON value is not
   16636             :                           UTF-8 encoded
   16637             : 
   16638             :     @complexity Linear.
   16639             : 
   16640             :     @liveexample{The example below shows the serialization with different
   16641             :     parameters to `width` to adjust the indentation level.,operator_serialize}
   16642             : 
   16643             :     @since version 1.0.0; indentation character added in version 3.0.0
   16644             :     */
   16645          58 :     friend std::ostream& operator<<(std::ostream& o, const basic_json& j)
   16646             :     {
   16647             :         // read width member and use it as indentation parameter if nonzero
   16648          58 :         const bool pretty_print = (o.width() > 0);
   16649          58 :         const auto indentation = (pretty_print ? o.width() : 0);
   16650             : 
   16651             :         // reset width to 0 for subsequent calls to this stream
   16652          58 :         o.width(0);
   16653             : 
   16654             :         // do the actual serialization
   16655         116 :         serializer s(detail::output_adapter<char>(o), o.fill());
   16656          58 :         s.dump(j, pretty_print, false, static_cast<unsigned int>(indentation));
   16657         116 :         return o;
   16658             :     }
   16659             : 
   16660             :     /*!
   16661             :     @brief serialize to stream
   16662             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   16663             :                 future 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
   16664             :                 @ref operator<<(std::ostream&, const basic_json&)
   16665             :                 instead; that is, replace calls like `j >> o;` with `o << j;`.
   16666             :     @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
   16667             :     */
