   16674             :     /// @}
   16675             : 
   16676             : 
   16677             :     /////////////////////
   16678             :     // deserialization //
   16679             :     /////////////////////
   16680             : 
   16681             :     /// @name deserialization
   16682             :     /// @{
   16683             : 
   16684             :     /*!
   16685             :     @brief deserialize from a compatible input
   16686             : 
   16687             :     This function reads from a compatible input. Examples are:
   16688             :     - an array of 1-byte values
   16689             :     - strings with character/literal type with size of 1 byte
   16690             :     - input streams
   16691             :     - container with contiguous storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container
   16692             :       types include `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`,
   16693             :       `std::valarray`, and `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style
   16694             :       arrays can be used with `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined
   16695             :       containers can be used as long as they implement random-access iterators
   16696             :       and a contiguous storage.
   16697             : 
   16698             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16699             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16700             :     with a static assertion.**
   16701             : 
   16702             :     @pre The container storage is contiguous. Violating this precondition
   16703             :     yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an
   16704             :     assertion.**
   16705             :     @pre Each element of the container has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16706             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16707             :     with a static assertion.**
   16708             : 
   16709             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
   16710             :              the function is called with a noncompliant container and with
   16711             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
   16712             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
   16713             : 
   16714             :     @param[in] i  input to read from
   16715             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
   16716             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
   16717             :     (optional)
   16718             : 
   16719             :     @return result of the deserialization
   16720             : 
   16721             :     @throw parse_error.101 if a parse error occurs; example: `""unexpected end
   16722             :     of input; expected string literal""`
   16723             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16724             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16725             : 
   16726             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16727             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
   16728             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
   16729             : 
   16730             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16731             : 
   16732             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16733             :     from an array.,parse__array__parser_callback_t}
   16734             : 
   16735             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
   16736             :     and without callback function.,parse__string__parser_callback_t}
   16737             : 
   16738             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function with
   16739             :     and without callback function.,parse__istream__parser_callback_t}
   16740             : 
   16741             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16742             :     from a contiguous container.,parse__contiguouscontainer__parser_callback_t}
   16743             : 
   16744             :     @since version 2.0.3 (contiguous containers)
   16745             :     */
   16746     9973641 :     static basic_json parse(detail::input_adapter&& i,
   16747             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
   16748             :                             const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   16749             :     {
   16750     9973641 :         basic_json result;
   16751    17722366 :         parser(i, cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
   16752     2224916 :         return result;
   16753             :     }
   16754             : 
   16755          12 :     static bool accept(detail::input_adapter&& i)
   16756             :     {
   16757          12 :         return parser(i).accept(true);
   16758             :     }
   16759             : 
   16760         454 :     static bool sax_parse(detail::input_adapter&& i, json_sax_t* sax,
   16761             :                           input_format_t format = input_format_t::json,
   16762             :                           const bool strict = true)
   16763             :     {
   16764         454 :         assert(sax);
   16765         454 :         switch (format)
   16766             :         {
   16767         440 :             case input_format_t::json:
   16768         440 :                 return parser(std::move(i)).sax_parse(sax, strict);
   16769          14 :             default:
   16770          16 :                 return binary_reader(std::move(i)).sax_parse(format, sax, strict);
   16771             :         }
   16772             :     }
   16773             : 
   16774             :     /*!
   16775             :     @brief deserialize from an iterator range with contiguous storage
   16776             : 
   16777             :     This function reads from an iterator range of a container with contiguous
   16778             :     storage of 1-byte values. Compatible container types include
   16779             :     `std::vector`, `std::string`, `std::array`, `std::valarray`, and
   16780             :     `std::initializer_list`. Furthermore, C-style arrays can be used with
   16781             :     `std::begin()`/`std::end()`. User-defined containers can be used as long
   16782             :     as they implement random-access iterators and a contiguous storage.
   16783             : 
   16784             :     @pre The iterator range is contiguous. Violating this precondition yields
   16785             :     undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced with an assertion.**
   16786             :     @pre Each element in the range has a size of 1 byte. Violating this
   16787             :     precondition yields undefined behavior. **This precondition is enforced
   16788             :     with a static assertion.**
   16789             : 
   16790             :     @warning There is no way to enforce all preconditions at compile-time. If
   16791             :              the function is called with noncompliant iterators and with
   16792             :              assertions switched off, the behavior is undefined and will most
   16793             :              likely yield segmentation violation.
   16794             : 
   16795             :     @tparam IteratorType iterator of container with contiguous storage
   16796             :     @param[in] first  begin of the range to parse (included)
   16797             :     @param[in] last  end of the range to parse (excluded)
   16798             :     @param[in] cb  a parser callback function of type @ref parser_callback_t
   16799             :     which is used to control the deserialization by filtering unwanted values
   16800             :     (optional)
   16801             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions  whether to throw exceptions in case of a
   16802             :     parse error (optional, true by default)
   16803             : 
   16804             :     @return result of the deserialization
   16805             : 
   16806             :     @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
   16807             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16808             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16809             : 
   16810             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16811             :     LL(1) parser. The complexity can be higher if the parser callback function
   16812             :     @a cb has a super-linear complexity.
   16813             : 
   16814             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16815             : 
   16816             :     @liveexample{The example below demonstrates the `parse()` function reading
   16817             :     from an iterator range.,parse__iteratortype__parser_callback_t}
   16818             : 
   16819             :     @since version 2.0.3
   16820             :     */
   16821             :     template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
   16822             :                  std::is_base_of<
   16823             :                      std::random_access_iterator_tag,
   16824             :                      typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
   16825         231 :     static basic_json parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last,
   16826             :                             const parser_callback_t cb = nullptr,
   16827             :                             const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   16828             :     {
   16829         231 :         basic_json result;
   16830         250 :         parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last), cb, allow_exceptions).parse(true, result);
   16831         212 :         return result;
   16832             :     }
   16833             : 
   16834             :     template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
   16835             :                  std::is_base_of<
   16836             :                      std::random_access_iterator_tag,
   16837             :                      typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
   16838          23 :     static bool accept(IteratorType first, IteratorType last)
   16839             :     {
   16840          23 :         return parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last)).accept(true);
   16841             :     }
   16842             : 
   16843             :     template<class IteratorType, typename std::enable_if<
   16844             :                  std::is_base_of<
   16845             :                      std::random_access_iterator_tag,
   16846             :                      typename std::iterator_traits<IteratorType>::iterator_category>::value, int>::type = 0>
   16847          23 :     static bool sax_parse(IteratorType first, IteratorType last, json_sax_t* sax)
   16848             :     {
   16849          23 :         return parser(detail::input_adapter(first, last)).sax_parse(sax);
   16850             :     }
   16851             : 
   16852             :     /*!
   16853             :     @brief deserialize from stream
   16854             :     @deprecated This stream operator is deprecated and will be removed in
   16855             :                 version 4.0.0 of the library. Please use
   16856             :                 @ref operator>>(std::istream&, basic_json&)
   16857             :                 instead; that is, replace calls like `j << i;` with `i >> j;`.
   16858             :     @since version 1.0.0; deprecated since version 3.0.0
   16859             :     */
   16860             :     JSON_DEPRECATED
   16861           4 :     friend std::istream& operator<<(basic_json& j, std::istream& i)
   16862             :     {
   16863           4 :         return operator>>(i, j);
   16864             :     }
   16865             : 
   16866             :     /*!
   16867             :     @brief deserialize from stream
   16868             : 
   16869             :     Deserializes an input stream to a JSON value.
   16870             : 
   16871             :     @param[in,out] i  input stream to read a serialized JSON value from
   16872             :     @param[in,out] j  JSON value to write the deserialized input to
   16873             : 
   16874             :     @throw parse_error.101 in case of an unexpected token
   16875             :     @throw parse_error.102 if to_unicode fails or surrogate error
   16876             :     @throw parse_error.103 if to_unicode fails
   16877             : 
   16878             :     @complexity Linear in the length of the input. The parser is a predictive
   16879             :     LL(1) parser.
   16880             : 
   16881             :     @note A UTF-8 byte order mark is silently ignored.
   16882             : 
   16883             :     @liveexample{The example below shows how a JSON value is constructed by
   16884             :     reading a serialization from a stream.,operator_deserialize}
   16885             : 
   16886             :     @sa parse(std::istream&, const parser_callback_t) for a variant with a
   16887             :     parser callback function to filter values while parsing
   16888             : 
   16889             :     @since version 1.0.0
   16890             :     */
   16891          78 :     friend std::istream& operator>>(std::istream& i, basic_json& j)
   16892             :     {
   16893          89 :         parser(detail::input_adapter(i)).parse(false, j);
   16894          67 :         return i;
   16895             :     }
   16896             : 
   16897             :     /// @}
   16898             : 
   16899             :     ///////////////////////////
   16900             :     // convenience functions //
   16901             :     ///////////////////////////
   16902             : 
   16903             :     /*!
   16904             :     @brief return the type as string
   16905             : 
   16906             :     Returns the type name as string to be used in error messages - usually to
   16907             :     indicate that a function was called on a wrong JSON type.
   16908             : 
   16909             :     @return a string representation of a the @a m_type member:
   16910             :             Value type  | return value
   16911             :             ----------- | -------------
   16912             :             null        | `"null"`
   16913             :             boolean     | `"boolean"`
   16914             :             string      | `"string"`
   16915             :             number      | `"number"` (for all number types)
   16916             :             object      | `"object"`
   16917             :             array       | `"array"`
   16918             :             discarded   | `"discarded"`
   16919             : 
   16920             :     @exceptionsafety No-throw guarantee: this function never throws exceptions.
   16921             : 
   16922             :     @complexity Constant.
   16923             : 
   16924             :     @liveexample{The following code exemplifies `type_name()` for all JSON
   16925             :     types.,type_name}
   16926             : 
   16927             :     @sa @ref type() -- return the type of the JSON value
   16928             :     @sa @ref operator value_t() -- return the type of the JSON value (implicit)
   16929             : 
   16930             :     @since version 1.0.0, public since 2.1.0, `const char*` and `noexcept`
   16931             :     since 3.0.0
   16932             :     */
   16933         244 :     const char* type_name() const noexcept
   16934             :     {
   16935             :         {
   16936         244 :             switch (m_type)
   16937             :             {
   16938          36 :                 case value_t::null:
   16939          36 :                     return "null";
   16940          21 :                 case value_t::object:
   16941          21 :                     return "object";
   16942          26 :                 case value_t::array:
   16943          26 :                     return "array";
   16944          30 :                 case value_t::string:
   16945          30 :                     return "string";
   16946          27 :                 case value_t::boolean:
   16947          27 :                     return "boolean";
   16948           1 :                 case value_t::discarded:
   16949           1 :                     return "discarded";
   16950         103 :                 default:
   16951         103 :                     return "number";
   16952             :             }
   16953             :         }
   16954             :     }
   16955             : 
   16956             : 
   16957             :   private:
   16958             :     //////////////////////
   16959             :     // member variables //
   16960             :     //////////////////////
   16961             : 
   16962             :     /// the type of the current element
   16963             :     value_t m_type = value_t::null;
   16964             : 
   16965             :     /// the value of the current element
   16966             :     json_value m_value = {};
   16967             : 
   16968             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16969             :     // binary serialization/deserialization //
   16970             :     //////////////////////////////////////////
   16971             : 
   16972             :     /// @name binary serialization/deserialization support
   16973             :     /// @{
   16974             : 
   16975             :   public:
   16976             :     /*!
   16977             :     @brief create a CBOR serialization of a given JSON value
   16978             : 
   16979             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the CBOR (Concise
   16980             :     Binary Object Representation) serialization format. CBOR is a binary
   16981             :     serialization format which aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet
   16982             :     more efficient to parse.
   16983             : 
   16984             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   16985             :     CBOR types according to the CBOR specification (RFC 7049):
   16986             : 
   16987             :     JSON value type | value/range                                | CBOR type                          | first byte
   16988             :     --------------- | ------------------------------------------ | ---------------------------------- | ---------------
   16989             :     null            | `null`                                     | Null                               | 0xF6
   16990             :     boolean         | `true`                                     | True                               | 0xF5
   16991             :     boolean         | `false`                                    | False                              | 0xF4
   16992             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649          | Negative integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x3B
   16993             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769                        | Negative integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x3A
   16994             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                               | Negative integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x39
   16995             :     number_integer  | -128..-25                                  | Negative integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x38
   16996             :     number_integer  | -24..-1                                    | Negative integer                   | 0x20..0x37
   16997             :     number_integer  | 0..23                                      | Integer                            | 0x00..0x17
   16998             :     number_integer  | 24..255                                    | Unsigned integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x18
   16999             :     number_integer  | 256..65535                                 | Unsigned integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x19
   17000             :     number_integer  | 65536..4294967295                          | Unsigned integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x1A
   17001             :     number_integer  | 4294967296..18446744073709551615           | Unsigned integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x1B
   17002             :     number_unsigned | 0..23                                      | Integer                            | 0x00..0x17
   17003             :     number_unsigned | 24..255                                    | Unsigned integer (1 byte follow)   | 0x18
   17004             :     number_unsigned | 256..65535                                 | Unsigned integer (2 bytes follow)  | 0x19
   17005             :     number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295                          | Unsigned integer (4 bytes follow)  | 0x1A
   17006             :     number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615           | Unsigned integer (8 bytes follow)  | 0x1B
   17007             :     number_float    | *any value*                                | Double-Precision Float             | 0xFB
   17008             :     string          | *length*: 0..23                            | UTF-8 string                       | 0x60..0x77
   17009             :     string          | *length*: 23..255                          | UTF-8 string (1 byte follow)       | 0x78
   17010             :     string          | *length*: 256..65535                       | UTF-8 string (2 bytes follow)      | 0x79
   17011             :     string          | *length*: 65536..4294967295                | UTF-8 string (4 bytes follow)      | 0x7A
   17012             :     string          | *length*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615 | UTF-8 string (8 bytes follow)      | 0x7B
   17013             :     array           | *size*: 0..23                              | array                              | 0x80..0x97
   17014             :     array           | *size*: 23..255                            | array (1 byte follow)              | 0x98
   17015             :     array           | *size*: 256..65535                         | array (2 bytes follow)             | 0x99
   17016             :     array           | *size*: 65536..4294967295                  | array (4 bytes follow)             | 0x9A
   17017             :     array           | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615   | array (8 bytes follow)             | 0x9B
   17018             :     object          | *size*: 0..23                              | map                                | 0xA0..0xB7
   17019             :     object          | *size*: 23..255                            | map (1 byte follow)                | 0xB8
   17020             :     object          | *size*: 256..65535                         | map (2 bytes follow)               | 0xB9
   17021             :     object          | *size*: 65536..4294967295                  | map (4 bytes follow)               | 0xBA
   17022             :     object          | *size*: 4294967296..18446744073709551615   | map (8 bytes follow)               | 0xBB
   17023             : 
   17024             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   17025             :           can be converted to a CBOR value.
   17026             : 
   17027             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   17028             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   17029             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   17030             : 
   17031             :     @note The following CBOR types are not used in the conversion:
   17032             :           - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
   17033             :           - UTF-8 strings terminated by "break" (0x7F)
   17034             :           - arrays terminated by "break" (0x9F)
   17035             :           - maps terminated by "break" (0xBF)
   17036             :           - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
   17037             :           - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
   17038             :           - decimal fraction (0xC4)
   17039             :           - bigfloat (0xC5)
   17040             :           - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
   17041             :           - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
   17042             :           - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
   17043             :           - undefined (0xF7)
   17044             :           - half and single-precision floats (0xF9-0xFA)
   17045             :           - break (0xFF)
   17046             : 
   17047             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   17048             :     @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
   17049             : 
   17050             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   17051             : 
   17052             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   17053             :     vector in CBOR format.,to_cbor}
   17054             : 
   17055             :     @sa http://cbor.io
   17056             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool strict) for the
   17057             :         analogous deserialization
   17058             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
   17059             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   17060             :              related UBJSON format
   17061             : 
   17062             :     @since version 2.0.9
   17063             :     */
   17064      196957 :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_cbor(const basic_json& j)
   17065             :     {
   17066      196957 :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   17067      196957 :         to_cbor(j, result);
   17068      196957 :         return result;
   17069             :     }
   17070             : 
   17071      197086 :     static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
   17072             :     {
   17073      197086 :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_cbor(j);
   17074      197086 :     }
   17075             : 
   17076           2 :     static void to_cbor(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
   17077             :     {
   17078           2 :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_cbor(j);
   17079           2 :     }
   17080             : 
   17081             :     /*!
   17082             :     @brief create a MessagePack serialization of a given JSON value
   17083             : 
   17084             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the MessagePack
   17085             :     serialization format. MessagePack is a binary serialization format which
   17086             :     aims to be more compact than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
   17087             : 
   17088             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   17089             :     MessagePack types according to the MessagePack specification:
   17090             : 
   17091             :     JSON value type | value/range                       | MessagePack type | first byte
   17092             :     --------------- | --------------------------------- | ---------------- | ----------
   17093             :     null            | `null`                            | nil              | 0xC0
   17094             :     boolean         | `true`                            | true             | 0xC3
   17095             :     boolean         | `false`                           | false            | 0xC2
   17096             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64            | 0xD3
   17097             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769               | int32            | 0xD2
   17098             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                      | int16            | 0xD1
   17099             :     number_integer  | -128..-33                         | int8             | 0xD0
   17100             :     number_integer  | -32..-1                           | negative fixint  | 0xE0..0xFF
   17101             :     number_integer  | 0..127                            | positive fixint  | 0x00..0x7F
   17102             :     number_integer  | 128..255                          | uint 8           | 0xCC
   17103             :     number_integer  | 256..65535                        | uint 16          | 0xCD
   17104             :     number_integer  | 65536..4294967295                 | uint 32          | 0xCE
   17105             :     number_integer  | 4294967296..18446744073709551615  | uint 64          | 0xCF
   17106             :     number_unsigned | 0..127                            | positive fixint  | 0x00..0x7F
   17107             :     number_unsigned | 128..255                          | uint 8           | 0xCC
   17108             :     number_unsigned | 256..65535                        | uint 16          | 0xCD
   17109             :     number_unsigned | 65536..4294967295                 | uint 32          | 0xCE
   17110             :     number_unsigned | 4294967296..18446744073709551615  | uint 64          | 0xCF
   17111             :     number_float    | *any value*                       | float 64         | 0xCB
   17112             :     string          | *length*: 0..31                   | fixstr           | 0xA0..0xBF
   17113             :     string          | *length*: 32..255                 | str 8            | 0xD9
   17114             :     string          | *length*: 256..65535              | str 16           | 0xDA
   17115             :     string          | *length*: 65536..4294967295       | str 32           | 0xDB
   17116             :     array           | *size*: 0..15                     | fixarray         | 0x90..0x9F
   17117             :     array           | *size*: 16..65535                 | array 16         | 0xDC
   17118             :     array           | *size*: 65536..4294967295         | array 32         | 0xDD
   17119             :     object          | *size*: 0..15                     | fix map          | 0x80..0x8F
   17120             :     object          | *size*: 16..65535                 | map 16           | 0xDE
   17121             :     object          | *size*: 65536..4294967295         | map 32           | 0xDF
   17122             : 
   17123             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   17124             :           can be converted to a MessagePack value.
   17125             : 
   17126             :     @note The following values can **not** be converted to a MessagePack value:
   17127             :           - strings with more than 4294967295 bytes
   17128             :           - arrays with more than 4294967295 elements
   17129             :           - objects with more than 4294967295 elements
   17130             : 
   17131             :     @note The following MessagePack types are not used in the conversion:
   17132             :           - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
   17133             :           - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
   17134             :           - float 32 (0xCA)
   17135             :           - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
   17136             : 
   17137             :     @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
   17138             :           parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
   17139             : 
   17140             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   17141             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   17142             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   17143             : 
   17144             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   17145             :     @return MessagePack serialization as byte vector
   17146             : 
   17147             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   17148             : 
   17149             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   17150             :     vector in MessagePack format.,to_msgpack}
   17151             : 
   17152             :     @sa http://msgpack.org
   17153             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(const std::vector<uint8_t>&, const size_t) for the
   17154             :         analogous deserialization
   17155             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
   17156             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   17157             :              related UBJSON format
   17158             : 
   17159             :     @since version 2.0.9
   17160             :     */
   17161      196782 :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_msgpack(const basic_json& j)
   17162             :     {
   17163      196782 :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   17164      196782 :         to_msgpack(j, result);
   17165      196782 :         return result;
   17166             :     }
   17167             : 
   17168      196910 :     static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o)
   17169             :     {
   17170      196910 :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_msgpack(j);
   17171      196910 :     }
   17172             : 
   17173           2 :     static void to_msgpack(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o)
   17174             :     {
   17175           2 :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_msgpack(j);
   17176           2 :     }
   17177             : 
   17178             :     /*!
   17179             :     @brief create a UBJSON serialization of a given JSON value
   17180             : 
   17181             :     Serializes a given JSON value @a j to a byte vector using the UBJSON
   17182             :     (Universal Binary JSON) serialization format. UBJSON aims to be more compact
   17183             :     than JSON itself, yet more efficient to parse.
   17184             : 
   17185             :     The library uses the following mapping from JSON values types to
   17186             :     UBJSON types according to the UBJSON specification:
   17187             : 
   17188             :     JSON value type | value/range                       | UBJSON type | marker
   17189             :     --------------- | --------------------------------- | ----------- | ------
   17190             :     null            | `null`                            | null        | `Z`
   17191             :     boolean         | `true`                            | true        | `T`
   17192             :     boolean         | `false`                           | false       | `F`
   17193             :     number_integer  | -9223372036854775808..-2147483649 | int64       | `L`
   17194             :     number_integer  | -2147483648..-32769               | int32       | `l`
   17195             :     number_integer  | -32768..-129                      | int16       | `I`
   17196             :     number_integer  | -128..127                         | int8        | `i`
   17197             :     number_integer  | 128..255                          | uint8       | `U`
   17198             :     number_integer  | 256..32767                        | int16       | `I`
   17199             :     number_integer  | 32768..2147483647                 | int32       | `l`
   17200             :     number_integer  | 2147483648..9223372036854775807   | int64       | `L`
   17201             :     number_unsigned | 0..127                            | int8        | `i`
   17202             :     number_unsigned | 128..255                          | uint8       | `U`
   17203             :     number_unsigned | 256..32767                        | int16       | `I`
   17204             :     number_unsigned | 32768..2147483647                 | int32       | `l`
   17205             :     number_unsigned | 2147483648..9223372036854775807   | int64       | `L`
   17206             :     number_float    | *any value*                       | float64     | `D`
   17207             :     string          | *with shortest length indicator*  | string      | `S`
   17208             :     array           | *see notes on optimized format*   | array       | `[`
   17209             :     object          | *see notes on optimized format*   | map         | `{`
   17210             : 
   17211             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any JSON value type
   17212             :           can be converted to a UBJSON value.
   17213             : 
   17214             :     @note The following values can **not** be converted to a UBJSON value:
   17215             :           - strings with more than 9223372036854775807 bytes (theoretical)
   17216             :           - unsigned integer numbers above 9223372036854775807
   17217             : 
   17218             :     @note The following markers are not used in the conversion:
   17219             :           - `Z`: no-op values are not created.
   17220             :           - `C`: single-byte strings are serialized with `S` markers.
   17221             : 
   17222             :     @note Any UBJSON output created @ref to_ubjson can be successfully parsed
   17223             :           by @ref from_ubjson.
   17224             : 
   17225             :     @note If NaN or Infinity are stored inside a JSON number, they are
   17226             :           serialized properly. This behavior differs from the @ref dump()
   17227             :           function which serializes NaN or Infinity to `null`.
   17228             : 
   17229             :     @note The optimized formats for containers are supported: Parameter
   17230             :           @a use_size adds size information to the beginning of a container and
   17231             :           removes the closing marker. Parameter @a use_type further checks
   17232             :           whether all elements of a container have the same type and adds the
   17233             :           type marker to the beginning of the container. The @a use_type
   17234             :           parameter must only be used together with @a use_size = true. Note
   17235             :           that @a use_size = true alone may result in larger representations -
   17236             :           the benefit of this parameter is that the receiving side is
   17237             :           immediately informed on the number of elements of the container.
   17238             : 
   17239             :     @param[in] j  JSON value to serialize
   17240             :     @param[in] use_size  whether to add size annotations to container types
   17241             :     @param[in] use_type  whether to add type annotations to container types
   17242             :                          (must be combined with @a use_size = true)
   17243             :     @return UBJSON serialization as byte vector
   17244             : 
   17245             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the JSON value @a j.
   17246             : 
   17247             :     @liveexample{The example shows the serialization of a JSON value to a byte
   17248             :     vector in UBJSON format.,to_ubjson}
   17249             : 
   17250             :     @sa http://ubjson.org
   17251             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool strict) for the
   17252             :         analogous deserialization
   17253             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json& for the related CBOR format
   17254             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the related MessagePack format
   17255             : 
   17256             :     @since version 3.1.0
   17257             :     */
   17258       98698 :     static std::vector<uint8_t> to_ubjson(const basic_json& j,
   17259             :                                           const bool use_size = false,
   17260             :                                           const bool use_type = false)
   17261             :     {
   17262       98698 :         std::vector<uint8_t> result;
   17263       98699 :         to_ubjson(j, result, use_size, use_type);
   17264       98697 :         return result;
   17265             :     }
   17266             : 
   17267       98740 :     static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<uint8_t> o,
   17268             :                           const bool use_size = false, const bool use_type = false)
   17269             :     {
   17270       98741 :         binary_writer<uint8_t>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
   17271       98739 :     }
   17272             : 
   17273             :     static void to_ubjson(const basic_json& j, detail::output_adapter<char> o,
   17274             :                           const bool use_size = false, const bool use_type = false)
   17275             :     {
   17276             :         binary_writer<char>(o).write_ubjson(j, use_size, use_type);
   17277             :     }
   17278             : 
   17279             :     /*!
   17280             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in CBOR format
   17281             : 
   17282             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the CBOR (Concise
   17283             :     Binary Object Representation) serialization format.
   17284             : 
   17285             :     The library maps CBOR types to JSON value types as follows:
   17286             : 
   17287             :     CBOR type              | JSON value type | first byte
   17288             :     ---------------------- | --------------- | ----------
   17289             :     Integer                | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x17
   17290             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x18
   17291             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x19
   17292             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x1A
   17293             :     Unsigned integer       | number_unsigned | 0x1B
   17294             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x20..0x37
   17295             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x38
   17296             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x39
   17297             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x3A
   17298             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x3B
   17299             :     Negative integer       | number_integer  | 0x40..0x57
   17300             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x60..0x77
   17301             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x78
   17302             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x79
   17303             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7A
   17304             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7B
   17305             :     UTF-8 string           | string          | 0x7F
   17306             :     array                  | array           | 0x80..0x97
   17307             :     array                  | array           | 0x98
   17308             :     array                  | array           | 0x99
   17309             :     array                  | array           | 0x9A
   17310             :     array                  | array           | 0x9B
   17311             :     array                  | array           | 0x9F
   17312             :     map                    | object          | 0xA0..0xB7
   17313             :     map                    | object          | 0xB8
   17314             :     map                    | object          | 0xB9
   17315             :     map                    | object          | 0xBA
   17316             :     map                    | object          | 0xBB
   17317             :     map                    | object          | 0xBF
   17318             :     False                  | `false`         | 0xF4
   17319             :     True                   | `true`          | 0xF5
   17320             :     Nill                   | `null`          | 0xF6
   17321             :     Half-Precision Float   | number_float    | 0xF9
   17322             :     Single-Precision Float | number_float    | 0xFA
   17323             :     Double-Precision Float | number_float    | 0xFB
   17324             : 
   17325             :     @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all CBOR
   17326             :              types can be converted to a JSON value. The following CBOR types
   17327             :              are not supported and will yield parse errors (parse_error.112):
   17328             :              - byte strings (0x40..0x5F)
   17329             :              - date/time (0xC0..0xC1)
   17330             :              - bignum (0xC2..0xC3)
   17331             :              - decimal fraction (0xC4)
   17332             :              - bigfloat (0xC5)
   17333             :              - tagged items (0xC6..0xD4, 0xD8..0xDB)
   17334             :              - expected conversions (0xD5..0xD7)
   17335             :              - simple values (0xE0..0xF3, 0xF8)
   17336             :              - undefined (0xF7)
   17337             : 
   17338             :     @warning CBOR allows map keys of any type, whereas JSON only allows
   17339             :              strings as keys in object values. Therefore, CBOR maps with keys
   17340             :              other than UTF-8 strings are rejected (parse_error.113).
   17341             : 
   17342             :     @note Any CBOR output created @ref to_cbor can be successfully parsed by
   17343             :           @ref from_cbor.
   17344             : 
   17345             :     @param[in] i  an input in CBOR format convertible to an input adapter
   17346             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   17347             :                        (true by default)
   17348             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions  whether to throw exceptions in case of a
   17349             :     parse error (optional, true by default)
   17350             : 
   17351             :     @return deserialized JSON value
   17352             : 
   17353             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   17354             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   17355             :     @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from CBOR were
   17356             :     used in the given input @a v or if the input is not valid CBOR
   17357             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
   17358             : 
   17359             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   17360             : 
   17361             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in CBOR
   17362             :     format to a JSON value.,from_cbor}
   17363             : 
   17364             :     @sa http://cbor.io
   17365             :     @sa @ref to_cbor(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
   17366             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for the
   17367             :         related MessagePack format
   17368             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for the
   17369             :         related UBJSON format
   17370             : 
   17371             :     @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
   17372             :            consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
   17373             :            @a strict parameter since 3.0.0; added @allow_exceptions parameter
   17374             :            since 3.2.0
   17375             :     */
   17376      394918 :     static basic_json from_cbor(detail::input_adapter&& i,
   17377             :                                 const bool strict = true,
   17378             :                                 const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17379             :     {
   17380      789836 :         basic_json result;
   17381      789836 :         detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
   17382      395352 :         const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::cbor, &sdp, strict);
   17383      788968 :         return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
   17384             :     }
   17385             : 
   17386             :     /*!
   17387             :     @copydoc from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool)
   17388             :     */
   17389             :     template<typename A1, typename A2,
   17390             :              detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
   17391           1 :     static basic_json from_cbor(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
   17392             :                                 const bool strict = true,
   17393             :                                 const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17394             :     {
   17395           2 :         basic_json result;
   17396           2 :         detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
   17397           1 :         const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::cbor, &sdp, strict);
   17398           2 :         return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
   17399             :     }
   17400             : 
   17401             :     /*!
   17402             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in MessagePack format
   17403             : 
   17404             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the MessagePack
   17405             :     serialization format.
   17406             : 
   17407             :     The library maps MessagePack types to JSON value types as follows:
   17408             : 
   17409             :     MessagePack type | JSON value type | first byte
   17410             :     ---------------- | --------------- | ----------
   17411             :     positive fixint  | number_unsigned | 0x00..0x7F
   17412             :     fixmap           | object          | 0x80..0x8F
   17413             :     fixarray         | array           | 0x90..0x9F
   17414             :     fixstr           | string          | 0xA0..0xBF
   17415             :     nil              | `null`          | 0xC0
   17416             :     false            | `false`         | 0xC2
   17417             :     true             | `true`          | 0xC3
   17418             :     float 32         | number_float    | 0xCA
   17419             :     float 64         | number_float    | 0xCB
   17420             :     uint 8           | number_unsigned | 0xCC
   17421             :     uint 16          | number_unsigned | 0xCD
   17422             :     uint 32          | number_unsigned | 0xCE
   17423             :     uint 64          | number_unsigned | 0xCF
   17424             :     int 8            | number_integer  | 0xD0
   17425             :     int 16           | number_integer  | 0xD1
   17426             :     int 32           | number_integer  | 0xD2
   17427             :     int 64           | number_integer  | 0xD3
   17428             :     str 8            | string          | 0xD9
   17429             :     str 16           | string          | 0xDA
   17430             :     str 32           | string          | 0xDB
   17431             :     array 16         | array           | 0xDC
   17432             :     array 32         | array           | 0xDD
   17433             :     map 16           | object          | 0xDE
   17434             :     map 32           | object          | 0xDF
   17435             :     negative fixint  | number_integer  | 0xE0-0xFF
   17436             : 
   17437             :     @warning The mapping is **incomplete** in the sense that not all
   17438             :              MessagePack types can be converted to a JSON value. The following
   17439             :              MessagePack types are not supported and will yield parse errors:
   17440             :               - bin 8 - bin 32 (0xC4..0xC6)
   17441             :               - ext 8 - ext 32 (0xC7..0xC9)
   17442             :               - fixext 1 - fixext 16 (0xD4..0xD8)
   17443             : 
   17444             :     @note Any MessagePack output created @ref to_msgpack can be successfully
   17445             :           parsed by @ref from_msgpack.
   17446             : 
   17447             :     @param[in] i  an input in MessagePack format convertible to an input
   17448             :                   adapter
   17449             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   17450             :                        (true by default)
   17451             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions  whether to throw exceptions in case of a
   17452             :     parse error (optional, true by default)
   17453             : 
   17454             :     @return deserialized JSON value
   17455             : 
   17456             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   17457             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   17458             :     @throw parse_error.112 if unsupported features from MessagePack were
   17459             :     used in the given input @a i or if the input is not valid MessagePack
   17460             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string was expected as map key, but not found
   17461             : 
   17462             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   17463             : 
   17464             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
   17465             :     MessagePack format to a JSON value.,from_msgpack}
   17466             : 
   17467             :     @sa http://msgpack.org
   17468             :     @sa @ref to_msgpack(const basic_json&) for the analogous serialization
   17469             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for the
   17470             :         related CBOR format
   17471             :     @sa @ref from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for
   17472             :         the related UBJSON format
   17473             : 
   17474             :     @since version 2.0.9; parameter @a start_index since 2.1.1; changed to
   17475             :            consume input adapters, removed start_index parameter, and added
   17476             :            @a strict parameter since 3.0.0; added @allow_exceptions parameter
   17477             :            since 3.2.0
   17478             :     */
   17479      361448 :     static basic_json from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter&& i,
   17480             :                                    const bool strict = true,
   17481             :                                    const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17482             :     {
   17483      722896 :         basic_json result;
   17484      722896 :         detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
   17485      361549 :         const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::msgpack, &sdp, strict);
   17486      722694 :         return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
   17487             :     }
   17488             : 
   17489             :     /*!
   17490             :     @copydoc from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool)
   17491             :     */
   17492             :     template<typename A1, typename A2,
   17493             :              detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
   17494           1 :     static basic_json from_msgpack(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
   17495             :                                    const bool strict = true,
   17496             :                                    const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17497             :     {
   17498           2 :         basic_json result;
   17499           2 :         detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
   17500           1 :         const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(std::forward<A1>(a1), std::forward<A2>(a2))).sax_parse(input_format_t::msgpack, &sdp, strict);
   17501           2 :         return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
   17502             :     }
   17503             : 
   17504             :     /*!
   17505             :     @brief create a JSON value from an input in UBJSON format
   17506             : 
   17507             :     Deserializes a given input @a i to a JSON value using the UBJSON (Universal
   17508             :     Binary JSON) serialization format.
   17509             : 
   17510             :     The library maps UBJSON types to JSON value types as follows:
   17511             : 
   17512             :     UBJSON type | JSON value type                         | marker
   17513             :     ----------- | --------------------------------------- | ------
   17514             :     no-op       | *no value, next value is read*          | `N`
   17515             :     null        | `null`                                  | `Z`
   17516             :     false       | `false`                                 | `F`
   17517             :     true        | `true`                                  | `T`
   17518             :     float32     | number_float                            | `d`
   17519             :     float64     | number_float                            | `D`
   17520             :     uint8       | number_unsigned                         | `U`
   17521             :     int8        | number_integer                          | `i`
   17522             :     int16       | number_integer                          | `I`
   17523             :     int32       | number_integer                          | `l`
   17524             :     int64       | number_integer                          | `L`
   17525             :     string      | string                                  | `S`
   17526             :     char        | string                                  | `C`
   17527             :     array       | array (optimized values are supported)  | `[`
   17528             :     object      | object (optimized values are supported) | `{`
   17529             : 
   17530             :     @note The mapping is **complete** in the sense that any UBJSON value can
   17531             :           be converted to a JSON value.
   17532             : 
   17533             :     @param[in] i  an input in UBJSON format convertible to an input adapter
   17534             :     @param[in] strict  whether to expect the input to be consumed until EOF
   17535             :                        (true by default)
   17536             :     @param[in] allow_exceptions  whether to throw exceptions in case of a
   17537             :     parse error (optional, true by default)
   17538             : 
   17539             :     @return deserialized JSON value
   17540             : 
   17541             :     @throw parse_error.110 if the given input ends prematurely or the end of
   17542             :     file was not reached when @a strict was set to true
   17543             :     @throw parse_error.112 if a parse error occurs
   17544             :     @throw parse_error.113 if a string could not be parsed successfully
   17545             : 
   17546             :     @complexity Linear in the size of the input @a i.
   17547             : 
   17548             :     @liveexample{The example shows the deserialization of a byte vector in
   17549             :     UBJSON format to a JSON value.,from_ubjson}
   17550             : 
   17551             :     @sa http://ubjson.org
   17552             :     @sa @ref to_ubjson(const basic_json&, const bool, const bool) for the
   17553             :              analogous serialization
   17554             :     @sa @ref from_cbor(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for the
   17555             :         related CBOR format
   17556             :     @sa @ref from_msgpack(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool) for
   17557             :         the related MessagePack format
   17558             : 
   17559             :     @since version 3.1.0; added @allow_exceptions parameter since 3.2.0
   17560             :     */
   17561      197784 :     static basic_json from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter&& i,
   17562             :                                   const bool strict = true,
   17563             :                                   const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17564             :     {
   17565      395568 :         basic_json result;
   17566      395568 :         detail::json_sax_dom_parser<basic_json> sdp(result, allow_exceptions);
   17567      198071 :         const bool res = binary_reader(detail::input_adapter(i)).sax_parse(input_format_t::ubjson, &sdp, strict);
   17568      394994 :         return res ? result : basic_json(value_t::discarded);
   17569             :     }
   17570             : 
   17571             :     /*!
   17572             :     @copydoc from_ubjson(detail::input_adapter, const bool, const bool)
   17573             :     */
   17574             :     template<typename A1, typename A2,
   17575             :              detail::enable_if_t<std::is_constructible<detail::input_adapter, A1, A2>::value, int> = 0>
   17576             :     static basic_json from_ubjson(A1 && a1, A2 && a2,
   17577             :                                   const bool strict = true,
   17578             :                                   const bool allow_exceptions = true)
   17579             :     {

   17586             :     /// @}
   17587             : 
   17588             :     //////////////////////////
   17589             :     // JSON Pointer support //
   17590             :     //////////////////////////
   17591             : 
   17592             :     /// @name JSON Pointer functions
   17593             :     /// @{
   17594             : 
   17595             :     /*!
   17596             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17597             : 
   17598             :     Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
   17599             :     No bound checking is performed. Similar to @ref operator[](const typename
   17600             :     object_t::key_type&), `null` values are created in arrays and objects if
   17601             :     necessary.
   17602             : 
   17603             :     In particular:
   17604             :     - If the JSON pointer points to an object key that does not exist, it
   17605             :       is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
   17606             :       is returned.
   17607             :     - If the JSON pointer points to an array index that does not exist, it
   17608             :       is created an filled with a `null` value before a reference to it
   17609             :       is returned. All indices between the current maximum and the given
   17610             :       index are also filled with `null`.
   17611             :     - The special value `-` is treated as a synonym for the index past the
   17612             :       end.
   17613             : 
   17614             :     @param[in] ptr  a JSON pointer
   17615             : 
   17616             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17617             : 
   17618             :     @complexity Constant.
   17619             : 
   17620             :     @throw parse_error.106   if an array index begins with '0'
   17621             :     @throw parse_error.109   if an array index was not a number
   17622             :     @throw out_of_range.404  if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
   17623             : 
   17624             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,operatorjson_pointer}
   17625             : 
   17626             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17627             :     */
   17628         114 :     reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr)
   17629             :     {
   17630         114 :         return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
   17631             :     }
   17632             : 
   17633             :     /*!
   17634             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17635             : 
   17636             :     Uses a JSON pointer to retrieve a reference to the respective JSON value.
   17637             :     No bound checking is performed. The function does not change the JSON
   17638             :     value; no `null` values are created. In particular, the the special value
   17639             :     `-` yields an exception.
   17640             : 
   17641             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17642             : 
   17643             :     @return const reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17644             : 
   17645             :     @complexity Constant.
   17646             : 
   17647             :     @throw parse_error.106   if an array index begins with '0'
   17648             :     @throw parse_error.109   if an array index was not a number
   17649             :     @throw out_of_range.402  if the array index '-' is used
   17650             :     @throw out_of_range.404  if the JSON pointer can not be resolved
   17651             : 
   17652             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,operatorjson_pointer_const}
   17653             : 
   17654             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17655             :     */
   17656          23 :     const_reference operator[](const json_pointer& ptr) const
   17657             :     {
   17658          23 :         return ptr.get_unchecked(this);
   17659             :     }
   17660             : 
   17661             :     /*!
   17662             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17663             : 
   17664             :     Returns a reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a ptr,
   17665             :     with bounds checking.
   17666             : 
   17667             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17668             : 
   17669             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr
   17670             : 
   17671             :     @throw parse_error.106 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17672             :     begins with '0'. See example below.
   17673             : 
   17674             :     @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17675             :     is not a number. See example below.
   17676             : 
   17677             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17678             :     is out of range. See example below.
   17679             : 
   17680             :     @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
   17681             :     pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
   17682             :     implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
   17683             : 
   17684             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
   17685             :     which cannot be found. See example below.
   17686             : 
   17687             :     @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
   17688             :     See example below.
   17689             : 
   17690             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   17691             :     changes in the JSON value.
   17692             : 
   17693             :     @complexity Constant.
   17694             : 
   17695             :     @since version 2.0.0
   17696             : 
   17697             :     @liveexample{The behavior is shown in the example.,at_json_pointer}
   17698             :     */
   17699         178 :     reference at(const json_pointer& ptr)
   17700             :     {
   17701         178 :         return ptr.get_checked(this);
   17702             :     }
   17703             : 
   17704             :     /*!
   17705             :     @brief access specified element via JSON Pointer
   17706             : 
   17707             :     Returns a const reference to the element at with specified JSON pointer @a
   17708             :     ptr, with bounds checking.
   17709             : 
   17710             :     @param[in] ptr  JSON pointer to the desired element
   17711             : 
   17712             :     @return reference to the element pointed to by @a ptr

   17715             :     begins with '0'. See example below.
   17716             : 
   17717             :     @throw parse_error.109 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17718             :     is not a number. See example below.

   17720             :     @throw out_of_range.401 if an array index in the passed JSON pointer @a ptr
   17721             :     is out of range. See example below.
   17722             : 
   17723             :     @throw out_of_range.402 if the array index '-' is used in the passed JSON
   17724             :     pointer @a ptr. As `at` provides checked access (and no elements are
   17725             :     implicitly inserted), the index '-' is always invalid. See example below.
   17726             : 
   17727             :     @throw out_of_range.403 if the JSON pointer describes a key of an object
   17728             :     which cannot be found. See example below.
   17729             : 
   17730             :     @throw out_of_range.404 if the JSON pointer @a ptr can not be resolved.
   17731             :     See example below.
   17732             : 
   17733             :     @exceptionsafety Strong guarantee: if an exception is thrown, there are no
   17734             :     changes in the JSON value.
   17735             : 
   17736             :     @complexity Constant.
   17737             :

   17741             :     */
